story:
"Bei täglichen Wegstrecken von weit mehr als 100 km, erscheint die Marathondistanz von 42 km einem Orca in seinem natürlichen Lebensraum wohl wie ein typischer Morgen-Spaziergang. Aber für manche Menschen eine einmalige Lebenserfahrung!"

With daily travel distances of far more than 100km, the marathon distance of 42km is a typical morning ride for an orca in his natural habitat … but for some humans a “once in a lifetime experience” 

Der Anlass
The Cause

SHIFTING VALUES ist eine in Österreich ansässige, international tätige und aktive Kampagnenagentur, die die Fortsetzung der unabhängigen wissenschaftlichen Arbeit von StudentInnen des Far East Russia Orca Project(FEROP) und ihren Schutzbemühungen für Orcas und andere Meeressäuger in Gewässern in Ostrussland unterstützt. Zu diesem Zweck starten wir die Initiative „Running for Orcas 2015“. Unser Team und begeisterungsfähige Freunde und Interessierte nehmen das Martyrium auf sich und nehmen am 12.April am Wien-Marathon teil. Wir nutzen den Anlass, um für die Erforschung und den Schutz der Orcas in russischen Gewässern zu werben und bitten Dich um Deine Unterstützung!

SHIFTING VALUES, an Austrian based and international active campaigning agency, supports the continued efforts by Russian students and researchers of the Far East Russia Orca Project (FEROP) to protect orcas as well as other marine wildlife in Far East Russia by initiating the event "Running for Orcas 2015". In 2015, the agency engages in contributing towards orca conservation and is organizing a team to use its participation at the Vienna City Marathon to launch a crowdfunding initiative in support of the continued independent research and orca conservation initiatives in Russia.

Orcas, der größte Delfin und König der Meere
Orcas, the largest dolphin and top predator in our oceans

Der Orca, auch bekannt als Killerwal, ist die größte Delfinart. Orcas zählen zu den am besten erforschten Meeressäugern und stehen am Ende der Nahrungskette. Wissenschaftler haben bei Orcas unterschiedliche Kulturen identifiziert, die unterschiedliche Dialekte und Nahrungsgewohnheiten, sowie Gruppenzusammensetzungen haben. Ihre Einzigartigkeit macht sie zu den idealen Botschaftern für die Einrichtung von Schutzzonen.

Orcas, also known as killer whales (the largest dolphin species), are traditionally considered to be among the most clever and beautiful sea creatures, and one of the fastest and strongest, with no predators of its own. In the world’s oceans, orcas have evolved into different cultures performing different dialects, social groupings and diets. This makes them one of the most outstanding research “subjects” but at the same time “Ambassadors” for protecting ocean habitats and marine biodiversity.

FEROP – Das Projekt
FEROP - The Project

Die ostrussischen Gewässer sind  eine der wenigen Regionen in denen Orcas weiterhin für die Showzwecke  gefangen werden. Die in den vergangenen Jahren seitens des FEROP Teams veröffentlichten wissenschaftlichen Daten werden auch genutzt, um entsprechende Schutzmaßnahmen zu entwickeln. Der Fang und die Haltung von Orcas in Gefangenschaft sind in keiner Weise zu rechtfertigen.

Russia is one of the few regions where orcas have been captured in recent years. The FEROP Team, made of young, passionate Russian scientists has been extremely active in publishing scientific results about their findings and orcas in the wild and at the same time calling for stricter conservation measures, including the prohibition of orca captures.

Shifting Values und Orcas
Shifting Values and Orcas

Gemeinsam mit FEROP veröffentlichte Shifting Values im Frühjahr 2012 Kenntnis und Bildmaterial des von FEROP identifizierten rein weißen Orca-Bullen „Iceberg“ und sorgte für globale Berichterstattung.

2014 organisierte SHIFTING VALUES die einzigen offiziellen Kinovorstellung des Dokumentarfilms BLACKFISH in Österreich

In spring 2012 Shifting Values in close cooperation with FEROP released information and images of the existence of a unique completely white orca bull identified by FEROP which resulted in global media coverage.

In 2014, SHIFTING VALUES brought the documentary BLACKFISH to Austria, organizing a few selective screenings of this exposure documentary which caused significant problems for the amusement park industry, in particular Sea World.


FEROP 2015

Die Einnahmen von €2.500 werden zur Fortführung der unabhängigen Forschung der Studenten beitragen und die Anschaffung von neuer Ausrüstung ermöglichen.

Raised funds of €2.500 will contribute to the continuation of independent research by students in Russia and support the acquisition of new equipment.

€500: Action Go Pro Camera 


€500: HD Video Camera 


€1500: Hexacopter

Die HD Videokamera als auch  GoPro Kamera werden benötigt, um in Ergänzung der Photo-Identifikationsforschung (Bestimmung der Inidividuen) das dabei zu beobachtende Verhalten via Video zu dokumentieren. Die z.B. an einer Person fixierte GoPro erleichtert dabei das gleichzeitige Manövrieren des Bootes in schwierigen Situationen. Die Drohne soll zusätzliches Bildmaterial aus der Luft beisteuern, um weitere Erkenntnisse während der Forschungsfahrten zu erhalten.

The HD Video camera and the action GoPro camera will allow the team to capture orca behavior while it happens and to provide a record of each encounter that can be used to compare against the still photos. GoPro allows hands-free mounting on the head for ease of use on a moving boat and this camera can be adapted for use with the hexacopter. The hexacopter will allow us to obtain valuable aerial photos to document health and aspects of their behavior.

SHIFTING VALUES – TEAM

Nicolas Entrup, Marathon:
„42 ist die Antwort auf alles. Zumindest nach Douglas-Adams in „per Anhalter durch die Galaxis“. Was sonst also, außer im Alter von 42 die Herausforderung 42 km laufend zu bewältigen. Als Motivation dann noch die wichtige Arbeit toller Menschen für faszinierende Tiere zu unterstützen. Absolut positiv! (M)ein richtiger Mehrwert!“

Sebastian Palasser, Marathon:
„Ausdauersport begleitet mich schon mein ganzes junges Leben, als kleines Kind bei den zahlreichen Zieleinläufen meines Vaters, als Jugendlicher im Schwimmsport und als 18-jähriger Ironman. Meine Leidenschaft für einen guten Zweck zur Verfügung zu stellen ist die extra Portion Motivation!"

Peter Treibenreif, Marathon:
"Einen Marathon laufen bedeutet für mich sportlich einmal im Jahr meine Grenzen zu überschreiten. Diesen Event den Orcas zu widmen ist für mich zusätzlich motivierend. Orcas gehören für mich zu den faszinierendsten Tieren auf dieser Welt."

Ivan Topic, Marathon:
"If you become better, your life becomes better."

Selina Kolland, Half Marathon:
"Wenn du danach immer noch gut aussiehst, dann hast du etwas falsch gemacht."

Birgit Palasser, Half Marathon:
"Nach vielen Jahren des Laufens ohne Wettkämpfe will ich mich selbst aus der Reserve locken. Der Anreiz, dabei die Erforschung der Orcas zu unterstützen, ist der erste Schritt, mit der tatsächlichen Anmeldung ist der zweite Schritt getan, nun heißt es nur noch Laufen, Schritt für Schritt!"

Laura Soyer, Half Marathon:
„Tiere können nicht für sich selbst sprechen. Und deshalb ist es so wichtig, dass wir als Menschen unsere Stimme für sie erheben und uns für sie einsetzen." (Gillian Anderson)

Bernhard Cares, Half Marathon:
"Das Meer tröstet, weil es die Zeit verschluckt. Meer und Zeit, Orcas und Marathon - wie schön und unterstützenswert ist diese Idee!"

Margot Pock, Half Marathon:
"Laufend Gutes tun - da bin ich dabei! Meinen ersten Halbmarathon bin ich gelaufen, um mir zu beweisen, dass ich es schaffen kann. Diesmal ist es diese wirklich tolle Projekt zum Schutz der Orcas, das mich motivieren wird, bis zum Ende durchzuhalten."

Updates vom Team findest du im #runningfororcas - Blog.
Updates from the team can be found in the #runningfororcas - blog(german only).

Support

Shifting Values bedankt sich bei den internationalen Schutzorganisationen OceanCare (www.oceancare.org) und WDC (www.de.whales.org) für die Materialien als Dankeschön für die Unterstützer, sowie für deren Kommunikation über die Initiative.
ShiftingValues expresses its THANKS to the two international marine conservation organisations OceanCare (www.oceancare.org) and WDC (www.de.whales.org) for supporting this initiative with items to pass on to supporters as well as for sharing information about this initiative.

Schritt, mit der tatsächlichen Anmeldung ist der zweite Schritt getan, nun
heißt es nur noch Laufen, Schritt für Schritt!"
Laura
Soyer, Half Marathon:„Tiere können nicht für sich selbst
sprechen. Und deshalb ist es so wichtig, dass wir als Menschen unsere Stimme
für sie erheben und uns für sie einsetzen." (Gillian Anderson)
Bernhard
Cares, Half Marathon:"Das Meer tröstet,
weil es die Zeit verschluckt. Meer und Zeit, Orcas und Marathon - wie schön und
unterstützenswert ist diese Idee!"
Margot Pock, Half Marathon:"Laufend Gutes tun - da bin ich dabei! Meinen ersten Halbmarathon bin ich gelaufen, um mir zu beweisen, dass ich es schaffen kann. Diesmal ist es diese wirklich tolle Projekt zum Schutz der Orcas, das mich motivieren wird, bis zum Ende durchzuhalten."

Updates vom Team findest du im #runningfororcas - Blog.Updates from the team can be found in the #runningfororcas - blog(german only).



Support
Shifting Values bedankt sich bei den internationalen
Schutzorganisationen OceanCare
(www.oceancare.org) und WDC (www.de.whales.org) für die Materialien als Dankeschön für die Unterstützer, sowie für deren
Kommunikation über die Initiative.
ShiftingValues expresses its THANKS to the two international marine
conservation organisations OceanCare (www.oceancare.org) and WDC (www.de.whales.org) for supporting this initiative with items to
pass on to supporters as well as for sharing information about this initiative.

story:
The Problem

Each year community groups in Streatham spend £7 - £10,000 erecting three real Christmas trees and disposing of them in January. Sadly austerity means the groups that have traditionally paid for these trees no longer have the money, and historically the lighting display has been very poor.

The Solution 

The Lane & Vale team and InStreatham have worked hard all year to come up with a solution for 2015 but unfortunately the funds were not available to go ahead, although we have already raised £9,600 toward the project and need £8,699 to make it happen in 2016. 

  • Plant permanent trees instead of buying temporary ones.
  • Buy lighting equipment that can be reused each year.
Please note that The Friends of Streatham Green have asked that only temporary trees are erected in Babington Road, so this project does not cover that area.

How Will The Money Be Spent

  • Purchase of three trees and tree planting £6,488.72.
  • Three years of maintenance, pruning, and watering to help the trees establish, and replacement insurance should the trees die or be vandalised £4,278.93.
  • Permanent lighting for the trees and reusable Christmas lights £7,231.52.
  • All costs are one off, there will be some ongoing costs for annual lighting installation and the tree lighting ceremony.

The Trees

We cannot plant Fir trees in paved areas due to their large root systems, so we will instead plant evergreen trees that provide a sweet smelling floral display in the summer and can be lit in the style of a Christmas Tree in the Winter.

  • One 7 - 8 metre Nordmann fir (Abies Nordmanniana) for Streatham Common.
  • 5 metre Conical Southern Magnolia (Magnolia Grandiflora) for Streatham Hill and Streatham Common.

Who Are Lane & Vale?

Established in 2012 Lane & Vale is a community organisation for the Streatham Vale area funded by the Streatham Bridge Business Association. 
In 2013/14 we received £67,500 of funding from the Mayor of London and match funding from Lambeth Council to plant 300 new street trees across Streatham. We were very pleased to win the Groundwork/Forestry Commission RE:LEAF Street Tree Award for this endeavour. 
Another such project is underway in 2014/15 for which the Mayor of London has already offered a further £67,500.

story:
What's at stake?

The coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge sweeps off the northern foothills of Alaska’s Brooks Range in rolling hills, river valleys, deep lakes, and sprawling tundra. Looking south from the ice-choked Arctic Ocean, the mountains shift in and out of focus and the air shimmers with the distance. It is a place that still belongs to birds, caribou, bears, wolves, and the Arctic wind.

The Arctic Refuge is a wild land balancing on the edge. Battles to open the coastal plain of the Refuge to oil drilling rage in the U.S. Congress. One of the last great expanses of wild country in North America persists on political whim. 

Why Now?

The campaign to permanently protect the refuge now has a rare chance to gain ground. The coastal plain was recently designated by the Department of the Interior as a Wilderness Study Area, a prelude to complete protection. To make this a reality, the conservation community needs to effectively reach out to the public and policy-makers. To achieve that successfully, we need images and video that accurately portray the beauty, wildlife, and wilderness of the refuge. 

To this end, Audubon Alaska has teamed up with two professional Alaskan photographers. In June, we will make an expedition to the refuge to gather images and footage in the threatened 1002 area of the coastal plain. With the resulting imagery, and the passion of those who defend the refuge, we can shift the political tide working against these incredible Arctic wildlands. 

How?

There is power in photography and video. People can see and hear what is at risk, the wild places and creatures that will be lost if oil development occurs. Opponents of permanent protection try to paint the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge as a wasteland, barren and empty. Images give us the tools to prove them wrong: birds nesting by the thousands, caribou migrating along the wild shores of the Arctic Ocean, bears and wolves patrolling the tundra. These are the realities of the Refuge, and with this project, we can prove it to the public, to policy-makers, and to the White House. 

Why we need your help:

Getting to the Refuge is not easy. It requires flights on commercial airlines, expensive chartered bush flights to remote sites, and weeks of effort by our photographers to create the needed images and video, edit and compile them. More time is required by the Audubon Alaska staff to put them to use, create videos, websites, blog posts, and outreach materials. Funding for this project can make all of this a reality. 

Permanent protection for the Refuge is possible, and never has the opportunity been better. With your help, it can happen.

What you get:

In exchange for your donation we’d like to offer you our thanks, no matter the amount. But we've thrown in a few awesome perks from digital images for your computer desktop, to signed archival prints, all the way up to a private photography workshop with one of our project photographers. Check out the perks on the right.  

Who Is Audubon Alaska?

Since we opened our doors in 1977, Audubon Alaska's mission is to conserve the spectacular natural ecosystems of the Great Land, focusing on birds, other wildlife, and their habitats, for the benefit and enjoyment of current and future generations. We employ science and cutting-edge mapping technology to drive our conservation priorities, with an emphasis on public lands and waters.

campaign_city: Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, United States

story:
Who I Am and Why I Care

I'm a recent college graduate with a degree in Biology with an Ecology and Animal Behavior emphasis. But I'm more than just a title on paper; I consider myself a voice of the animals. Ever since I was a little girl, I had a passion for helping lost pets or injured wildlife and dreams of one day helping to save all species from extinction. Now I know that all is a bit extreme, and life sometimes doesn't put the opportunity at your fingertips. You have to be willing to reach out and find it, even if your career  or family or other pursuits take up the bulk of your time. 

Even though I'm not working as a zoologist or marine biologist (yet), I still want to use what talents and time I have to help make a difference. Because I believe that even the smallest effort or contribution can change the future and help save animal lives.

The Polar Bear

Polar bears naturally populate areas of arctic sea ice like Northern Canada, Russia, Greenland, and Norway. But as the climate warms, the sea ice disappears - melting earlier and forming later each year. This places the polar bear in jeopardy as the species cannot travel its natural paths, hunt, or teach the next generation crucial survival skills. Habitat loss has already shown a direct impact on polar bear health and numbers. Skinny and hungry bears face a harsher challenge each and every year, through no fault of their own and without a way to speak for themselves.
It's up to us to speak for them and to act on their behalf. From signing a petition that urges climate change to modifying your own habits to save energy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, you can make a difference. By donating to this project, you are showing your support for research and outreach to help save polar bears.

The Project

This past year, I've begun painting animal portraits. I am contributing my original artwork to help raise awareness and money for the polar bear, just one of the many animals in the world whose lives are in jeopardy and whose species might ultimately face extinction. Every dollar of the net amount raised will go directly to the "Adopt a Polar Bear" cause hosted by the World Wildlife Fund.

I have never sold or contributed a single painting to a cause before, so this will be an experimental project for me. I know that there are more talented artists out there, but just like actual polar bears, each piece of polar bear art is unique. This is the only venue through which you can donate funds and in return receive this one-of-a-kind piece. Each art print and painting will be hand signed and numbered by me as part of a limited edition set. You can choose to hang the piece on your office or bedroom wall. Each time you look at it, you can remember how you contributed to the cause and how you are a voice for the polar bear. OR you can gift it to a loved one who shares your passion for animals!

The Impact

With this project, I hope to raise money for a great cause while simultaneously spreading the word that polar bears are still a threatened species (since 2008). They may not be in the news or face immediate extinction, but that doesn't make the cause any less worthy of notice. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate money, you can still help remind your friends and family by sharing this project through Facebook, Twitter, and any other way you deem fit. 

Additionally, you can discover more about polar bears, the threats against them, and ways to help by visiting http://www.polarbearsinternational.org >> The site suggests turning the thermostat down a few degrees on Int. Polar Bear Day (Feb. 27th), bundle up like a polar bear, and save energy!

story:
Why We're Fundraising
We (Nico's family) are currently involved in a lengthy application process through a local organization called NEADS (National Education for Assistance Dog Services). We expect to have a completed and approved application for Nico's dog through NEADS this coming Spring, 2013. Once the application is approved, we will move all of the donations collated through this website over to NEADS in Nico's name. This means that your donation through this website is tax deductible as NEADS is a 501c3 nonprofit organization. Should you need a receipt for your donation from NEADS, we will be able to provide that after the completion of the application process. 
 
About NEADS
The NEADS mission is to provide independence to people who are deaf or have a disability through the use of canine assistance.
 
NEADS (National Education for Assistance Dog Services) – also known as Dogs for Deaf and Disabled Americans – is a non-profit organization that was established in 1976 to provide canine assistance for people who are deaf or have a disability. These assistance dogs become an extension of their handlers and bring freedom, physical autonomy and relief from social isolation to their human partners. NEADS has trained over 1,300 assistance dog teams since 1976.
 
For more information, visit their website here: http://www.neads.org/Aboutus
 
Once our application is approved, fundraising will continue for Nico's dog until we reach the goal of $9,500.00, which is our portion of the cost for the service dog.
 
How This Will Help
Before we began this application, we had multiple conversations with Nico about what it means to own and care for a service dog. We wanted to be certain that Nico was ready and willing to take on the responsibilities involved. We asked Nico a number of questions to this end, and his answers all indicated that he will be ready and eager to accept responsibility.
 
In his own words:
“The main reason I want a service dog is it will help me be more independent. The other main reason I want a service dog is to comfort me when I am sad. When people around me are talking and laughing, I sometimes get sad. The dog can help me with that. Like a friend.” 
 
Nico also shared how the dog might also help him with some basic needs that he’s not able to do independently:
“He/she will help me turn on the fan and the light switch. The dog can also help me when transferring from my wheelchair, and with carrying my sports equipment.” 
 
As his family, we're with Nico every day and we know that the ways in which a service dog will benefit and enrich his life are innumerable. At 11-years-old, we find Nico facing one of the greatest challenges of life — learning to be independent with a disability. He’s become more aware of his body and emotions, and understandably feels a heightened need for more control over his actions and day-to-day needs. Impaired by both physical and cognitive disabilities, we can’t think of any better tool than a service dog to help him achieve this goal. 
 
Some examples of how we know this service dog will help Nico include:
  • Finding help in an emergency situation by either fetching the phone so Nico can call for help or barking when commanded by Nico to attract attention.
  • Helping Nico move between spaces as well as transferring from his wheelchair without adult assistance.
  • Helping Nico access out-of-reach items as well as carrying items for him.
  • Above all, being an emotional support for Nico, who suffers with anxiety, a sensory disorder, and a non-verbal learning disability. 
Please contact us directly if you have any questions and thank you so much for your support!
 
Dan Bolton, Zoe Langosy, and Billiana Angelova (Nico's family)

story:
Short Summary

1.6 billion people around the world live without electricity or require an alternative because electricity is too expensive and power outages are daily events. We developed a low-cost, solar-powered, folding light made of a recyclable material. It has a lifespan of 3-5 years and provides light for 8-12 hours. Our patented origami balloon folding design allows it to be flat packed for easy transport. It can be charged by the sun while folded or when expanded.

Our folding lamp provides enough light to study with at night and can light up a room up to 100 square feet. Many solar portable lamps are produced with emergency situations in mind. As a result, the light quality is not conducive for daily use as an alternative to electricity. Our lamp provides a quality of light that works for both task and ambient light. 

Our light is one of the lightest weight portable lights made and, because it folds, it can be easily packed by the hundreds and shipped at a low cost for emergency relief situations. It is durable and reliable in extreme weather conditions.

Visit our website (http://www.faarm.org) to see other projects our nonprofit has ongoing around the world.

What We Need

We have had success with the introduction of our earlier prototypes and are now seeking your hlep to produce our final prototype and make it available to people  in need. We are seeking $30,00 to complete the following:

Circuit board tooling: $2,000

Envelope refinement and tooling: $5,000

Final prototype development: $2,500

3-country household test: $20,500

Total: 30,000

One key aspect of finalizing our solar light is the inclusion of phone charging capability. Today, nearly 500 million people worldwide have a mobile phone subscription but no easy or cheap access to a means of charging it.

We will use whatever monies we raise to continue with the following steps:

First, we will complete the final prototype. This includes phone charging capability; brighter light capacity; and a more durable envelope construction.

Second, we will complete our in-country testings. Our plan is to work with NGOs with whom our nonprofit already has established relationships to help  distribute the lights. We expect that we will conduct tests in locations in the Caribbean, Asia and Africa.

Finally, we will secure agreements with NGOs to incorporate our solar light as part of their their existing programs. We've already begun these conversation and have some commitments underway.

The Impact

While governments are working to increase access to electricity, the global population is growing faster than the rate of electrification. It is expensive and sometimes not technically feasible to provide electricity in some areas. Even when electricity does reach a village or town, customers may be asked to pay steep fees to establish service. Even when connected to the grid, power outages are a daily occurrence in the developing world. In Africa, more than one-third of the connected population experience power loss at least once a week, lasting anywhere between a couple of hours to days at a time.

Currently, the majority of people with little or no access to electricity rely on kerosene for light. Kerosene lamps are known to be toxic, carcinogenic and inefficient. Kerosene-based lamps can contribute to lung disease, respiratory problems and eye-related issues. Reports by the World Health Organization indicate that indoor air pollution from kerosene and similar fuels used for indoor lighting and cooking cause more than 1.5 million deaths annually.

In addition, $10 billion a year is spent on kerosene in sub-Saharan Africa, or $36 billion globally. In Tanzania, for example, households often spend 10% to 25% of their income on kerosene.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, please spread the word about our campaign to anyone you think might be interested in.

In Africa, more than one-third of the connected population experience power loss at least once a week, lasting anywhere between a couple of hours to days at a time.
Currently, the majority of people with little or no access to electricity rely on kerosene for light. Kerosene lamps are known to be toxic, carcinogenic and inefficient. Kerosene-based lamps can contribute to lung disease, respiratory problems and eye-related issues. Reports by the World Health Organization indicate that indoor air pollution from kerosene and similar fuels used for indoor lighting and cooking cause more than 1.5 million deaths annually.
In addition, $10 billion a year is spent on kerosene in sub-Saharan Africa, or $36 billion globally. In Tanzania, for example, households often spend 10% to 25% of their income on kerosene.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, please spread the word about our campaign to anyone you think might be interested in.

story:
I'm a gardener who's noticed the explosion of invasive plants in the Champlain Valley.  Around the Route 7 corridor, many woods consist of just two or three kinds of Eurasian shrubs, where they once hosted dozens of native species living in balance with each other.  With no natural enemies, the plants are only widening their range.  



I'd like to manage their growth by cutting down the prolific adults in sensitive and strategic areas, and by returning to pull new growth.  The target areas are in Hinesburg, VT and neighboring towns, in parks, income-sensitive properties, and roadside areas.  The work will benefit hikers, farmers, and wildlife like migratory birds for years to come.  



Where we start the project will depend on how much money we raise for work hours.  Even if we fall short of our goal, the money will go right into invasive plant removal, so any size donation helps us to get the ball rolling.  You can also use Indiegogo to help spread the word without contributing.



I've gotten very good at removing big, thorny trees on retired farmland in Shelburne and East Charlotte.  I love to uncover the surviving native understory and see what will be thriving the following year.  You'll love the before-and-after pictures for every project we undertake.

story:
Hello, my name is Sonia and I am originally from Mexico City, Mexico. I am one of the Co-Founders of MomoEffect, a Social Enterprise that focuses on youth empowerment around the world. Recently, I have been accepted as a team member on the International Antarctic Expedition (IAE) 2013 as part of the Antarctic Youth Ambassador Program which will be held from 28 February to 13 March 2013.

Being part of the team means that we will explore the Antarctic Peninsula with onboard experts and gain firsthand knowledge of the continent’s fragile ecosystem. We will also experience the unique Antarctic wildlife and observe its magnificent landscape, all while learning about climate change, sustainability and what we can do to protect this last great wilderness on Earth.


As you can imagine I am over the moon with excitement for having this truly once in a lifetime opportunity, most of all because since I was a little girl I have been fascinated with whales, and how disregarded of their size they are truly gentle magnificent creatures. Not only this, but as the last great wilderness on earth, and the furthest point there is a certain mysticism that I have always admired. To have the opportunity to go in this lifetime and raise awareness about the plight of animals such as the great whales that risk having their natural habitats depleted in the search for fuels, is truly an honour. Particularly as I get to do it whilst promoting the use of renewable energy, a zero waste lifestyle and the creation of job opportunities for youth along the way,

It is for this reason that I am reaching out for contributions to all those that believe in the protection of great animals like the whales. If animals are not your thing how about renewable energy? If that’s still doesn’t make the cut, how about show your support for the creation of youth employment? Whatever the reason you decide to sponsor me, I promise I will be eternally grateful!

In order to be able to participate I must fundraise $20 000 USD by December 1st, 2012. I need the funds to cover the cost of the expedition (15 000 USD), plus airfare and special clothing for the region. I realize that the amount to fundraise is quite a bit, nevertheless, if I am unable to fundraise enough funds, all of the money will go to our social enterprise where we seek to provide seed funding to young entrepreneurs who have innovative business ideas that are not only environmentally concious, but that are creating jobs, providing tranferrable skills, and which are ultimately leading their communities to achieving sustainable development. 

What I intend on doing as a result of my participation in the AYAP:

Through one of my contacts in Brazil I have managed to begin to develop a tangible project for after the Ambassador Programme including the Zero Waste motto. The idea we have come up with will help safeguard the environment for future generations through a Zero Waste lifestyle, which will not only help ensure humankind’s survival but also for endangered species such as whales.


We also want to educate people in countries that do not necessarily have a coast, or ‘political’ interest in Antarctica, given that a lot of the time just because people are not personally connected they do not know much about the situation and how it is that their lifestyle influences the outcomes in the polar regions. Perhaps, if they found out more in a personal manner and how it is through their actions that they affect international space, they might just listen and decide to lead more of a Zero Waste lifestyle.
Finally, for us living a zero waste life, or having proper waste management infrastructure is key. Waste that is properly processed pollutes less, not only that, but if people become more conscious of the trash they are producing it helps reduce it. Alternatively, they can make better purchases such as products made out of recyclables. Added to this, is the idea of turning waste into energy as a renewable energy source is something that we believe in.


Our target audience is mainly youth as that is the range of people we work for and have access to (ages 18-30). The project/campaign/idea will launch at this year’s Zero Waste International Youth Meeting to be hosted in Florianópolis by Zero Waste Youth, where youth from all over the world will be attending to find out how to spread the idea of Zero Waste and renewable energy in their respective countries. This will help us hit the ground running and start with a wide network in order to have the best impact. As a Zero Waste ambassador within the Antarctica programme I would document my experience through a photo essay/video and spread it through our social media channels to our already existing network. Eventually, the idea would be to lead to an action day in ever place where we have representation in order to raise awareness about Antarctica, renewable energy and a Zero Waste lifestyle, bringing it all full circle.

Another project for after the Programme (hopefully!): 

I have always been passionate about photography, and have become quite the travel photojournalist. I have always wanted to hold an exhibition for my photos, so I can share the stories of my life with others, and hopefully inspire them to follow their hearts and beat to their own drums in their own ways. And if through them I can inspire people to want to change the world, why not!? 

I am quite the whale lover, and my dream has always been to swim with them in their natural environment (although I am not sure this will be able to happen this time around) I thought I could document this experience and add it to my other travel experiences, creating a Memoir of sorts (being that before 30 I will now have officially been to all continents) but mostly focus on the pressing issues all over the world  such as the rapid change of the environment. This would then be put into a photography exhibition, and perhaps into a photo book. 

Contributions would most definitely help in making this idea into a reality. Whether big or small, any support will be of great encouragement as I move forward towards achieving this dream of mine, and ultimately, hopefully will also create a ripple effect that will contribute to the empowerment of youth around the world and the safe guarding of this great planet and all its living beings. 

If unable to contribute financially, can I ask yout o please share my cause with others to help spread the word, and help me reach my target!? 

Should you have any questions about my fundraising efforts, please do not hesitate to get in touch at sonia.preisser@gmail.com

 

Thank you for stopping by and taking the time to read my cause!

story:
I have just been given a wonderful opportunity to work at Ile Sainte Marie in Madagascar. Every year, humpback whales migrate to give birth in the canal between St. Mary’s Island and the Big Island of Madagascar. This year, a Festival of Whales will take place, along with the first Humpback Whale World Congress for scientists from around the world. Association CÉTAMADA has asked me to work as translator and organizer for the conference and the Festival and throughout the summer (Austral winter) I will also be giving conferences to tourists, translating and helping out on scientific and tourist expeditions at sea.

Cétamada's goal is to protect marine mammal population and their habitat in Madagascar. The Association is committed to community awareness and sustainable development, involving local populations in its actions.

I amlooking for funding for travel, lodging and meal expenses. I have set up this campaign to make the trip possible. Any amount and all types of encouragement are welcome. And please, feel free to circulate this message.

Thank you all in advance.

I can’t singlehandedly save the Whales, but with you help, we can help them.


Je viens de me faire offrit une occasion unique d’aller travailler à l’Ile Sainte-Marie à Madagascar. À chaque année, les baleines à bosse migrent vers le canal entre l’Ile Sainte-Marie et la Grande Ile de Madagascar. Cette année, l’Ile tiendra un Festival des Baleines et le premier Congrès Mondial des Baleines à Bosse, pour les scientifiques de monde entier . Association CÉTAMADA m’a demandé de travailler comme traducteur et organisateur pour la Conférence, le Festival et tout au long de l’été (hiver austral) Je donnerai aussi des conférences pour les touristes, traduirai et accompagnerai les expéditions scientifiques et touristiques lors d’explorations en mer.

L'objectif de Cétamada  est la préservation des populations de mammifères marins et de leur habitat à Madagascar. En impliquant les populations locales dans ses actions, l’association s’engage dans une démarche de sensibilisation et dedéveloppement durable.

Je cherche de l'aide pour financer les frais de transport, d’hébergement et repas. Cette campagne est mise sur pied afin de rendre possible ce voyage. Tout montant et toute forme d’encouragement seront grandement appréciés. Je vous prie de faire circuler cette information , si'il vous plait.

Je vous remercie tous d’avance.

Luc St-Laurent

Seul, je ne peux pas sauver les baleines, mais avec vote aide, nous pouvons les aider.

story:
Rhino Drone

The Rhino Drone project was born from a concept to get cost effective, unmanned aircraft into the air to assist with tracking down the Rhino Poachers.

Studying animals from the air is not a new concept and it works well, but it is very expensive!

South Africa is loosing more than 400 Rhino's per year and I want to make  a difference. Help me hunt a Rhino Poacher!

What We Need & What You Get

The aim of the Rhino Drone project is to investigate and build a high-fidelity prototype of advanced; low cost, high-impact and/or technologically advanced equipment and study the viability of using these to create remote controlled aircraft intended for nature conservation.

This is phase one and we need to gauge the support we can get for this project, so we will list all donators on our project web site, www.rhinodrone.co.za.

All funds raise will be used for this project, if this project is stopped, for whatever reason, all funds will be donated to the Makanyane Volunteers www.makanyane.org.za.

Once our initiall development is done in phase one and we move into phase two, we will start offering T-Shirts and memorabilia showing that you were a part of this initative. This is phase one, we don't have capacitiy to offer this just yet.

Rhino Drone Project Break Down

Phase One

The first phase actually involves something I have been doing for a few months now; it is taking the research I've done and putting it into action.

Phase one is raising funds to create a high fidelity prototype of the concept. 

This prototype will be flown in controlled environments and monitored to ensure the maximum effectiveness in the field... we will then take it to the bush and fly it to its extremes and then push it to its limits. 

Phase Two

The next phase is to take the base unit and add the fancy video technology to it. Here we will experiment with various techniques which will allow us to remotely fly (out of sight and at night) and provide alternative view points for trackers and parks board officials.

We will also investigate recording technologies for the out puts, ensuring that all video streams can not only be monitored onsite, but post flight too!

Phase Three

To take lessons learnt from Phase one & two and improve on the prototype.

We aim to improve the following in this phase:

1.       Distance for video feeds (streaming video)

2.       Flight Duration (time in the air)

3.       Stability of Aircraft (some really fancy equipment to be investigated)

The Impact

Over 430 Rhino have been poached this year, that is more than last year's number of Rhino have already been poached and the year is not finished yet!

I love spending time with the volunteer group Makanyane, which I've been a member since 2005, were we help maintain the Pilanesburg Reserve... a very special piece of Africa with a wide diversity of animals.

I want to make a difference, I want to build a cost effective tool to be used initially for assisting with protecting the Rhino, and in the future to be used for nature conservation.

story:
In March, I'll start walking north from Georgia to Maine on the Appalachian Trail with my pup Gaia. For those of you that know me, I've been talking about it for years, and now the time is right for the 2,180 mile trek.

I'm a wilderness therapy field instructor and Gaia is certified to work in the wilderness with me. We spend over half of our lives outside--hiking, bowdrilling, mentoring struggling teenagers.  I love my job because it offers opportunities to challenge and empower the students I work with.  

I am seeking an equally challenging and empowering journey for myself.  I want to raise money to help with expenses along the way and I want to give you something handmade in the Georgia woods in return for your kind contribution.

 

"If you really want something, you'll find a way.  If not, you'll find an excuse." 

And I really want to make it to Maine!

I'm working to raise $2,180 to put with what I have saved for the trail.  $2,180 will be one dollar for every mile of the AT.  Your contribution will help with gear, food, and other expenses along the way--like boarding Gaia for the Smokeys, one of the sections she isn't allowed to hike.  

As I mentioned, the perks are handmade WITH LOVE by me (knitted or carved) in the Georgia woods. These things are quality. You want them.

 

What if I want to contribute, but can't?

Don't worry about that. If you can't contribute, please share this campaign with friends and family, and spread the word!

story:
After the success of our previous campaign, Archipelagos have decided to launch a follow up campaign! Our previous campaign raised money to help conserve marine mammals and fish stocks of the Aegean island of Lipsi by providing the small-scale fishermen of Lipsi Island, with new, more sustainable nets. This time we want to raise more and help more fishermen.

The fishermen are constantly coming into an inevitable conflict with marine mammals, due to decreasing fish stocks and the fight for fish to survive. The nets we are providing are more selective: have a larger mesh size, preventing the capture of smaller fish, allowing them to reproduce, repopulating the area. 

With this 2nd campaign we we wish to raise even more money so that we can reach out to a greater number of fishermen from Lipsi, Patmos and Arki islands, and especially those fishing within the Permanent Wildlife Refuge of Arki Island Complex (Patmos region). All of the fishermen involved will agree to and sign a voluntary code of conduct promising to respect marine life. 


The last campaign raised €1280 from 27 funders. With this we were able to provide 1600m of nets to 12 fishermen of Lipsi.


Photo above: Giving out nets after the last campaign 

This time we want to beat this amount and raise at least €10,000 which we will give in the form of sustainable fishing gear to at as many fishermen as posible (with priority to those who have no income other than fishing). If everyone pulls together and donates even just a small amount, we can achieve this target, or even exceed it, allowing us to reach out to more fishermen on more islands. Please donate as little or as much as you can, as all help and support is extremely important to us, not only in monetary value but also as moral support.


RESULTS OF OUR LAST CAMPAIGN

Our last campaign helped out many of the small-scale fishermen of Lipsi, and they were all thoroughly touched by everyone’s generosity. They were especially amazed at how even people with very little spare money still made a contribution. This made them feel like they hadn’t been forgotten and that people care. In the past, many marine mammals were caught in the nets, damaging them, however none were injured or killed.  

If you would like to find out more about what we did last time, please click this link:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-conserve-dolphins-and-fish-stocks-on-the-small-aegean-island-of-lipsi


WHY ARE THESE NETS IMPORTANT?

Our fish stocks are currently declining at an alarming rate, which is putting pressure on both humans (in terms of food security and the economy) and marine wildlife. The result of this is many conflicts between fishermen and the marine mammals because of competition for the fish.

The conflicts particularly arise with the bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops truncatus), the common dolphin (Delphinus delphis) the critically endangered Mediterranean monk seal (Monachus monachus) and loggerhead turtles (Caretta caretta). As a consequence of the conflicts, these beautiful and precious animals are often being hurt or killed because they are trying to take fish from the nets.

The new nets we will provide the fishermen with have a larger mesh size, which prevents the catch of small immature fish, allowing them to grow and repopulate the surrounding area. This results in a rise in fish stocks, which not only provides more food for the dolphins and other wildlife, but also benefiting the catches of the fishermen.

We are currently placing huge pressures on our seas, and if we wish to continue to live off them then we need to conserve and protect all the species that live within them. One of the main problems our oceans are currently facing is the decimation of fish stocks, and with this project we are trying to tackle and prevent further decline.

Photo above: Giving out nets after the last campaign

A small amount of money was able to make a large positive change, therefore, whatever you are able to contribute, even €1, can make a huge difference and shows lots of support. 

OUR GOALS

Short term goals

·  Provide new large mesh nets to as many fishermen as possible from the area of Lipsi, Patmos, and Arki, and begin to increase fish stocks

·  Reduce conflict between marine mammals and fishermen

·  Work with the local fishing community to develop a fisheries management plan of sustainable practices of fishing, minimising damage to the environment



Long term goals

·  Extend the project and provide new large mesh nets to fishermen of other islands

·  Extend the fisheries management plan to other islands too

·  Protect and increase fish stocks of the Aegean to further reduce conflicts between fishermen and marine mammals

·  Long term monitoring of marine mammals to gather knowledge on their population sizes and patterns

WHO ARE WE?

 Archipelagos, Institute of Marine Conservation are an environmental non-profit organization, committed to protecting and defending the marine and island biodiversity of the North Eastern Mediterranean. Our main actions are to:

* Contribute to the scientific work about the biodiversity conservation

* Work in close collaboration with the local communities

* Report actions to the national and EU authorities

* Development of realistic – Sustainable Management Measures

Our Transparency Policy

Here at Archipelagos, we strive to ensure full transparency of use made of all donations received and that our donators are kept up to date and well informed on all news related to the causes their money is put towards.
story_txt:
After the success of our previous
campaign, Archipelagos have decided to launch a follow up campaign! Our previous
campaign raised money to help conserve marine mammals and fish stocks of the Aegean
island of Lipsi by providing the
small-scale fishermen of Lipsi Island, with new, more sustainable nets. This time we
want to raise more and help more
fishermen.The fishermen are constantly coming
into an inevitable conflict with marine mammals, due to decreasing fish stocks and the fight
for fish to survive. The nets we are providing are more selective: have a larger mesh size,
preventing the capture of smaller fish, allowing them to reproduce, repopulating the area. With this 2nd campaign
we we wish to raise even more money so that we can reach out to a greater number of fishermen from Lipsi, Patmos and Arki islands, and especially those fishing within the Permanent Wildlife Refuge of Arki Island Complex (Patmos region). All of the fishermen involved will agree to and sign a voluntary code of conduct promising to respect marine life. 
The last campaign raised €1280 from 27
funders. With this we were able to provide 1600m of nets to 12 fishermen of
Lipsi.Photo above: Giving out nets after the last campaign 
This time we want to beat this
amount and raise at least €10,000 which we will give in the form of sustainable fishing gear to at as many fishermen as posible (with priority to those who have no income other than fishing). If everyone pulls together and donates even just a small amount, we can achieve
this target, or even exceed it, allowing us to reach out to more fishermen on more islands. Please donate as little or as much as you can, as all help and
support is extremely important to us, not only in monetary value but also as
moral support.RESULTS OF OUR LAST CAMPAIGN
Our
last campaign helped out many of the small-scale fishermen of Lipsi, and they
were all thoroughly touched by everyone’s generosity. They were especially
amazed at how even people with very little spare money still made a contribution. This made them feel like they hadn’t been forgotten and
that people care. In the past, many marine mammals were caught in the nets, damaging them, however none were injured or killed.  If you would like to find out more about what we did last time, please click this link:https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-conserve-dolphins-and-fish-stocks-on-the-small-aegean-island-of-lipsiWHY ARE THESE NETS IMPORTANT?Our fish stocks are currently
declining at an alarming rate, which is putting pressure on both humans (in
terms of food security and the economy) and marine wildlife. The result of this
is many conflicts between fishermen and the marine mammals because of
competition for the fish.
The conflicts particularly arise
with the bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops truncatus), the common dolphin (Delphinus delphis) the critically endangered Mediterranean monk seal (Monachus
monachus) and loggerhead turtles (Caretta caretta). As a consequence of the conflicts, these beautiful and
precious animals are often being hurt or killed because they are trying to take
fish from the nets.
The new nets we will provide the
fishermen with have a larger mesh size, which prevents the catch of small
immature fish, allowing them to grow and repopulate the surrounding area. This
results in a rise in fish stocks, which not only provides more food for the
dolphins and other wildlife, but also benefiting the catches of the fishermen.

We are currently placing huge
pressures on our seas, and if we wish to continue to live off them then we need
to conserve and protect all the species that live within them. One of the main
problems our oceans are currently facing is the decimation of fish stocks, and
with this project we are trying to tackle and prevent further decline.Photo above: Giving out nets after the last campaignA small amount of money was able to make a large positive change, therefore, whatever you are able to contribute, even €1, can make a huge difference and shows lots of support. 
OUR GOALSShort
term goals
·  Provide new large mesh nets to as many fishermen as possible from the area of Lipsi, Patmos, and Arki, and begin to increase fish stocks
·  Reduce conflict between marine
mammals and fishermen
·  Work with the local fishing community to develop a fisheries management plan of sustainable practices of
fishing, minimising damage to the environment
Long
term goals
·  Extend
the project and provide new large mesh nets to fishermen of other islands
·  Extend
the fisheries management plan to other islands too
·  Protect
and increase fish stocks of the Aegean to further reduce conflicts between
fishermen and marine mammals
·  Long
term monitoring of marine mammals to gather knowledge on their population sizes
and patterns
WHO ARE WE?
 Archipelagos, Institute of Marine Conservation are an environmental non-profit organization, committed to
protecting and defending the marine and island biodiversity of the North
Eastern Mediterranean. Our main actions are to: 
* Contribute to the scientific work about the biodiversity conservation 
* Work in close collaboration with the local communities 
* Report actions to the national and EU authorities
* Development of realistic – Sustainable Management MeasuresOur Transparency PolicyHere at Archipelagos, we strive to ensure full transparency of use made of all donations received and that our donators are kept up to date and well informed on all news related to the causes their money is put towards.

story:
Director of Photography: Spenser Gabin

Activist: Hannah Aubry

Video Creation Wizard: Rohan Thadani 

 

 

Who are we, and what are we all about? 

Bring Your Bag Chicago is a campaign that is leading an important and necessary environmental movement in the beautiful city of Chicago. There are three key groups of people in our movement. One is a group of activists working hard on public outreach and education; several of whom you're being introduced to today on Indiegogo. Second is another group of activists working hard on the legislative/political front. Their mission is to pass a citywide ordinance, introduced by Alderman Joe Moreno (http://www.ward1.org) and signed by four co-sponsors, that will greatly reduce use of single-use plastic bags in Chicago and incentivize a cultural shift towards bringing reusable bags. The third, and most important part of the group, is all of YOU - people who engage, say NO to plastic bags and take action by using reusable bags themselves. All of you are a critical part of this wave of change happening in Chicago - and throughout the world - today. (A great resource for bag news throughout the world is http://www.bagmonster.com. Click on "Track the Movement" for a list of hundreds of cities that have already passed bag legislation.) 

 

                             

Abby Goldberg, a 13-year-old from the Chicago area, created a Change.org petition (now up to 174,810 signatures) that convinced Governor Quinn to veto a statewide bill last summer initiated by Big Plastic. The bill would have taken away the rights of cities and towns to pass bag legislation throughout the state Illinois. Abby also testified with us at City Hall, along with her traveling Bag Monster. 

 

The first hearing for Chicago's Plastic Bag Reduction Ordinance was a huge success at Chicago's City Hall on June 18th, 2013. (Watch our campaign video which was shown at City Hall here: https://vimeo.com/68606941. Note there is an updated statistic since the creation of this video: plastic bags cost Chicago consumers over $40 million a year as opposed to the original statistic of $27 million in the video.) 

The second hearing is anticipated as early as September of this year, at which there will be a vote on this issue in the Committee for Health and Environmental Protection. Help us build this wave of momentum and make positive change happen all the way from City Hall to the grocery store in your neighborhood to Lake Michigan and the five oceans beyond. 

 

Stiv Wilson, Communications and Policy Director for The 5 Gyres Institute (http://5gyres.org), blows away the opposition at our hearing. 

 

Students from the Academy for Global Citizenship in Chicago who cheered us on at the hearing June 18th along with their fearless leader, Dan Schnitzer, Director of Sustainability at the school. 

 

The four goals of this campaign are to: 

 

  • CREATE AWARENESS of the devastating effect plastic pollution is having on our world.

  • EDUCATE about the importance of shifting away from disposable bags - both single-use, disposable plastic AND paper bags - towards REUSABLE BAGS. The educational component of this campaign will be ongoing. We are here to make sure THIS doesn't happen in Chicago: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d545PS_AkOw.

  • SUPPORT LEGISLATION that incentivizes people to become more CONSCIOUS of the power of their choices and their affect on the environment.

  • INSPIRE and EMPOWER people to embrace this small lifestyle shift that collectively makes an enormous POSITIVE IMPACT on the one and only place we all have to live: Earth.

                                 

                    Bring Your Bag Chicago's Official Logo, Designed by Lisa Leone

 

 

So...where is all the money going to go?  

$8,000 will be used to support four specific campaign goals.

  • An installation at Figment, an arts festival coming to Chicago the weekend of August 10th and 11th in Garfield Park, Chicago                                             
  • Launching a paid social media campaign
  • Community outreach events
  • “Seed” money to fund an initial small line of products we will sell online and/or at local stores in Chicago

 

Please read below for complete details about all four.  

 1. FIGMENT. Our first big event to engage and educate the public will be setting up an art installation at arts festival Figment. We will have a pop-up (a tent-like structure propped up by four posts) surrounded by a plastic bag canopy containing 2,568 bags - the amount of plastic bags used EVERY MINUTE of EVERY DAY in Chicago. That's insane, isn't it? 

Strings of plastic bags will be threaded and tied together and secured to the ground by tent stakes. To show support, you can sign one of these 2,568 bags, and at our next hearing one of our activists (Rohan Thadani) will testify with this giant pile of plastic before City Council, creating a powerful visual testimony. We will also be giving away 800 reusable, 100% cotton, WASHABLE tote bags at the installation totally FREE. People will be able to screen print their own bags with our campaign logo, sign our Change.org petition, and sign a postcard we will hand-deliver to Rahm Emanuel. Lots of cool stuff going on. The funding we need for Figment is as follows: 

  • 800 cotton tote bags: $800
  • Pop-up: $100
  • Two tables and four chairs: $100
  • Screen printing supplies: $150
  • Twine and tent stakes: $50
  • 1,000 postcards: $50
  • Candy and fruit to seduce people into our installation: $50

 TOTAL FUNDING NEEDED FOR FIGMENT: $1300

 

The 11 founding principles behind Figment, an arts festival coming to Chicago on August 10th and 11th, in Garfield Park. 

 

2. PAID SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN. To promote our first hearing which happened June 18th, our campaign experimented with a few Facebook advertisements and promoted posts to reach a wider audience. The cost of these promotions was small ($15-$25), and the amount of traffic and engagement generated on our site was huge. Marketing is a vital component to any successful campaign; it played a key role in the lead up to our successful hearing. We will use this advertising budget to promote Figment, promote our community events, promote our Change.org petition, promote our hearing, generate calls to aldermen preceding the hearing as well as advertise our cool campaign swag that people can purchase. We have budgeted $2000 for advertising and marketing so that we can get the word out about all the stuff we’re doing and get people engaged! 

 TOTAL FUNDING NEEDED FOR PAID SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN: $1500

      

Facebook and Twitter are more than ways to waste your life away trolling newsfeeds. They can also be used to make the world a better place: being extremely effective at reaching people and cost efficient, social media is especially useful for social and environmental activism campaigns. 

 

3. COMMUNITY OUTREACH EVENTS. Rahm needs to hear from the people of Chicago, and letter writing is a great way to let him know what we want. We will host at least FOUR letter-writing parties where people can create their own letters or sign our postcards. We will personally deliver these letters and post cards to Rahm’s office at City Hall. Two of these parties will be at bars (21+) we are partnering with in Chicago, and two of these parties will be at family-friendly establishments (exact locations are to be determined). We have budgeted $200 for each of these letter-writing parties, where everyone will get a reusable, screen printed cotton tote AND a drink, ice cream cone or other small token of our appreciation on us. We have also budgeted $200 for 4,000 postcards (a total of $1000 budgeted for letter-writing events).

We will also be giving away FREE REUSABLE BAGS in various locations throughout Chicago, particularly in neighborhoods where constituents may feel that they cannot afford to purchase a reusable bag. We will host as least FOUR reusable bag giveaways, where we will set up a table with information about our campaign. Everyone who signs our Change.org petition will receive a free reusable cotton tote printed with our campaign logo. We have budgeted $1600 for reusable cotton totes to give away at these events (this will buy us 1600 cotton tote bags). 

TOTAL FUNDING NEEDED FOR COMMUNITY OUTREACH EVENTS: $2600 

Community outreach is a critical part of any campaign. People need to know about the issue and be inspired to do something about it. Above is a shot from the YouTube video, 'Plastic State of Mind.' http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=koETnR0NgLY

 

4. “SEED” MONEY FOR CAMPAIGN SWAG WE CAN SELL FOR A SMALL PROFIT. We expect a second successful hearing in Chicago, but after the legislation is passed the work of raising awareness, educating the public and helping to facilitate a smooth transition from disposables to reusables only ramps up. Legislation has to be accompanied by public education to work.

So we thought it would be a great idea if we could come up with a few products to sell that would advertise for us AND generate a small profit that could be rolled into more funding. This will assure that we will be able to provide more free bag giveaways and advertising going forward. 

We are joining forces with ChicoBag, a reusable bag company, to provide our campaign with an initial 250 rip-stop nylon bags printed with our campaign logo. These bags fold up into a tiny sack that can be clipped right onto your keychain or bag and slipped into any purse or briefcase. We can get these bags for approximately five dollars each. We will be selling these online as well as taking them to a few local retailers to see if they would be interested in carrying our product (all the proceeds would go to our campaign). The other things that we will be selling are t-shirts, v-neck t-shirts, and tank tops with our campaign logo. The cost of 250 ChicoBags is approximately $1250, and we are budgeting $750 for our small line of clothing which includes the cost of prizes for donating to our campaign. 

This $2000 that we are investing in campaign swag serves an important purpose. If we can self-sustain, we can provide THOUSANDS of free bags to people who need them, continue to grow our influence, and ensure Chicago becomes a leader in this worldwide movement! 

TOTAL “SEED” MONEY FUNDING NEEDED: $2000

 

Bring Your Bag Chicago is partnering with ChicoBag and other companies to produce a small line of products. 

 

The grand total of our budget is $7400. If we do raise the full amount - $8,000 - that we are hoping to, our net fundraising total after site fees will be $7440. That will give us an extra $40 to buy unexpected things we may not have budgeted for...like, extra cherries, gummi sharks, and bug spray for our fabulous volunteers. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, and we understand that. But that doesn’t mean they can’t still help us out! Here are five great ways to still help us out: 

  • "Like" us on Facebook, share our page with your friends, and sign our petition at www.change.org/petitions/bring-your-bag-chicago.
  • Share our Indiegogo with anyone who you think might support us.
  • VOLUNTEER with us! We are constantly looking for people to help us out, even if it's just for a couple hours. Send us a private message through our Facebook page to find out about different opportunities. 
  • Come to our next hearing, which may be as soon as September, at Chicago City Hall. Even sign up to testify if you'd like! 
  • Finally, BRING YOUR OWN BAG! Whenever you leave your house, you are an advertisement for your lifestyle. When you go shopping, everyone around you will see you use your reusable bag and you never know who it might inspire. 

 

“Each time a man stands up for an ideal, or acts to improve the lot of others, or strikes out against injustice, he sends forth a tiny ripple of hope, and those ripples build a current which can sweep down the mightiest walls of oppression and resistance.”


― Robert F. Kennedy

 

Bring Your Bag Chicago would like to extend a huge thank you and amazing karma to everyone who has helped to create this campaign for over a year and a half, and all of the supporters who helped it really get off the ground this spring. This is just the beginning of more exciting things for Chicago!
