"THANK YOU"
TO YOU, FOR BEING PART OF THE EFFORT TO RESTORE THE FIRE-DAMAGED LANDSCAPES OF CHIOS AND TO TURN THE HILLSIDES GREEN AGAIN.

story:
What is Indiegogo?  And why should you care?

Crowdfunding? Indiegogo? If this sounds like a new language you don’t speak, don’t run away just yet! Think of our campaign like a mix of grassroots activism, fundraising and a business start-up – all enabled by the power of social media and the Internet. We have a great cause that needs a little help from our friends. We start with a heartfelt request to watch our video, donate if you are able and then please share our campaign with your friends, colleagues, family, etc. Eventually we’ll gather these first few snowflakes into a snowball that will grow and grow, gathering momentum as we build towards our goal.

Short Summary

We’re taking on the Big Banks! We want to fund worthwhile energy projects. That means solar, wind, geothermal – or even upgrades to existing equipment like windows or air conditioners. The list is extensive. These projects have huge benefits to local workers, economies and the environment. Wall Street and the Big Banks often don’t understand these projects and Big Oil & Gas often don’t want them funded. We believe that a group of thoughtful, committed people can change the world. And we’re asking for your crucial support in the early stages of the process. 

 

Founded in 2012 by a team of lifelong environmental entrepreneurs from California and Colorado, Planetary Finance has extensive experience in energy efficiency and renewable projects from decades of fieldwork. We’ve gotten our hands dirty and we know these projects from the ground up. By funding these projects directly, rather than through a financial system with its fingers in the pie, we can offer a more cost-effective process. In short, the benefits of these projects get realized by the people who install them and the communities they serve. No Big Banks or Wall Street in the picture.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $40,000 in start-up capital and legal help to be able to compete with Big Banks on their own turf. We have a Perk Program that lets you donate as little as $1(Yes! – a mere $1) – and we’ve done our best to give something back at every level. All donations of $100 or more will receive dividends from the projects we invest in. By donating to our campaign – at any level – you’ll be boosting local economies and helping to improve the environment.

The Impact

The benefits of these energy projects are impressive. If renewable energy and energy efficiency projects were embraced on a national scale, the results would be:

  • 2 Million US jobs created
  • $400 Billion – about $2600 per US household – in annual energy costs saved
  • 2.8 Billion tons of carbon saved from the atmosphere

These projects support local economies, local environments, as well as the people who live and work where these projects are found. The good they do is real and enduring. By joining us, you are playing a part in spreading the good!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t manage to scrape together $1 for our campaign, you can still help us out! We need you to spread the word…. forward our campaign, website, and video to your friends, family, neighbors or anyone who could use a boost or maybe a laugh (at our acting)!
story_txt:
What is Indiegogo?  And why should you care?
Crowdfunding? Indiegogo? If this sounds like a new language you don’t speak, don’t run away just yet! Think of our campaign like a mix of grassroots activism, fundraising and a business start-up – all enabled by the power of social media and the Internet. We have a great cause that needs a little help from our friends. We start with a heartfelt request to watch our video, donate if you are able and then please share our campaign with your friends, colleagues, family, etc. Eventually we’ll gather these first few snowflakes into a snowball that will grow and grow, gathering momentum as we build towards our goal.
Short Summary
We’re taking on the Big Banks! We want to fund worthwhile energy projects. That means solar, wind, geothermal – or even upgrades to existing equipment like windows or air conditioners. The list is extensive. These projects have huge benefits to local workers, economies and the environment. Wall Street and the Big Banks often don’t understand these projects and Big Oil & Gas often don’t want them funded. We believe that a group of thoughtful, committed people can change the world. And we’re asking for your crucial support in the early stages of the process. 
 
Founded in 2012 by a team of lifelong environmental entrepreneurs from California and Colorado, Planetary Finance has extensive experience in energy efficiency and renewable projects from decades of fieldwork. We’ve gotten our hands dirty and we know these projects from the ground up. By funding these projects directly, rather than through a financial system with its fingers in the pie, we can offer a more cost-effective process. In short, the benefits of these projects get realized by the people who install them and the communities they serve. No Big Banks or Wall Street in the picture.
 
What We Need & What You Get
We need $40,000 in start-up capital and legal help to be able to compete with Big Banks on their own turf. We have a Perk Program that lets you donate as little as $1(Yes! – a mere $1) – and we’ve done our best to give something back at every level. All donations of $100 or more will receive dividends from the projects we invest in. By donating to our campaign – at any level – you’ll be boosting local economies and helping to improve the environment.
The Impact
The benefits of these energy projects are impressive. If renewable energy and energy efficiency projects were embraced on a national scale, the results would be:

2 Million US jobs created
$400 Billion – about $2600 per US household – in annual energy costs saved
2.8 Billion tons of carbon saved from the atmosphere

These projects support local economies, local environments, as well as the people who live and work where these projects are found. The good they do is real and enduring. By joining us, you are playing a part in spreading the good!
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can’t manage to scrape together $1 for our campaign, you can still help us out! We need you to spread the word…. forward our campaign, website, and video to your friends, family, neighbors or anyone who could use a boost or maybe a laugh (at our acting)!

story:
Special Announcement from the Powering Conservation on Cousin Island Indiegogo appeal!

Global Vision International (GVI) has teamed up with Nature Seychelles and Climatecaring to offer an amazing prize as our fund raising campaign reaches its climax.

We have raised 52% of our target as of 14/05/2014 with a huge boast from Utilita, a UK energy company that has donated £10K. The cash will take some time to organise through the corporate channels so will not show on the Indiegogo total. We hope to get closer to our target by offering this unique incentive.

There are on average 12 hours of sunshine a day in the Seychelles Islands. We want you to donate £1 for every hour. For your £12 donation we will send you a postcard from paradise and our eternal gratitude, Plus you will be entered into a prize draw to win a FREE four week conservation expedition on Curieuse Island, a sister Island of Cousin, worth £1,495. The expedition is operated by GVI, the world's foremost volunteering organisation and keen supporter of our work in the Seychelles. 

Climatecaring will assist the lucky winner to set up a crowd funding page to raise the funds for an air ticket and donate the first £100 or equivalent currency to the site. Click here for full details.

Our Campaign.

This fund raising Campaign is being initiated by Nature Seychelles in partnership with Climatecaring.org and backed by Birdlife International. Small Island devolping states (SIDS) are at the the forfront of climate change. Rising sea levels and disturbance of natural weather patterns are already causing catastrophic changes to their very existence. Small economies reliant on tourism and fisheries are finding it increasingly hard to survive in a world where fish stocks are diminishing through over exploitation and a fickle tourist industry has been hit by one of the worst financial crises on record.

We need to replace the diesel powered generator on Cousin Island with a Photovoltaic Solar Power system. This will bring multiple benefits: Save approximately £600 a month, this money will used to fund continuing research, extra staffing, island maintenance, boat repairs, energy security and much more. It will also save around 8,000kg’s of CO² emissions annually. This will finally bring the Island back to as near a pristine natural habitat as possible fulfilling the dream of Dr Nirmal Shah (CEO, Nature Seychelles) and Dr Marco Lambertini (CEO, Birdlife international).

Quote from Dr Rolph Payet (Seychelles Minister for Enviroment and Energy).

As individuals we can do something about climate change and this is your chance to make a difference, all be it small. If we can succeed in this project and do many more, thereby influencing and teaching as we go it can be a BIG difference and help in the fight to keep climate change in check.

BirdLife international is a global partnership of conservation organisations that strives to conserve birds, their habitats and global biodiversity, working with people towards sustainability in the use of natural resources. It is the World's largest partnership of conservation organisations, with over 120 partner organisations. Together the Birdlife partnership forms the leading authority on the status of birds, their habitats and the issues and problems affecting bird life.


Cousin Island, Seychelles.

Cousin Island is a granitic island covering 27 hectares and lies approximately 2km from Praslin Island. It became the world’s first internationally owned-reserve when it was purchased in 1968 by the International Council for the Protection of Birds (ICBP), now Birdlife International. The objective was to save the last remaining population of the Seychelles warblers and return the Island to its original natural state. Warbler numbers had dropped to 28 individuals at that time and their extinction looked imminent. The rescue mission has proved so successful that these endearing little song birds have now been reintroduced to other Islands. Their population now stands at 2500 and is growing annually.

As part of the Islands rehabilitation process it was made rat and cat free making one of the few rat free Islands in the Seychelles and a safe haven for breading birds.

Seychelles Warbler.

First made into a Nature Reserve in 1968 it was afforded further protection when it was designated a Special Reserve in 1974. It is not only significant for sea birds and endemic land birds but is also the most important breeding site for Hawksbill turtles in the Western Indian Ocean. The reserve is managed by “Nature Seychelles” a local, well known and respected NGO. The Island is run solely by local staff and benefits local communities on the neighbouring Praslin Island through eco-tourism.

Hawksbill Turtle.

Magpie Robin recovery program: Another remarkable success story in the fight against species extinctions through manmade habitat change and disturbance’s.

Seychelles Magpie Robin.

This charismatic bird, originally found in great numbers on several islands, was in 1990 down to a population of only 23 birds on Frégate Island, making it one of the most critically endangered species in the world. In 1990, a special recovery programme was established by Nature Seychelles, leading to the eventual translocation of several birds to Cousin, Cousine, and Aride islands. In 1999 the total population had increased to 90 birds, 25 of them on Cousin, and today, there are about 250 scattered over various islands. The species has been removed from the critically endangered list but still remains endangered. 

Other inhabitants.

The island hosts over 300,000 nesting seabirds of seven species. A large colony, dominated by Lesser Noddie but including about 1300 pairs of Brown Noddies, is present from May to September during the south-east monsoon. During the north-west monsoon, the hill supports a breeding colony of Wedge tailed shearwaters. 

Year-round breeders include White Fairy and Brindled terns, White tailed tropic birds and some 1000–1,500 pairs of Audubon’s Shearwaters. Several hundred Great and Lesser Frigate birds use the island for roosting and can be seen soaring over it. Some waders are present throughout the year, the commonest being the Ruddy Turnstone. Common Moorhens and Striated Herons also breed on the island.


Climatecaring.org: Reason to be.

Tim Kirkpatrick studied off grid PV design and installation extensively when studying for an MSc in renewable energy. As an ardent conservationist who had been GVI Seychelles country director for eight years he had a plan to start a movement that would assist conservation whilst mitigating against climate change and save large amounts of money at the same time.

To this end Climatecaring.org was born. It's Mission statement:  Save 10,000 tons of CO2 emissions annually through the intelligent deployment of renewable energy systems. To do this using sound economic practices and education strategies that save significant amounts of money compared to a business as usual approach. In doing so kick start 100 like minded institutions annually to do the same, thereby saving 1 million tons of climate changing emissions. It is my sincere hope that, perhaps through this initiative, we as custodians of this beautiful planet may ensure its continued good health and harmony that is intrinsically linked to ours. The effects of man made climate change are destabalizing the earths abilty to regulate its complex life support systems that have been in perfect balance for thousands of years.

Below is a short extract from the 2011 report from The United Nations  International Panel on Climate Change.



Tim will design and install the system on Cousin Island after this fund raising campaign has run its course.

How do we know PV sytems work well in Seychelles and what are the costs?

Tim designed and installed a PV stand alone system on the neighbouring Island of Curieuse. It came online on December 20th 2013. It has worked flawlessly since then, totally replacing the generator. The investment needed was £7217, this was paid back through the saving of generator fuel and maintenance costs on the 1st of March 2014.

The money being saved every month can be used to increase are conservation activities on the island from now on.

The Island is now saving £516 a month. CO² and other green house gas emissions avoided are 7955 Kg’s annually. Island peace and harmony; priceless.

In fact with the modern, reliable and cost effective renewable energy technology available today it does not make any financial or environmental sense to use generators for electrical energy production in the tropics.

Cousin PV standalone system.

The PV system for Cousin Island is already at the design stage waiting for funding. We have calculated a rough power load profile which dictates the size of the system needed to cover the entire daily output of the existing 5.5 Kva generator. Based on these calculations we have estimated the Island will need a 6 Kw system with a battery bank size of approximately 20 Kilowatt hours (Kwh). The Curieuse PV system is 2 Kw therefore the Cousin system will need to be 3 times larger. Giving us an estimated total cost of £25,000, Taking into account the extra transport cost and inflation.

Our Rewards.

We want to thank you with something special for donating towards our goal, so we have come up with unique opportunities over five different levels of giving. There are a couple of different ways to own specialy commissioned art works. The first is a series of photographs by a talanted wildlife photographer, Maxime Aliaga. If you donate at the third level, you can chose one picture featured in the video below by telling us the ID number of the photo. At our fourth donation level you will receive two pictures, with the option to receive up to 14 photos by donating an additional £20 for each one.


We have also commisioned an art work of Cousin Island life by a renowned local artist Michael Arnphie. A limited run of prints will be availible for slightly larger donations. Micheal has now finished the art works and they have been added to our perks. Below are the stunning peices of work he has completed for us.

Cousin Island Study.

Detail examples.

Cousin Island, lesser Noddy Study.

The Cousin Island Study will be a massive 8” x 20” fine art giclee on canvas print sent to you in a protective tube. This 18Mb print appears almost three dimensional with incredibly intricate detailing. It can be yours for a donation or £50. This will be a strictly limited edition; each print will be numbered and signed by the artist. Only 250 prints will ever be produced.

The Cousin Island, lesser Noddy Study will be an A4 fine art giclee on canvas print with equally incredible attention to detail. It can be yours for a donation of £40. Again this will be a strictly limited edition with each print signed by the Artist and numbered. Only 250 will ever be printed.

This is a once in a lifetime chance to own these artworks, and do a wonderful thing for a little island in the Indian Ocean, please don’t let it slip by.

Spread the word!

Even if you can't contribute to the fundraiser we still need your help to spread the word about our fundraiser. You can do this by using the share tools that can be found on the campaign at the bottom.

Fundraiser Information

Risks & Challenges.

There is virtually zero risk involved in this campaign. Nature Seychelles is a long running well respected organisation with an international reputation. Tim Kirkpatrick is a long term resident of the Seychelles and well know local figure in the renewable energy field. He has designed and installed two Photovoltaic standalone systems on outer Islands which have proved their viability. The supply chain for equipment has already been established as well as technical backup.


Timescale.

From the end of the campaign it will take at least four months to complete the installation and commissioning of the Cousin Island PV system. The Seychelles is a rather remote region of the world and importing the components of the PV system by ship will take between two and three months from the time of ordering. Transportation to Cousin Island will be weather dependent which could hold up the installation further. Installation will take a few days. It is hoped that we will be up and running by September 2014. Perks that are posted will be sent out before this but obviously the access to system monitoring will only be available after the system is commissioned.


Frequently Asked Questions

Q, Why are there two Curieuse prize draw donation boxes?

A, They are both the same perk and just give it more exposure.

Q, Are you having trouble donating through the site?

A, If yes please leave a private comment and we will contact you to assist.

story:
Hi! Welcome to the Indiegogo page for a project that's near and dear to me. Here's why.

Three years ago I volunteered at the Itapoa Reserve, which is one of many organizations working toward protecting the Ecuadorian Choco. (The Choco runs all the way up into Colombia. There's a map in the video.) Raul, the owner of the Itapoa Reserve, is a biologist who has devoted his life to saving the Choco. I don't say this lightly: he moved to the Choco rainforest 20 years ago, and never left. Every single day, he works toward reforesting the vanishing jungle. And there are others like him, and other organizations like his. Their dedication is stunning.

The problem is, despite the efforts of men and women in Ecuador and abroad, approximately just .3% of the Ecuadorian Choco is under protection status. And if we consider the fact that the Choco we see today is just 5% of what it once was, that .3% becomes even more troubling.

Why is the rate of deforestation so high?

Lots of reasons. Among them: slash-and-burn agriculture, mining, logging, and monoculture crops. Of these crops, African palm oil plantations are the top contributor to the rainforest's disappearance. 

If deforestation continues at its current rate, the Choco could disappear entirely. So what can we do to stop it?

Man. It seems like a huge task, doesn't it: saving the rainforest? It seems impossible. It seems like you'd have to be a biologist, or or a wide-eyed undergraduate environmentalist to even attempt it. 

Well, first, I happen to be neither of those things. I'm a writer with a filmmaking hobby, who teaches playwriting, and walks dogs, and makes smoothies part-time for a living. I am very much not a biologist, and I've yet to chain myself to a tree - and still, I fully believe we can help save the rainforest. I spent three months volunteering toward the cause a few years ago, and this winter I'll return to help in a slightly different capacity. (More on that in a moment!)

Second, it is a huge task. But huge tasks are undertaken in small steps.

Here's the plan.

Three years ago, I not only had the pleasure of volunteering for Raul, but I also gained a pretty spectacular friend. I've kept in touch with other volunteers as well, even after we've all gone home, and I've watched some remarkable projects come to fruition. My friend Daniel funded a project to build a water pipe to allow a community access to clean water once again. Another volunteer made a book of photographs, the proceeds of which fund Itapoa's efforts. Raul has raised money to buy another tract of land in the Choco, in order to protect it from being deforested.

I've watched all this happen while living in New York, working on a graduate degree in Creative Writing and Literature. Now, with the end of classes in sight, I'm making my way back to the Itapoa Reserve.

The plan is two-fold.

Fold number one.

With your help, I'll be donating to Itapoa a brand-new laptop with editing software and a video camera. Why? Because Raul, his volunteers, and his neighbors are taking small steps to save the Choco. But if they could reach more people - potential volunteers, biologists, researchers, universities, even the Ministry of Environment! - and these people take even more small steps to save the Choco, the next thing you know, you've turned 10 small steps into 1,000. You've turned .3% of the protected forest into 30%.

Right now, Raul's publicity of his cause depends on photos that volunteers take with their digital and cell phone cameras. And he's managing. His facebook page is filled photos of endangered animals, and volunteers trekking through the forest, encountering thigh-high mud pits and monkeys. People want to help, and Raul's often got a few volunteers at a time devoting, as I did, a couple of weeks or months to the cause.

But let's imagine what he could do with video equipment. 

In fact, I asked Raul to imagine what he might do with it, and he gave me one idea after the next. Here's an overview of a few of those ideas, so you get the gist of what a game-changer video could be for his cause.

  • An educational video highlighting the Itapoa reserve. Featuring Raul, neighboring communities, international volunteers, and the Choco - where it thrives, and where it has been destroyed.
  • A video of the Choco's endangered birds. Aimed at birders, biologists, audobon societies, conservation organizations. 
  • Video for crowdfunding sites (like this one!). Raul is currently working on a children's book to educated local and indigenous children. Raising literacy rates will prevent locals, many of whom are illiterate and therefore unaware of their rights, from being targeted by African palm companies that notoriously take advantage of these circumstances, and buy up locals' land for mere hundreds of dollars.

Each video, with its unique targeted audience, and in its own way, will educate, raise awareness, and call to action thousands of people who, today, remain unaware of the endangered Choco rainforest. 

Fold number two.

Raul and I will make the first video on that list together. I'll get him acquainted with the camera, and give him instruction in basic editing. All interested volunteers and locals will participate as well, receiving training and lots of hands-on experience.

We'll spend about two months collecting footage and editing together a short film. By the time I leave, he'll be comfortable enough with the equipment that he can shoot his own video, like the ones described above, and, if he can help it, dozens more.

And the video I'm shooting video is going to be really, really cool.

My friend Will, an engineer, is donating a flying camera for the duration of my trip. That's right, a flying camera. It's a hero cam strapped onto a robot. And he'll be there to operate it.

We can get a bird's eye view of the deforested rainforest. We can get a bird's eye view of other birds' eyes. 

And we'll be using the regular, non-flying camera too. We'll collect footage of the reserve, and interview locals and volunteers, and put together a neat, concise picture of Raul and the Itapoa Reserve. This video will be designed to attract volunteers. It will be featured on Raul's web site, which right now is quite basic. With this video, he can take fuller advantage of the traffic the Itapoa Reserve attracts from facebook, word of mouth, and even Lonely Planet. 

What I'm asking from you.

All the funding I receive on Indiegogo will go toward camera and audio equipment and a lap top with Final Cut Pro - all of which will donated to the Itapoa Reserve - and my plane ticket. 

Luckily I won't need any money once I'm down there (living in the rainforest is free!).

What you get in return.

Our money is hard-earned. And some of us don't have much left after bills are paid. I've been a grad student for the past few years; boy do I understand. 

Say you skip a latte. Say you buy a book used instead of new. Say you skip a whole week of lattes. Say you don't want to skip any of these things, but you're still able and willing to donate. Or, who knows, you found a balled-up bill at the bottom of the dryer today. Trust me: donating to save the rainforest tastes better than coffee, and smells better than a crispy, new book. Every dollar counts. 

What's more, in exchange for your donation, you get awesome stuff from the heart of the Choco rainforest. Check out the perks! There's sustainable chocolate, harvested by locals and made by Itapoa volunteers. There's local artwork. There are framed photos, hand-carved rings, dried and pressed flora - all from the Choco. 

What happens if I don't reach my goal?

If I don't reach my goal, I'll still get the amount I raised, but I'll have pay a higher fee to Indiegogo. I won't be able to donate the new laptop, editing software, camera and audio equipment to Raul and the Itapoa Reserve. 

Not reaching my goal would certainly be a hiccup. But I'd hold my breathe, drink some water, and help Raul in whatever capacity I can. I'll still make the video. I'll scrounge up any and all equipment I can to bring with me. I will spend two months in the Choco doing anything and everything I can to protect it.

Are you having trouble donating through paypal?

Send me an email: danielle.e.berg@gmail.com. We'll work it out.

Other ways you can help.

Just because you can't donate money doesn't mean you can't help.

Spread the word! Do you have a friend who loves to travel? Who loves nature? Who loves South America? Or a friend/family member who enjoys giving to a good cause? Send them on over. 

Donate old clothes. There's lots of bugs in the Choco. I've got to keep covered from neck to ankle, in heat-friendly colors/material. Got stuff with holes and stains? I'll take it.

Got any photo/video equipment? Editing software? A connection that'll offer a discount? Email me. 

For more information, check out:

Itapoa's web site: http://www.itapoareserve.com/

and facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Itapoa-Tropical-R...

These articles on the future of the Choco: 

http://www.environment.ucla.edu/ctr/research/ecuador/choco_rainforest.html

http://news.mongabay.com/2008/1009-interview_ka...

A vivid account of Raul's guided jungle trek into the Choco:

http://www.lonelyplanet.com/thorntree/thread.js...

My blog:

http://olddanyeller.tumblr.com
story_txt:
Hi! Welcome to the Indiegogo page for a project that's near and dear to me. Here's why.
Three years ago I volunteered at the Itapoa Reserve, which is one of many organizations working toward protecting the Ecuadorian Choco. (The Choco runs all the way up into Colombia. There's a map in the video.) Raul, the owner of the Itapoa Reserve, is a biologist who has devoted his life to saving the Choco. I don't say this lightly: he moved to the Choco rainforest 20 years ago, and never left. Every single day, he works toward reforesting the vanishing jungle. And there are others like him, and other organizations like his. Their dedication is stunning.
The problem is, despite the efforts of men and women in Ecuador and abroad, approximately just .3% of the Ecuadorian Choco is under protection status. And if we consider the fact that the Choco we see today is just 5% of what it once was, that .3% becomes even more troubling.
Why is the rate of deforestation so high?
Lots of reasons. Among them: slash-and-burn agriculture, mining, logging, and monoculture crops. Of these crops, African palm oil plantations are the top contributor to the rainforest's disappearance. 
If deforestation continues at its current rate, the Choco could disappear entirely. So what can we do to stop it?
Man. It seems like a huge task, doesn't it: saving the rainforest? It seems impossible. It seems like you'd have to be a biologist, or or a wide-eyed undergraduate environmentalist to even attempt it. 
Well, first, I happen to be neither of those things. I'm a writer with a filmmaking hobby, who teaches playwriting, and walks dogs, and makes smoothies part-time for a living. I am very much not a biologist, and I've yet to chain myself to a tree - and still, I fully believe we can help save the rainforest. I spent three months volunteering toward the cause a few years ago, and this winter I'll return to help in a slightly different capacity. (More on that in a moment!)
Second, it is a huge task. But huge tasks are undertaken in small steps.
Here's the plan.
Three years ago, I not only had the pleasure of volunteering for Raul, but I also gained a pretty spectacular friend. I've kept in touch with other volunteers as well, even after we've all gone home, and I've watched some remarkable projects come to fruition. My friend Daniel funded a project to build a water pipe to allow a community access to clean water once again. Another volunteer made a book of photographs, the proceeds of which fund Itapoa's efforts. Raul has raised money to buy another tract of land in the Choco, in order to protect it from being deforested.
I've watched all this happen while living in New York, working on a graduate degree in Creative Writing and Literature. Now, with the end of classes in sight, I'm making my way back to the Itapoa Reserve.
The plan is two-fold.
Fold number one.
With your help, I'll be donating to Itapoa a brand-new laptop with editing software and a video camera. Why? Because Raul, his volunteers, and his neighbors are taking small steps to save the Choco. But if they could reach more people - potential volunteers, biologists, researchers, universities, even the Ministry of Environment! - and these people take even more small steps to save the Choco, the next thing you know, you've turned 10 small steps into 1,000. You've turned .3% of the protected forest into 30%.
Right now, Raul's publicity of his cause depends on photos that volunteers take with their digital and cell phone cameras. And he's managing. His facebook page is filled photos of endangered animals, and volunteers trekking through the forest, encountering thigh-high mud pits and monkeys. People want to help, and Raul's often got a few volunteers at a time devoting, as I did, a couple of weeks or months to the cause.
But let's imagine what he could do with video equipment. 
In fact, I asked Raul to imagine what he might do with it, and he gave me one idea after the next. Here's an overview of a few of those ideas, so you get the gist of what a game-changer video could be for his cause.

An educational video highlighting the Itapoa reserve. Featuring Raul, neighboring communities, international volunteers, and the Choco - where it thrives, and where it has been destroyed.
A video of the Choco's endangered birds. Aimed at birders, biologists, audobon societies, conservation organizations. 
Video for crowdfunding sites (like this one!). Raul is currently working on a children's book to educated local and indigenous children. Raising literacy rates will prevent locals, many of whom are illiterate and therefore unaware of their rights, from being targeted by African palm companies that notoriously take advantage of these circumstances, and buy up locals' land for mere hundreds of dollars.

Each video, with its unique targeted audience, and in its own way, will educate, raise awareness, and call to action thousands of people who, today, remain unaware of the endangered Choco rainforest. 
Fold number two.
Raul and I will make the first video on that list together. I'll get him acquainted with the camera, and give him instruction in basic editing. All interested volunteers and locals will participate as well, receiving training and lots of hands-on experience.
We'll spend about two months collecting footage and editing together a short film. By the time I leave, he'll be comfortable enough with the equipment that he can shoot his own video, like the ones described above, and, if he can help it, dozens more.
And the video I'm shooting video is going to be really, really cool.
My friend Will, an engineer, is donating a flying camera for the duration of my trip. That's right, a flying camera. It's a hero cam strapped onto a robot. And he'll be there to operate it.
We can get a bird's eye view of the deforested rainforest. We can get a bird's eye view of other birds' eyes. 
And we'll be using the regular, non-flying camera too. We'll collect footage of the reserve, and interview locals and volunteers, and put together a neat, concise picture of Raul and the Itapoa Reserve. This video will be designed to attract volunteers. It will be featured on Raul's web site, which right now is quite basic. With this video, he can take fuller advantage of the traffic the Itapoa Reserve attracts from facebook, word of mouth, and even Lonely Planet. 
What I'm asking from you.


All the funding I receive on Indiegogo will go toward camera and audio equipment and a lap top with Final Cut Pro - all of which will donated to the Itapoa Reserve - and my plane ticket. 
Luckily I won't need any money once I'm down there (living in the rainforest is free!).
What you get in return.
Our money is hard-earned. And some of us don't have much left after bills are paid. I've been a grad student for the past few years; boy do I understand. 
Say you skip a latte. Say you buy a book used instead of new. Say you skip a whole week of lattes. Say you don't want to skip any of these things, but you're still able and willing to donate. Or, who knows, you found a balled-up bill at the bottom of the dryer today. Trust me: donating to save the rainforest tastes better than coffee, and smells better than a crispy, new book. Every dollar counts. 
What's more, in exchange for your donation, you get awesome stuff from the heart of the Choco rainforest. Check out the perks! There's sustainable chocolate, harvested by locals and made by Itapoa volunteers. There's local artwork. There are framed photos, hand-carved rings, dried and pressed flora - all from the Choco. 
What happens if I don't reach my goal?
If I don't reach my goal, I'll still get the amount I raised, but I'll have pay a higher fee to Indiegogo. I won't be able to donate the new laptop, editing software, camera and audio equipment to Raul and the Itapoa Reserve. 
Not reaching my goal would certainly be a hiccup. But I'd hold my breathe, drink some water, and help Raul in whatever capacity I can. I'll still make the video. I'll scrounge up any and all equipment I can to bring with me. I will spend two months in the Choco doing anything and everything I can to protect it.
Are you having trouble donating through paypal?
Send me an email: danielle.e.berg@gmail.com. We'll work it out.


Other ways you can help.
Just because you can't donate money doesn't mean you can't help.
Spread the word! Do you have a friend who loves to travel? Who loves nature? Who loves South America? Or a friend/family member who enjoys giving to a good cause? Send them on over. 
Donate old clothes. There's lots of bugs in the Choco. I've got to keep covered from neck to ankle, in heat-friendly colors/material. Got stuff with holes and stains? I'll take it.
Got any photo/video equipment? Editing software? A connection that'll offer a discount? Email me. 
For more information, check out:
Itapoa's web site: http://www.itapoareserve.com/
and facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Itapoa-Tropical-R...
These articles on the future of the Choco: 
http://www.environment.ucla.edu/ctr/research/ecuador/choco_rainforest.html
http://news.mongabay.com/2008/1009-interview_ka...
A vivid account of Raul's guided jungle trek into the Choco:
http://www.lonelyplanet.com/thorntree/thread.js...
My blog:
http://olddanyeller.tumblr.com

story:
Hi, my name is Dominick Myers. Not only do I want to do this project to help out, but for myself. Since I could remember I have always wanted to do something to help someone else. My grandfather was a police officer so I looked up to him keeping my community safe; but that type of job wasn’t for me. It wasn’t till I teamed up with Planet Rag that I knew I wanted to help people abroad, in other countries that didn’t have all the luxuries I did growing up. I know the way it feels to get something new (to me). I want the families in Uganda to feel what it feels like to get something. To have that weight lifted off their shoulders because they finally have a decent set of clothes to wear.

$3,200 will cover all expenses for the trip and getting the clothes to Mabare, Uganda. I'm saving up myself from working when im not in classes and I would be so stoked just to make it to $1800 for my plane ticket. I will be spending 2 weeks there not only handing out clothes to families but I will be helping extend the pipeline of a well and helping with community education workshops. Im planning to use space bags and jam pack my suitcase and all my fellow travelers extra suitcases with the clothes to get it all there.

I currently am teaming with Planet Rag in starting textile recycling drives. I have already started collecting reusable clothes to help. I plan to take this as far as all schools in my county. I am also in the process of bringing this back to where I’m from in central California to get as much as possible to bring to Uganda. ALL reusable clothing will be properly sanitized and sorted before bringing to Uganda. ALL textile scraps will be collected and sold to textile recycling companies in bulk to help with costs of the trip.

From Planet Rag: "We at Planet Rag are here to get the word out for textile recycling. Not only do we want to recycle our textiles, but we want to reuse them in any way possible. Most people look over the fact that textiles are recyclable. Going to Uganda to donate clothing to families in need does not only help us reuse our textiles. It brings a smile to some people that may not get new clothing often. It’s not always about the big things that change the world, it sometimes can come down to the little things that can make just one person happy.

It is vital that we aid in lighting the load on our Mother Earth. Each year we send an enormous 11.1 million tons of textiles to our landfills. In fact, the average American disposes 65lbs of clothing and textiles each year and only 10lbs are actually recycled.

Essentially 99% of all garments and textiles are recyclable."

When I go to Uganda I plan on keeping a daily blog going of my trip. I want to make sure everyone supporting this project knows exactly what’s going on. Just because some may never go to Uganda for something like this doesn’t mean they can't experience what it’s like.

story:
With the $7,000 raised through this campaign, ACT will repair and renovate the Yachaikury School's dilapidated infrastructure, including the construction of two additional dormitories, with the goal of bolstering the school's capacity as the central hub in a network of associated schools primarily serving indigenous and peasant communities.

The Amazon Conservation Team (ACT)

The Amazon Conservation Team (ACT) was established in 1996 to work in partnership with indigenous people of tropical South America to protect biodiversity, improve health, and strengthen culture in an effort to preserve one of the world's most precious resources, the Amazon rainforest. By helping indigenous communities work in close collaboration, ACT has created a powerful and effective alliance of stakeholders working to conserve the Amazon.

The Yachaikury School of Colombia

ACT firmly believes that the most effective way to protect the indigenous people of the Amazon is to protect the rainforest to which they are inextricably tied. At the same time, we believe an especially effective way to protect the rainforest is to protect and strengthen indigenous youth, empowering them to address the many challenges they face.

Fundamental to this process is providing culturally relevant educational opportunities to indigenous youth. With funding provided by this campaign, ACT will build dormitories to house students and utilize an entrepreneurial educational model, ethnoeducation.  Ethnoeducation integrates native traditions and modern academic instruction to support the values and viability of native communities.

The environmental and traditional education of indigenous youth is essential to the survival of the forests and cultures within them. In Colombia, in the transition zone between the Andes and the Amazon, indigenous and peasant communities face staggering environmental and social pressures. In June 2000, ACT helped establish the Yachaikury Ethno-Education School in this region to empower indigenous youth who will ultimately become guardians of the rainforest. Nearly 75% of its students live in the school's dormitories. However, the school does not have adequate infrastructure, computer equipment, desks, or learning materials for its students. Moreover, the school does not have enough resources to feed all of its students, nor pay its staff and administration.  If we are fortunate enough to surpass our goal with your help, we will address these additional critical issues as well.

The Global Impact of Educating the Children of the Forest

The key to containing global climate change is the protection of the rainforests. When a tree is burned, the primary driver of global warming, carbon, is released. We must empower the future guardians of the forests to prevent the killing of these trees. Funding construction of dormitories at the Yachaikury School allows ACT to provide the tools these children, the future guardians of the forest, need to control their lands, preserve their culture, and lead the fight against encroaching deforestation.

Perks!

To show our gratitude for your generosity, we would like to offer these tokens of appreciation:

$25 - ACT clear vinyl sticker to show your support to everyone!

$50 - Amazon rainforest workbook educating schoolchildren about the significance of the people, culture and biodiversity of the rainforest

$500 - Acknowledgment of your donation on the ACT website page devoted to the Yachaikury school project and a woven bracelet handcrafted by women of the Amazon

What else you can do

Please visit www.amazonteam.org to learn more about our unique, effective approach to preserving the rainforest, its peoples and its cultures. Share this campaign with your friends, and let them know that the fight to contain climate change is global and that helping the students of the Yachaikury School will make a real contribution to this effort.

We won't get a second chance to save the rainforest!

story:
Woman as a force of nature ~ on behalf of nature. 

You can still donate....

STRETCH GOAL: Brilliant backers, we just reached our goal! THANK YOU so much. We want you to know that all funds we raise above and beyond our $88,000 will all go to plant trees in Southern India! To donate just select a perk...

Thank you SO much for helping to Grow TreeSisters!

What is TreeSisters?

Imagine a reforestation revolution ignited by the shared creativity and courage of a global network of millions of women - and you are sharing our vision. We aim to help reforest the tropics within 10 years by engaging the unique feminine consciousness, gifts and leadership of women everywhere and focusing it towards that goal.

“Scientifically, practically, and emotionally, the work and purpose of TreeSisters is one of, if not the most, significant initiatives that can be undertaken by humankind to address the future of civilization. The world’s greatest land-based stores of carbon reside between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn in the form of forests. Their restoration is critical to reverse climate change and create a humane and liveable future.
Can women accomplish something that has failed governments and agencies for decades? I not only think so—I believe it may be the only way it can be accomplished.”
~Paul Hawken, Author of 'Blessed Unrest' and Founder of Project Drawdown

To go to the next level we need to build a state of the art online platform and several short films to activate the ingenuity and generosity of the global community to help normalize monthly giving to trees. To do that we need your help.

The new site will underpin both the social mobilization and practical delivery of our shared ecological impact year by year - eg: 100,000 trees/month by the end of 2016 - which we do by channeling donations into a diverse portfolio of existing tropical tree-planting organizations who we partner with.

We have funded 27,400 trees to date and with your support we can grow this exponentially.


Who are we?

We are a nature-based women’s organisation focusing upon the vast reservoir of feminine capacities that are ready to be unleashed into our world to reinstate a global culture of ecological responsibility and care.

We produce online feminine wisdom courses and co-create reforestation funding campaigns. Our courses plug women back into personal power and nature connectedness - inspiring them to make giving back to nature (by funding trees) core to their lives.

We are a registered UK based charity composed of a growing international team of social entrepreneurs, cultural creatives and volunteers, led by an experienced Board of Trustees.

We believe women across the globe are dreaming the same dream: a thriving planet for our children’s children to call home.

  • We have over 78,000 followers, 3,650 members and 475 monthly donors

  • Our first 27,400 tropical evergreen trees are planted

  • Our courses have inspired a wave of nature-based feminine leadership for over 600 women.

    TreeSisters is a twin tree. One trunk embodies our mission to help reforest the Tropics and the other trunk embodies our mission to awaken and call forth women’s nature-based feminine leadership as the means by which we bring balance back to our planet. The two trunks share a common root system. For us, women and trees are indivisible.



Why we need your help

It's time to to activate our existing network and call in millions of new treesisters to take shared ownership of our mission. Your donation will fund the development of our new, interactive, online community platform - the crucial beating heart of the global network - and catalyze the growth of this movement.

There are many components to the campaign that need to be designed and created ready to launch next Spring (see detailed breakdown below) that you are supporting us to deliver, including the vital marketing campaign and several short films that articulate our reforestation strategy, unique cosmology, mission and vision.  

This is literally everything that we need to take our campaign to scale and deliver our reforestation goals in 2016.

What your contribution will fund
Budget Breakdown:

Website
We are working with an award winning technology team called 'Nameless' to design a new system robust enough to manage the increased volume of members, donors, course participants and traffic to tree campaigns needed to achieve the scale of visibility and network growth required to deliver our mission. This includes new levels of interactivity, community capacity and the mapping technologies needed to catalyze creative cross pollination, direct action and local planting throughout the network.

User Experience ~ designing the seamless navigation of our offerings: $4,800
Branding ~ finding the fullest expression of the TreeSisters mission: $2,100
Design ~ creating the most compelling, grounded, robust web design: $5,400
Build ~ architecting the interactive platform to handle our ever-expanding global network of hundreds of thousands of women: $54,400

Campaign Management  
A wave of outreach, marketing and interaction for three months: $5,310

Video Production
The creation of three short, magnetic films that serve as invitations into the heart of the TreeSisters ethos:
~Development of the first major tree campaign video: $830
~An in-depth exploration of the TreeSisters map: $830
~Clare's personal introduction to TreeSisters: $830

Advertising
This is where the rubber hits the road! It will help us create the necessary reach to bring in the people we need to fulfill and surpass our goal, so that the women who are made for this can find us: $4,500

Planting a tree for every donor: $1,000
Indiegogo Campaign Fees: $8,000

TOTAL: $88,000

Thank you so much for helping us reach our goal!


How YOU can be part of this movement

This is an invitation to join a circle of women around the bonfire of life.

By donating today you are underpinning a mechanism designed to deliver long term ecological and behavioural change. You will become part of TreeSisters and receive a nourishing series of welcome e-mails with gifts and tools to inspire you, as well as invitation to attend the When 1000 Goddesses Gather event to celebrate those answering the call of this campaign.

Every amount is deeply appreciated and will greatly help us to grow this forest.

A global network of mobilized treesisters can crowdfund major tropical reforestation fast. Help us build the online heart of the network to launch the movement bigger and catalyze more direct action on behalf of the trees.


You will also receive these gorgeous gifts!

(all gifts will be sent to you in November.)

$11 ~ Nurturing

You receive our heartfelt gratitude and an invite to our When 1000 Goddesses Gather online global meditation (tree brothers are welcome too!)

$22 ~ Planting

We will plant a tree in your name, and you’ll receive an invite to When 1000 Goddesses Gather.

$33 ~ Belonging

You’ll receive a two hour online retreat: Reinstating the Feminine, with TreeSisters founder Clare Dakin (plus all the above)

$55 ~ Igniting

You’ll receive a two hour online retreat: The Roots of a Woman’s Soul, with Clare Dakin and Edveeje Fairchild (plus all the above)

$77 ~ Re-Wilding

You’ll receive a Wild Soul Woman Online Retreat ~ Embodying the Wisdom of the Forest, with TreeSisters Instructor Mary Reynolds Thompson (plus all the above)

$99 ~ Seeding

You’ll receive a free place on our next online course (plus all the above)

$250 ~ Empowering

You’ll receive a free place on our next two online courses (plus all the above)

$2500 ~ Activating

You’ll receive an individual TreeSister Map session with Clare Dakin and a coaching session with TreeSisters’ Cultural Midwife, Edveeje Fairchild (only five available) (plus all the above)


How YOU can help

Every time you share this campaign with a friend, you help to seed this movement. Thank you SO much for sharing it with your community:

  • Share it on Facebook 

  • Email it to five friends

  • Tweet about it

  • Invite your friends to the Facebook event

With your generous donation we hope to gather 5,000 active TreeSisters and $50,000 donated monthly to plant over one million more trees in the tropics in 2016.

Your generosity is invaluable, thank you so much!

The TreeSisters Team
Clare, Edveeje, Kalyani, Amrita and Sophie

story_txt:
Woman as a force of nature ~ on behalf of nature. You can still donate....STRETCH GOAL: Brilliant backers, we just reached our goal! THANK YOU so much. We want you to know that all funds we raise above and beyond our $88,000 will all go to plant trees in Southern India! To donate just select a perk...Thank you SO much for helping to Grow TreeSisters!
What is TreeSisters?Imagine a reforestation
revolution ignited by the shared creativity and courage of a global network of
millions of women - and you are sharing our vision. We aim to help reforest the
tropics within 10 years by engaging the unique feminine consciousness, gifts
and leadership of women everywhere and focusing it towards that goal.
“Scientifically, practically, and emotionally, the work and purpose of TreeSisters is one of, if not the most, significant initiatives that can be undertaken by humankind to address the future of civilization. The world’s greatest land-based stores of carbon reside between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn in the form of forests. Their restoration is critical to reverse climate change and create a humane and liveable future.Can women accomplish something that has failed governments and agencies for decades? I not only think so—I believe it may be the only way it can be accomplished.” ~Paul Hawken, Author of 'Blessed Unrest' and Founder of Project Drawdown

To go to the next level we
need to build a state of the art online platform and several short films to
activate the ingenuity and generosity of the global community to help normalize
monthly giving to trees. To do that we need your help. 
The new site will underpin both the social mobilization and practical delivery
of our shared ecological impact year by year - eg: 100,000 trees/month by the
end of 2016 - which we do by channeling donations into a diverse portfolio of
existing tropical tree-planting organizations who we partner with.
We have funded 27,400 trees to date and with your support we
can grow this exponentially.



Who are we?We are a nature-based women’s organisation focusing upon the vast reservoir of feminine capacities that are ready to be unleashed into our world to reinstate a global culture of ecological responsibility and care.We produce online feminine wisdom courses and co-create reforestation funding campaigns. Our courses plug women back into personal power and nature connectedness - inspiring them to make giving back to nature (by funding trees) core to their lives.We are a registered UK based charity composed of a growing international team of social entrepreneurs, cultural creatives and volunteers, led by an experienced Board of Trustees.We believe women across the globe are dreaming the same dream: a thriving planet for our children’s children to call home.
We have over 78,000 followers, 3,650 members and 475 monthly donors
Our first 27,400 tropical evergreen trees are planted

Our courses have inspired a wave of nature-based feminine leadership for over 600 women.

TreeSisters is a twin tree. One trunk embodies our
mission to help reforest the Tropics and the other trunk embodies our mission
to awaken and call forth women’s nature-based feminine leadership as the means
by which we bring balance back to our planet. The two trunks share a common
root system. For us, women and trees are indivisible.



Why we need your helpIt's time to to activate our existing network and call in millions of new treesisters to take shared ownership of our mission. Your donation will fund the development of our new, interactive, online community platform - the crucial beating heart of the global network - and catalyze the growth of this movement.There are many components to the campaign that need to be designed and created ready to launch next Spring (see detailed breakdown below) that you are supporting us to deliver, including the vital marketing campaign and several short films that articulate our reforestation strategy, unique cosmology, mission and vision.  This is literally everything that we need to take our campaign to scale and deliver our reforestation goals in 2016.What your contribution will fundBudget Breakdown:
Website We are working with an award winning technology team called 'Nameless' to design a new system robust enough to manage the increased volume of members, donors, course participants and traffic to tree campaigns needed to achieve the scale of visibility and network growth required to deliver our mission. This includes new levels of interactivity, community capacity and the mapping technologies needed to catalyze creative cross pollination, direct action and local planting throughout the network.User Experience ~ designing the seamless navigation of our offerings: $4,800Branding ~ finding the fullest expression of the TreeSisters mission: $2,100Design ~ creating the most compelling, grounded, robust web design: $5,400Build ~ architecting the interactive platform to handle our ever-expanding global network of hundreds of thousands of women: $54,400Campaign Management  A wave of outreach, marketing and interaction for three months: $5,310Video ProductionThe creation of three short, magnetic films that serve as invitations into the heart of the TreeSisters ethos: ~Development of the first major tree campaign video: $830~An in-depth exploration of the TreeSisters map: $830~Clare's personal introduction to TreeSisters: $830Advertising This is where the rubber hits the road! It will help us create the necessary reach to bring in the people we need to fulfill and surpass our goal, so that the women who are made for this can find us: $4,500Planting a tree for every donor: $1,000Indiegogo Campaign Fees: $8,000
TOTAL: $88,000Thank you so much for helping us reach our goal!


How YOU can be part of this movement
This is an invitation to join a circle of women around the bonfire of life.
By donating today you are underpinning a mechanism designed to deliver long term ecological and behavioural change. You will become part of TreeSisters and receive a nourishing series of welcome e-mails with gifts and tools to inspire you, as well as invitation to attend the When 1000 Goddesses Gather event to celebrate those answering the call of this campaign.
Every amount is deeply appreciated and will greatly help us to grow this forest.
A global network of mobilized treesisters can crowdfund major tropical reforestation fast. Help us build the online heart of the network to launch the movement bigger and catalyze more direct action on behalf of the trees. 
You will also receive these gorgeous gifts!
(all gifts will be sent to you in November.)
$11 ~ Nurturing
You receive our heartfelt gratitude and an invite to our When 1000 Goddesses Gather online global meditation (tree brothers are welcome too!)
$22 ~ Planting
We will plant a tree in your name, and you’ll receive an invite to When 1000 Goddesses Gather.
$33 ~ Belonging
You’ll receive a two hour online retreat: Reinstating the Feminine, with TreeSisters founder Clare Dakin (plus all the above)
$55 ~ Igniting
You’ll receive a two hour online retreat: The Roots of a Woman’s Soul, with Clare Dakin and Edveeje Fairchild (plus all the above)
$77 ~ Re-Wilding
You’ll receive a Wild Soul Woman Online Retreat ~ Embodying the Wisdom of the Forest, with TreeSisters Instructor Mary Reynolds Thompson (plus all the above)

$99 ~ SeedingYou’ll receive a free place on our next online course (plus all the above)
$250 ~ EmpoweringYou’ll receive a free place on our next two online courses (plus all the above)
$2500 ~ ActivatingYou’ll receive an individual TreeSister Map session with Clare Dakin and a coaching session with TreeSisters’ Cultural Midwife, Edveeje Fairchild (only five available) (plus all the above)
How YOU can help
Every time you share this campaign with a friend, you help to seed this movement. Thank you SO much for sharing it with your community:

Share it on Facebook 
Email it to five friends
Tweet about it
Invite your friends to the Facebook event

With your generous donation we hope to gather 5,000 active TreeSisters and $50,000 donated monthly to plant over one million more trees in the tropics in 2016.
Your generosity is invaluable, thank you so much!

story:
The problem

Most of the world’s designed items are harmful to the environment and society. Design is often centered on overconsumption and waste with countless impacts up and down the supply chain. From digital media to print publishing, graphic design has a profound affect on the health of the planet and it’s people. We want to turn this around.

Consider a simple product packaging for a moment. Perhaps it’s a new cosmetic or an electronic device. Think about the length of time between the moment you spot it on the store shelf until you get it home, rip it open, and remove the product inside. How long did that take? This is the wasteful story of 90% of graphic design products. As designer Scott Ewen aptly described it, “I make beautiful trash.” The scariest part is that this is only one small part of the story. The the journey of materials and where they came from is missing. How was the packaging made or how were the materials put together? Who was affected by their sourcing? Were the employees treated fairly?

Combine that concern with the growing economical and social risks from global warming,  designers need to change the way they create to not only curb rising greenhouse gas emissions (GHG), but reverse it. However, they need the help and guidence to get started. That is where our site's tools and resources on systems thinking and sustainable desing comes in.

 

Solution

Our goal is to raise $25,000 to expand and improve our site's offerings and expand our research and outreach to encourage and increase the practice of sustainable graphic design in industry and higher education. 

We need to make significant changes, additions, and improvements to the Project Calculator tool, add a free teaching resource for design educators, enhance content, implement technical updates to the site, and launch season two of Onward Radio.

These require time and money, both of which are in short supply on our end. As full-time educators and professional designers, we donate our weekends and evenings to research and site updates, just like you do with the work you are passionate about. We want to continue providing quality free information, content, and tools. With your financial help, Re-nourish can be an ever better resource.

And the best part is, Re-nourish is a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, any donation you make is 100% tax deductible!

 

How Re-nourish started

We both went through the same serendipitous experience one thousand miles apart in the same week. While grocery shopping—Eric in Illinois and Yvette in Massachusetts—we noticed (more so than usual) the copious amounts of packaging and plastic that filled each fluorescently lit aisle. All of the graphic design in the grocery stores is just making a short pit stop before an eternity in the landfill. We both vividly remember feeling deflated yet more motivated than ever to inspire change as we discussed the experience after our coinciding shopping trips. Waste, and the endless connected problems associated with it, is a wicked problem. It seems like it can’t be solved. We asked how can—and will—our profession ever evolve? Is it hopeless? What can we do?

Since 2008 we have been working together with the one goal of making the outcomes of the graphic design profession sustainable. To do so we created Re-nourish, a nonprofit organization that provides online interactive tools, resources, a podcast, and consulting to create positive change in our field.

After all, to ‘renourish’ means to foster, cherish, and strengthen positive growth. Those are our goals and we need help making sure it happens. This will take a committed community. (You.) Join us.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends and networks. We thank you for helping spread the word and supporting sustainable design!

 

FAQs

Why does it cost so much to update and improve the Re-nourish calculator?

Great question! Updating and improving the calculator tool requires significant research on the latest metrics, science and conversions. It also requires bringing the current information up to date on the printing industry's best and latest practices. Time = money my friends! The second  stage of the calculator updates involves some complicated development and backend coding using something SQL databases and Ajax and javascript and other languages we've never really heard of. It's pretty hard-core nerd, even to us, so that's why we have to hire some pretty talented folks to bring our vision to life. It will be worth it, we're sure.

What updates can we look forward to on the Re-nourish calculator ?

With the calculator updates, users will be able to choose different units of measurement (the metric system!) and add in other materials in addition to paper (like fabric, web press sheets, etc). Our goal is to create user accounts so that you can save your projects and compare your savings over time and include more detailed and accurate environmental savings data. 

Why should I donate to the educators portion of the site if I don't teach?

Another great question! First off, you might end up teaching one day! We never thought we'd be educators, but low and behold, here we are. It is quite a rewarding and challenging profession! But back to your questions... the money that goes toward this section of the site will pay for technical help to develop a strong educator-driven project/curriculum community. Young designers need a design foundation that is rooted in the tenets of sustainability. There is not enough of this happening in our colleges and universities, and those educators who want to get started teaching this topic lack the time and resources to make a change on their own. Your donation will help on the technical side of this portion of the site giving young designers more of a shot of changing the industry starting with their first class. 

What does the money go toward for Onward Radio season 2?

During season 1, we relied on Apple GarageBand and some free software to make Skype not sound so tinny and yucky. Eric did the recording tech, interview preparation, and sound editing. It was a lot of work that delayed many of the episodes. We aim to hire an assistant to help with some of these efforts and invest in better recording software and equipment to create a better product. And lest we forget, we need to pay our annual hosting fees and advertising.

Have a question to add? Get in touch with us and we'll respond right away!

story:
Who are we?

Singing Rooster helps Haitian farmers cultivate and process high quality, gourmet coffee. Then we buy/export tons of it at premium prices, roast and package, then create new markets on behalf of farmer partners. 

Since 2009, we've invested 100% of sale proceeds and donations into our supply chain to ensure impact through:

  1. Premium prices: we pay a minimum of $3 per pound green (double the price most coffee companies pay), which put thousands into the pockets of small-scale producers.
  2. Continuous improvement: We've returned over $86,000 from roasted coffee sales to improve harvest management, upgrade equipment, building repairs, more.
  3. Buyer Finance: We've supported over $500,000 in affordable financing to partner cooperatives for pre-harvest work and working capital.
  4. Building a Movement:  we've helped other non-profits to raise over $150,000 through Singing Rooster's coffee fund raiser program.

What’s next?  Farmers need help regenerating tired, old coffee fields while simultaneously promoting reforestation on Haiti's bare mountains.

What We Need + What You Get

Farmers have already raised $4,000 from roasted coffee sale proceeds to build a seedling nursery.  They need an additional $4,000 to complete the project.  Combined, their hard earned $4,000 with your $4,000 in donations will provide greater incomes and promote reforestation efforts: 

  • Coffee trees have a perfect root structure for holding delicate mountain soil in place: horizontal roots stretch for meters.
  • Since coffee provides income, they won't be cut down for firewood. 
  • Coffee trees thrive in the shade of larger trees, and therefore they serve as protectors of the forest (shade trees won’t be cut down either).

We need your help. 100% of your dollars will go directly towards building a coffee seedling nursery, which will produce over 32,000 seedlings.

  • $10 = 40 seedlings, which grow into earth-stabilizing and productive trees for 20 years.

The Impact

32,000 coffee trees will generate:

  • over 640,000 pounds of coffee across a 20-year period
  • over $2,200,000 in farmer income
  • soil stability, which improves watersheds & water availability
  • protection of taller, old-growth trees
  • tens of thousands of jobs
  • dignity/autonomy - farmers want meaningful employment

Thank You Perks:  

We believe in sharing the love and will send you coffee (or Haitian art) as a thank you:

  • $35 = one bag of Singing Rooster Haitian coffee
  • $50 = two bags of Singing Rooster Haitian coffee
  • $85 = three bags of Singing Rooster Haitian coffee
In addition to coffee perks, we have 2 beautiful tree of life sculptures for larger contributions. These handmade pieces are constructed using recycled metal:

  • $150: 17-inch tree of life
  • $250: 23-inch tree of life

We have a proven track record working with farmers. Read more about our work: http://www.singingrooster.org/

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to making a contribution, share our campaign!  We want to raise the funds by Tuesday April 22 -- Earth Day.  Please  make some noise about our campaign. Using the Indiegogo share tool is a great way to get the word out. Twitter, Facebook & email your friends too.

story:
Racing with the Sun is a documentary on the urgent need to harden the power grid against X-class solar flares. X-Class flares are hundreds of times more powerful than normal flares and, if one of them should directly hit the Earth, scientists say its electro-magnetic energy would knock out the power grid, not just for hours or days, but for years. That’s because primary transformers would be destroyed, and it takes up to two years to replace them – assuming the factories that build them have electrical power to do so.

Fortunately, X-Class flares occur only two or three times each year, and few of those hit the Earth. But, unfortunately, one does hit the Earth about every one-hundred-and-fifty years, on average. The last one occurred 155 years ago!

Earth is racing to keep its next appointment with the Sun. When it happens, it will present a challenge that has never occurred before in history. X-class flares have bombarded this planet for millions of years, but power grids have existed less than 100 years. The two have never come together – at least not yet – but it is inevitable.

THE GRID IS VULNERABLE
Power grids currently are not hardened to withstand a direct hit by an X-Class solar flare. If that were to happen now, the consequences would be apocalyptic. There is no other word to describe the collapse of modern civilization that would follow the long-term loss of electricity. Mankind would say goodbye to lights, refrigerators, furnaces, water from pipes, sewage disposal, trash removal, television, Internet, telephones, computers, hospitals, pharmacies, credit cards, banks, grocery stores, gasoline stations, automobiles, trains, air travel, and police protection. The worst suffering would occur in cities and suburbs. It has been estimated that 80% of the population would perish within a few months. 

"It would literally paralyze all the United States, not just for a day or an hour, but for months to years."~~ Michio Kaku, Professor of Theoretical Physics, City College of New York

"Severe geomagnetic storms have the potential to cause long-duration outages to widespread areas of the North American grid." ~~ North American Electric Reliability Corporation and the US Department of Energy, High Impact, Low Frequency Event Risks to the North American Bulk Power System (June, 2010)

Summary: Eventually, possibly within the next decade, Earth will be hit by a solar burst that will knock out the world's power grids for months or years.  ~~ Severe Space Weather Events: Understanding Societal & Economic Impacts, December 2008, National Academy of Sciences in collaboration with NASA

BAD NEWS – GOOD NEWS
The bad news is that we don’t know how much time we have to fix this problem, and it is stupid to think it could not happen in our lifetime. But the good news is that solutions are known. They are based on existing technology and are affordable – far less than the cost of installing so-called Smart Meters on everyone’s home.  

Because of corporate lethargy and government bureaucracy, no action has been taken so far except to hold hearings and issue reports. The purpose of Racing with the Sun is to set in motion a grass-roots movement to build a fire under utility companies and government agencies to get this job done – while we still can.

PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION
This program is being produced by G. Edward Griffin and Patrea Patrick, both of whom are well known for their award-winning documentaries. Because we want to get this information out to the public as quickly as possible, it will be placed on the Internet for free viewing immediately upon completion. The anticipated release date is 2014 August 15. Research is complete, topics have been determined, and several video interviews have been recorded, but 80% of the work lies ahead.

We will adjust the production to fit the amount of money raised. If we receive more than our goal, it will be applied to improving production value in such areas as music and graphics. If we receive less, we will have to cut back on the number of experts we can interview and the amount of historical footage we can purchase. In either case, we will do the best we can with what we have.

Our current goal is to obtain funding to send a camera crew around the country to record the testimony of scientists and engineers. We hope to be rolling cameras by May 5.  

FAILURE IS NOT AN OPTION
Everyone is deeply involved with the outcome of this project whether they want to or not. Literally, the future of civilization is at stake. For the sake of your family and loved ones, for your community and nation, for all humanity, please become part of this incredibly important undertaking. Failure is not an option.

is a documentary on the urgent need to harden the power grid against X-class
solar flares. X-Class flares are hundreds of times more powerful than normal
