electro-magnetic energy would knock out the power grid, not just for hours or
days, but for years. That’s because primary transformers would be destroyed,
and it takes up to two years to replace them – assuming the factories that
build them have electrical power to do so. 
Fortunately, X-Class
flares occur only two or three times each year, and few of those hit the Earth.
But, unfortunately, one does hit the Earth about every
one-hundred-and-fifty years, on average. The last one occurred 155 years ago! 
Earth is racing to keep its next appointment with the Sun. When it happens, it
will present a challenge that has never occurred before in history. X-class
flares have bombarded this planet for millions of years, but power grids have
existed less than 100 years. The two have never come together – at least not
yet – but it is inevitable.THE GRID IS VULNERABLE
Power grids currently are not hardened to withstand a direct hit by an X-Class
solar flare. If that were to happen now, the consequences would be apocalyptic.
There is no other word to describe the collapse of modern civilization that
would follow the long-term loss of electricity. Mankind would say goodbye to
lights, refrigerators, furnaces, water from pipes, sewage disposal, trash
removal, television, Internet, telephones, computers, hospitals, pharmacies,
credit cards, banks, grocery stores, gasoline stations, automobiles, trains,
air travel, and police protection. The worst suffering would occur in cities
and suburbs. It has been estimated that 80% of the population would perish
within a few months. 



"It would literally paralyze all the
  United States, not just for a day or an hour, but for months to years."~~ Michio Kaku, Professor of Theoretical
  Physics, City College of New York "Severe geomagnetic storms have the potential to cause long-duration
  outages to widespread areas of the North American grid." ~~ North American Electric
  Reliability Corporation and the US Department of Energy, High Impact, Low
  Frequency Event Risks to the North American Bulk Power System (June, 2010) Summary: Eventually, possibly within the next decade, Earth will be hit by
  a solar burst that will knock out the world's power grids for months or
  years.  ~~ Severe Space Weather
  Events: Understanding Societal & Economic Impacts, December 2008,
  National Academy of Sciences in collaboration with NASA


BAD NEWS – GOOD NEWS
The bad news is that we don’t know how much time we have to fix this problem,
and it is stupid to think it could not happen in our lifetime. But the good
news is that solutions are known. They are based on existing technology and are
affordable – far less than the cost of installing so-called Smart Meters on
everyone’s home.  
Because of
corporate lethargy and government bureaucracy, no action has been taken so far
except to hold hearings and issue reports. The purpose of Racing with the
Sun is to
set in motion a grass-roots movement to build a fire under utility companies
and government agencies to get this job done – while we still can. PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION
This program is being produced by G.
Edward Griffin and Patrea
Patrick, both
of whom are well known for their award-winning documentaries. Because we want
to get this information out to the public as quickly as possible, it will be
placed on the Internet for free viewing immediately upon completion. The
anticipated release date is 2014 August 15. Research is complete, topics have been determined,
and several video interviews have been recorded, but 80% of the work lies
ahead. 

We will adjust the production
to fit the amount of money raised. If we receive more than our goal, it will be
applied to improving production value in such areas as music and graphics. If
we receive less, we will have to cut back on the number of experts we can
interview and the amount of historical footage we can purchase. In either case,
we will do the best we can with what we have.

Our current goal is to
obtain funding to send a camera crew around the country to record the testimony
of scientists and engineers. We hope to be rolling cameras by May 5.  
FAILURE
IS NOT AN OPTIONEveryone
is deeply involved with the outcome of this project whether they want to or
not. Literally, the future of civilization is at stake. For the sake of your
family and loved ones, for your community and nation, for all humanity, please
become part of this incredibly important undertaking. Failure is not an option.

story:
About Us

Surfrider Foundation's mission is the protection and enjoyment of oceans, waves and beaches through a powerful activist network. The Volusia/Flagler Chapter of Surfrider serves our mission by educating the public about relevant issues, cleaning our beaches, and working to solve many of the issues plaguing our beaches.

What Your Donation Does

We have set a fundraising goal of $2,500 for this fundraiser. Roughly half of this money will help us purchase new Chapter t-shirts, which act as a fundraiser themselves since we are able to sell them to fund our activities. The rest of the money will be used for things like: putting on a public forum about Seismic Testing in the Atlantic, helping with our Ocean Friendly Gardens program, providing refreshments for our volunteers at beach clean ups, and a recognition event for our volunteers. In the future, we also hope to use Chapter funds for new campaigns and programs (ex: cigarette butt trash cans for the beaches or public education campaigns). 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! "Like" us on Facebook: www.facebook.com/vfsurfrider or Follow us on Twitter: www.twitter.com/vfsurfrider
  • Are you an artist? You can donate your talent by creating a new design for our Chapter t-shirts!
  • Are you a business? You can become a sponsor and have your business name and logo on our website! Sponsors can donate money, in kind donations or a discount to Surfrider members. Contact chair@volusia.surfrider.org for more info.
  • Are you a restaurant? You can donate food for our next beach clean up or event! Contact vicechair@volusia.surfrider.org for more info.
  • We always need new volunteers and specifically, leadership volunteers to help take charge of campaigns and programs!

We always need new volunteers and specifically, leadership volunteers to help take charge of campaigns and programs!

story:
Anais' Summer Trip 

  • My name is Anais, I am a senior at UC Davis and will graduate with a Bachelors of Science in Environmental Science with an emphasis in Ecology, Biodiveristy, and Conservation. 
  • I am raising money to go on a research trip to Mexico at the Calakmul Reserve, along with other students and scientists where we will be studying a variety of animal species. I will specifically be studying the jaguar. 

What I Need

  • My trip will help me gain the experience I need to get a job after college.
  • The cost of the trip is $4650 plus the cost of the plane. This expense includes all the equipment we will use, money for the scientists that will be guiding us, immunizations needed for the trip, and more. 
  • I will send a personal thank you video to everybody who donates $50 or more! 

The Impact

  • Collecting data is important in order to gain the right information for managing and conserving these species and their environment. 
  • There are many endangered species that need the knowledge and expertise of scientists to save them from human threats such as deforestation, habitat fragmentation, pollution, and more. 

Thank you in advance for the help. This trip means a lot to me and my future.

The cost of the trip is $4650 plus the cost of the plane. This expense includes all the equipment we will use, money for the scientists that will be guiding us, immunizations needed for the trip, and more.

story:
Greetings!

I'm Tyler, the compiler of this idea.

I have lots of plant medicines and crafts to offer you,
if you'll help me move north, for a new farming job this year!

The video above gives a broader explanation, as does the paragraphs below.
Further down, I explain the specifics of the "perks"
Please contact me if this setup is confusing, or if you'd like to discuss anything.

(flowers soaking in vodka; yarrow on left, st. john's wort on right)

After completing my degree in Sustainable Agriculture, I moved to Vermont last year to work on a small organic farm - teaching young people about barn animals, garden plants, and herbal medicines.
That setting allowed lots of wild-crafting of the Earth's bounty! I gratefully picked from the ground's gifts - and now I have so many herbal teas and tinctures, medicinal salves and oils!

So, could I mail anyone a small tin of healing salve, or an ounce of calming tincture? How about a non-tobacco, legal smoking blend? Or a few bags of nourishing herbal tea?!

I want to share this abundance with my friends, while also getting the green paper that's necessary to begin this next stage of my journey..



This year, I'll be living in southwest Wisconsin at New Forest Farm - the home base of author and real-world permaculture farmer Mark Shepard!! I will be managing several acres of vegetables for the Organic Valley Cooperative, as well as learning alongside Mark about his integrated perennial polycultures of fruit and nut trees, & much more.


This endeavor entails northward travel, and a few months of rental expenses - at least till the spring asparagus goes to market. All money I currently have, and could raise through this campaign, will be used to get established in Wisconsin, and attend a few relevant trainings this Spring. 
(http://mosesorganic.org/organic-university/farmscale-permaculture/)
(http://www.permaculturevoices.com/)

(New Forest Farm, Viola, WI)

Thus - If you'll help me travel north, get settled, and start learning - I can send you any of my wild-harvested and organically cultivated plant medicines. And if you're trying to stay cozy this winter, I could make you one my famous winter hats, or a pair of my hand-knitted warm socks!

Check out what I have to offer, and communicate with me further. Let's talk about how we can cultivate some healing synergy, for our bodies, and the planet, this growing season!

revolutionbytruth@gmail.com

(quart jar on left: beebalm tincture, quart jar on right: damiana/Skullcap tincture, 4oz jar on top right: st. johns wort infused oil)


PERK POSSIBILITIES:


Salves:

1. Holy Healing Salve
--""promotes the healing of bruises, sprains, fractures.. & provides effective treatment for most minor skin problems .. & stimulates tissue repair" (comfrey leaf, calendula and st. john's wort flowers)

2. Summer 2014 Blend:
--aids the healing of small cuts & abrasions, mild rashes, bug bits, poison ivy, dry skin (comfrey, plantain, mint, & jewelweed leaf; heal-all & calendula flowers)

3. Lipbalm:
Same plants as the 2014 blend, but put in a lip balm tube.

            

Tinctures:

1. Scarlet Beebalm
-- I'm still learning this plant's power. Here's some commentary; but I'd recommend humility, awe, and experimentation if you try this flower.

2. Damiana & Skullcap Blend
-- "nerve tonic, antidepressant, sexual restorative, antispasmodic"

3. Summer 2014 Blend 
-- "relaxing tonic for anxiety, restlessness and irritability"
(lemonbalm, beebalm, catnip, & st. john's wort)

Smoking Blend:

1. Summer 2014 Mix
-- Great to mix with, or to wean from, tobacco. Could be inhaled by itself, or mixed with other herbs. Inspired by Mtn Rose. (damiana, skullcap, coltsfoot, lobelia, mint)

2. Respiratory Repair
- The closest thing to a healthy cigarette. But don't add tobacco to this. These plants are effective antiseptics, expectorants, antispasmodics, & demulcents.
(coltsfoot, mullein)

Smoking Blend

Tea Blend


Herbal Tea Blends:

CUSTOM TEA BLENDS ONLY..
Red raspberry base, and then pick one or two of the following:

Dried Leaves of:

-Coltsfoot(2), Damiana, Lobelia, Lemonbalm, Mullein, Mint, Skullcap, Red Raspberry (LEAF, not fruit) & Yarrow Blossoms

OR


Hand-Knitted Hat and Socks

These can come in variable colors, but most of my yarn stock are earth-tones.



Other Stuff:
References: I tried to offer hyperlinks as much as possible, to give you the power to learn about these sacred species. My main two sources of information are PFAF.org and the Encyclopedia of Herbal Medicine.

Amounts: Salves will be in small 5mL tins, and you'll get a few. Tinctures will be in 1/2 oz or 1 oz glass bottles. Herbal Teas can be put in individual-use bags, or left loose leaf, receiving ~10 bags worth. Smoking blend will be loose leaf in a 2"x3"bag. Hats and socks are one size fits all.
*Note that I have a limited number of everything, and will update this daily, deleting what's no longer available.

Pricing:
--Beyond helping me, the prices of the perks help to cover: the cost of the individual vessels, the shipping of the medicine to you, as well as the 9% that Indiegogo takes for hosting this.
--Let me know if you'd like to barter, or need to receive these as a gift. "From each according to his ability, to each according to his need."

Contact Information:
revolutionbytruth@gmail.com
http://www.facebook.com/tyler.hess

"Disclaimer: I can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. This information is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. None of this has been evaluated by the FDA." (As if they're a legitimate source of what's safe anyways)

story:
What will we do?

We want to build and donate a mobile drinking water unit to a community which suffers from water scarcity. This can help up to 72 000 people in the first instant. In the long-run, this sustainable unit will be able to help a much larger population due to its long life cycle of 20+ years without any maintenance (50+ if maintained). 

This is the only water purification process which can provide safe water through distillation efficiently. Other processes are either too complicated or very energy-inefficient. 

 

Why should this matter to you? 

This is not a project like any other, it will change how we get water worldwide. It is a big move for the environment, for you, and for the less fortunate who cannot benefit from such an important need. With MVT, we can provide all the following benefits:

  • Access to pure drinking water for everyone worldwide
  • Provides some of the purest water due to its distillation process instead of filtration
  • 30%+ economy of energy compared to current processes
  • Even less power consumption due to its ability to be used with renewable energy
  • Can purify water at any capacity, thanks to its modular capabilities
  • Available for both large and small communities

 

And most importantly, you want less of this:

And more of this:

Together, we can make a difference,

we can make today's world a completely different one,

we can give the same rights to everyone,

and we can make this project a reality, but not without your help. 

You're not just helping us, you're helping the world. We all have needs and you can give them to less fortunate people.

You're able to help, but they can't do anything. Without your help, the world will not change.

 

So... What is MVT?

Mechanical Vapour Transfer (MVT) is the well-known Mechanical Vapour Compression process (MVC) completely reshaped and set to its lowest energy level. So, nothing new for the requirements of the Water Utilities, just a comprehensive redesign leading to many tremendous advantages and readily available for production.

MVT produces some of the purest water on Earth using the distillation process (purification of a liquid by evaporation and condensation). Vapour is extracted from all types of water, and the selected good portion of its steam is then condensed into pure water (H2O).

 

MVT has been validated!

The innovative thermodynamic cycle of MVT process has been validated by global engineering companies active in the field of water treatment, including ENGIE Tractebel. Please find here the document in full.

In this video, you can see the raw water falling and being evaporated on the external side of the evapo-condenser during operating tests. 

The process is proved to work, we now just need to redesign the prototype into the larger-scale pilot plant, which is the size of a shipping container.

 

Populations in need are grateful for being given clear water just like in this glass on the left. However, clear does not mean safe.

When water is filtered, only the visible part of the pollution is removed. But toxic minerals or small organics cannot be removed with basic filtration due to their very small size. Filtered clean water of unmonitored source can contain toxic levels of minerals (chromium, lead, mercury, etc.) or organics (VOC, THM, viruses). And sadly, sources of water are often polluted in poorer regions of the world.

With our new MVT process, we do not use filtration, we evaporate then condensate. So, even the smallest minerals are left behind which leaves us with pure water. Of course, the good minerals can be added to the H2O after, but we avoid all types of harmful minerals.

 

Sustainability

MVT fits ideally into the framework of sustainable development for the following multiple reasons ;

  • The decrease in the overall cost of desalination
  • The simplicity of design, construction and operation
  • Easier access for third world countries
  • Easier access to regions with a scarcity of skilled labour
  • Increased ease of integration with renewable energy producers
  • Energy-friendly involving the very minimum amount of electricity, reaching the theoretical limits

 

The Pilot Plant

The following images are a brief representation of the pilot plant we will build and donate to a community of your choice. This unit is the size of a shipping container, making it very small for its water purification potential of 144,000 litres/day. 

The MVT process can be used for both small and larger communities with an unlimited production capacity due to its modular capabilities. 

The advantage is that large communities will be able to purify water for a cheaper price and lower energy consumption. And for the small communities, they will now be able to afford technically efficient water purification units which provide clean and safe water. No more harmful minerals, only H2O.

 

Project Schedule

Project Research - This is where we discovered the potential of this innovation and have designed properly each of its characteristics.  

Prototype - The phase where we built the prototype, which has validated the arrangement of the new purification process. We have already invested over 1,000,000€ up to this point. 

Pilot Plant Initiation - We now need your help to redesign the small prototype into the larger-scale pilot plant, and to secure the workshop facility where we will be building and testing this pilot plant. 

Pilot Plant Launch - Building the pilot plant and obtaining the water quality certification. At this point, we will offer this unit to a town/community of your choice. 

Large Scale Production - We will then be able to produce large-scale modular units. This will change how the world purifies water.

 

How does it work?



     

      The Advantages of MVT vs. RO

      Reverse Osmosis (RO) has taken the lead of the desalination market thanks to its lower global cost than the Thermal Processes, but at the price of a seriously increased complexity regarding the design and the operation.

      Back-to-the-Basics, MVT offers a simple process, as stable as the Thermal processes, and much more cost-effective :

      • 30+% cheaper than RO on CAPEX (Capital Expenditure) thanks to its simplicity and its modular concept
      • 30+% more efficient on Electrical Energy consumption
      • Very limited OPEX, similar to Thermal processes
      • No need for a pretreatment (which is a huge handicap for RO, regarding stability and Capex)
      • No need to perform much site investigation like full water analysis over a year, 12m. bathymetry, etc.
      • No Boron related concern, very low TDS product water, directly compatible with partial or full industrial uses
      • Easy to operate
      • Easy to upgrade or decrease the capacity in the future
      • No high pressure, no high temperature, no need for noble stainless steels, no need for local high skills

       

      Energy Advantage*

      The power consumption of the MVT core process is very close to the technical minimum achievable energy consumption. In other words, it would become impossible to make this process much more efficient than we have made it. 

      (*) Core process consumption (without auxiliaries or pre-treatment) including the compressor and the electrical motor efficiencies. For seawater at 35 g/L. (1) Mechanical Vapour Transfer. (2) Reverse Osmosis/Seawater Reverse Osmosis. (3) Thermal Processes.

       

      CAPEX Advantage

      The table below compares the CAPEX of an MVT desalination plant vs. RO of the same capacity. 

       

      How Come ...?

      "To be honest, I wasn’t even trying to improve MVC, I was looking for a way to take advantage of the low-but-existing delta-temperature which resides between the oceans and their surrounding atmosphere, mostly always except two times a day during the inversions.

      After having modelled a nice process involving a master heat pump with a very high COP (coefficient of performance), the idea just came, in order to further reduce the losses of efficiency, to simply replace the heat pump with a sheet of thermal material. Doing this, was just bringing my new concept back into the field of the MVC, almost ignoring it like Professor Calculus…

      The result is MVT, an MVC with a virgin approach, a modular simple concept, and a set of so-far unexploited low-energy operating points leading to a specific energy consumption close to the minimum theoretical limit achievable for desalting."

      - Francois-M. WINANDY, Inventor of the MVT process.

What is MVT?Mechanical Vapour Transfer (MVT) is the well-known Mechanical Vapour Compression process (MVC) completely reshaped and set to its lowest energy level. So, nothing new for the requirements of the Water Utilities, just a comprehensive redesign leading to many tremendous advantages and readily available for production.MVT produces some of the purest water on Earth using the distillation process (purification of a liquid by evaporation and condensation). Vapour is extracted from all types of water, and the selected good portion of its steam is then condensed into pure water (H2O). MVT has been validated!The innovative thermodynamic cycle of MVT process has been validated by global engineering companies active in the field of water treatment, including ENGIE Tractebel. Please find here the document in full.In this video, you can see the raw water falling and being evaporated on the external side of the evapo-condenser during operating tests. The process is proved to work, we now just need to redesign the prototype into the larger-scale pilot plant, which is the size of a shipping container. Populations in need are grateful for being given clear water just like in this glass on the left. However, clear does not mean safe.When water is filtered, only the visible part of the pollution is removed. But toxic minerals or small organics cannot be removed with basic filtration due to their very small size. Filtered clean water of unmonitored source can contain toxic levels of minerals (chromium, lead, mercury, etc.) or organics (VOC, THM, viruses). And sadly, sources of water are often polluted in poorer regions of the world.With our new MVT process, we do not use filtration, we evaporate then condensate. So, even the smallest minerals are left behind which leaves us with pure water. Of course, the good minerals can be added to the H2O after, but we avoid all types of harmful minerals. SustainabilityMVT fits ideally into the framework of sustainable development for the following multiple reasons ;
The decrease in the overall cost of desalination
The simplicity of design, construction and operation

Easier access for third world countries
Easier access to regions with a scarcity of skilled labour

Increased ease of integration with renewable energy producers
Energy-friendly involving the very minimum amount of electricity, reaching the theoretical limits

 The Pilot PlantThe following images are a brief representation of the pilot plant we will build and donate to a community of your choice. This unit is the size of a shipping container, making it very small for its water purification potential of 144,000 litres/day. The MVT process can be used for both small and larger communities with an unlimited production capacity due to its modular capabilities. The advantage is that large communities will be able to purify water for a cheaper price and lower energy consumption. And for the small communities, they will now be able to afford technically efficient water purification units which provide clean and safe water. No more harmful minerals, only H2O. Project ScheduleProject Research - This is where we discovered the potential of this innovation and have designed properly each of its characteristics.  Prototype - The phase where we built the prototype, which has validated the arrangement of the new purification process. We have already invested over 1,000,000€ up to this point. Pilot Plant Initiation - We now need your help to redesign the small prototype into the larger-scale pilot plant, and to secure the workshop facility where we will be building and testing this pilot plant. Pilot Plant Launch - Building the pilot plant and obtaining the water quality certification. At this point, we will offer this unit to a town/community of your choice. Large Scale Production - We will then be able to produce large-scale modular units. This will change how the world purifies water. How does it work? The Advantages of MVT vs. ROReverse Osmosis (RO) has taken the lead of the desalination market thanks to its lower global cost than the Thermal Processes, but at the price of a seriously increased complexity regarding the design and the operation.Back-to-the-Basics, MVT offers a simple process, as stable as the Thermal processes, and much more cost-effective :
30+% cheaper than RO on CAPEX (Capital Expenditure) thanks to its simplicity and its modular concept
30+% more efficient on Electrical Energy consumption
Very limited OPEX, similar to Thermal processes
No need for a pretreatment (which is a huge handicap for RO, regarding stability and Capex)
No need to perform much site investigation like full water analysis over a year, 12m. bathymetry, etc.
No Boron related concern, very low TDS product water, directly compatible with partial or full industrial uses
Easy to operate
Easy to upgrade or decrease the capacity in the future
No high pressure, no high temperature, no need for noble stainless steels, no need for local high skills
 Energy Advantage*The power consumption of the MVT core process is very close to the technical minimum achievable energy consumption. In other words, it would become impossible to make this process much more efficient than we have made it. (*) Core process consumption (without auxiliaries or pre-treatment) including the compressor and the electrical motor efficiencies. For seawater at 35 g/L. (1) Mechanical Vapour Transfer. (2) Reverse Osmosis/Seawater Reverse Osmosis. (3) Thermal Processes. CAPEX AdvantageThe table below compares the CAPEX of an MVT desalination plant vs. RO of the same capacity.  How Come ...?"To be honest, I wasn’t even trying to improve MVC, I was looking for a way to take advantage of the low-but-existing delta-temperature which resides between the oceans and their surrounding atmosphere, mostly always except two times a day during the inversions.After having modelled a nice process involving a master heat pump with a very high COP (coefficient of performance), the idea just came, in order to further reduce the losses of efficiency, to simply replace the heat pump with a sheet of thermal material. Doing this, was just bringing my new concept back into the field of the MVC, almost ignoring it like Professor Calculus…The result is MVT, an MVC with a virgin approach, a modular simple concept, and a set of so-far unexploited low-energy operating points leading to a specific energy consumption close to the minimum theoretical limit achievable for desalting."- Francois-M. WINANDY, Inventor of the MVT process.

story:
WE NEED YOUR HELP TO RESTORE THIS TREASURE

——UPDATE: With the help of Indiegogo and other efforts, we have raised near $40,000.  Although our Indiegogo campaign online has ended (2/7/15), we still continue our campaign to raise funds to restore the Nature Center. 

If you are interested in still contributing: you can send a check payable to the Thurston Nature Center -PTO (Thurston Elementary School, Attn: Thurston Nature Center, 2300 Prairie St, Ann Arbor, MI 48105) or use a credit card for payment for an online donation from our website thurstonnaturecenter.org. Get updates on our progress and awesome photos of the nature center by liking us on facebook.com/ThurstonNatureCenter

THANK YOU TO ALL WHO HAVE AND CONTINUE TO SUPPORT US  !  ---


Located in North East Ann Arbor, the 20 acre site has been used for 50 years to support hundreds of environmental educational explorative and experimental learning activities for students of all ages.  Since 1966 the Thurston Nature Center has served the community by a dedicated group of local volunteer residents with community donated  time, resources and funding. However, the little donated funding we receive cannot support our greater efforts.

The challenge we are now facing requires help from our community.  Without your support the pond and its interconnected ecosystems cannot be restored and we will lose the pond, and its associated wildlife. We have acquired the necessary permits and approvals due to the tireless efforts from a few volunteers. However, the deadline for the expiration date for the permits is fast approaching and we are are lacking the  funds to complete the Restoration Project. 

THE CRITICAL SITUATION

-  Sediment has increased to critical levels and is affecting the biodiversity of the plant and animal life in Thurston Pond and its wetlands.

-  It has reached the point where environmental education opportunities and community activities are being severely compromised.

-  The Thurston Nature Center Committee has has developed and published a comprehensive plan to rehabilitate and restore the ecological health and biodiversity of Thurston Pond and its surrounding wetlands.

- Engineering designs, difficult to obtain government & environmental approvals have been completed. WE NEED FUNDING to make this project happen in 2015.

THE PLAN IS IN MOTION AND WE NEED YOUR HELP

We need to raise $60k by  Spring 2015 to meet our project timeline. The permit we have to complete this work expires in the Fall of 2015.

Your gift will help us meet the goals of restoring the Thurston Nature Center and saving its pond.

The STRUGGLE and CHALLENGE we are now facing pleads for additional help from the community. Without your support the pond and its interconnected ecosystems cannot be restored and we will LOSE the pond, wetlands, and associated wildlife

We want to

- Improve the water quality and Increase water storage capacity

- Reinforce and strengthen the berm to better retain storm water

- Improve biodiversity and re-establish the plant and wildlife habitats

We are at a stage in our efforts that without your help we cannot change the fate of our Thurston Nature Center and specifically our precious pond ecosystem. We simply want to carry out the original dreams and goals of our forbearers and not let their efforts be lost.

It is incumbent upon all of us to consider the needs of future generations. 

Thousands have and can continue to benefit from taking advantage of our “outdoor-classroom” - as an educational environment to learn from environmental explorative and experiential interactions means what is taught in science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics curriculums inside the classroom.

WHY RESTORE THE THURSTON NATURE CENTER? 

- The Thurston Nature Center offers our community not only a holistic natural environment for enjoyment of the pond, various plants, trees, and wildlife but also environmental education for local area students.

- For decades, people have enjoyed educational programming, walking, ice skating, nature tours, bird watching and other recreational activities in the Nature Center. 

- The area provides unique environmental educational, explorative, and experimental learning activities for students of all ages.

- Recognized legacy of pioneering environmental education since 1966, the 20 acre Nature Center has beautiful walking trails, a variety of wildlife, 70+ indigenous Michigan trees, environmental education amphitheater, and 7 distinct ecosystems including  the wetlands, rain gardens, oak savannah, vegetable garden and amphibian center.

- One of only seven sites chosen in the United States to be recognized, and honored by the President and First Lady Johnson at the White House for the Youth Natural Beauty and Conservation Proclamation Act of 1967. 

-  In its glory, it was filled with deep waters and healthy wetlands with a large diversity of wildlife such as fish, trumpet swans, geese, muskrats and turtles. Today much of this population has dwindled.

- The pond is essential for controlling millions of gallons of City of Ann Arbor storm water – preventing flooding and erosion, while improving the quality of water in the Huron River.


Thank you for your support and consideration,

The Friends of the Thurston Nature Center

story:
A Montana watershed and a rural way of life are threatened by fracking. This video will inform the public and galvanize local action.

The Beartooth Front in southern Montana is gorgeous ranch and farm country, home to 17,000 people spread over 3,800 square miles. Just an hour's drive from Yellowstone National Park, the area's remarkable ecosystem is fed by five rivers that are the lifeblood of the region. 

Last fall the CEO of Energy Corporation of America (ECA), a Denver-based oil and gas company, announced that his company planned to drill 50 oil wells in the region. The announcement sent shock waves through the area, with fears that forcing the heavy industry of a large drilling operation onto our rural communities and small town way of life will have disastrous effects on the environment and local economy. 

There is no doubt what will happen if drilling is not controlled. ECA has a long history of violations and fines associated with oil and gas drilling in West Virginia and Pennsylvania. Their plans threaten the environment and economy of the region. The area's natural water supply is clean and pure -- contamination would be ruinous not only to the area's farms and ranches, but to wildlife as well. 

Montana law clearly favors the oil and gas industry to the detriment of the state's residents.  State agencies regularly issue permits without concern for the environmental impact of drilling and do not employ enough staff to inspect or punish companies that violate the law. Landowners often don't own the mineral rights under the surface, and are powerless to keep drillers off their property. Those who don't own mineral rights will likely see their property values decline. 

Members of the Northern Plains Resource Council and Carbon County Resource Council filed suit just to get a public hearing of local concerns. This slowed ECA down, but has not stopped their progress.

Because there is no help coming from State and federal agencies, the only option open to residents is local action. A grassroots effort is needed at the local level to define how and where drilling takes place, and protect our water quality and way of life.

To accomplish this, we need to inform local citizens of the dangers inherent in runaway oil and gas drilling and empower them to take action. In a rural area where instant communication is not the norm, the best way to do this quickly is to create a powerful video that will show how oil and gas extraction has affected other communities, and galvanize them to action. The video will be shown at public events, with copies passed from resident to resident throughout the area.

Members of the Northern Plains Resource Council, working with members of local affiliates Carbon County Resource Council and Stillwater Protective Association, have been working hard to raise awareness, but there is no budget for this video. Funds raised for this project will pay for all costs associated with creation of the video, including the deeply discounted services of a professional videographer, flights over the area, and other costs associated with production.

This is an opportunity to help preserve one of the few pristine watersheds in the United States. To succeed against a powerful opponent with limitless resources, we need your help and we need it now. Work started on ECA's first well in Belfry just a few days ago, as pictured below. No sooner had they started than neighbors discovered they were illegally using water without a permit.

Please support us in our efforts to put community interests above oil and gas profits. Our environment, economy and unique way of life are threatened with ruin if we don't act now. Please make a contribution today.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Alice Spacedoll. I am a vocalist, music producer and performance artist from Melbourne, Australia.

I have an important message to share with the world.

This  is important to me because I see so much suffering in the world, just like you, and I am paralyzed by the overwhelming feeling that I must do something more to help the planet.


By donating to this cause, you will be helping me to spread love, light and empowerment to the human race through music. We are all magnificent beings, and I believe that given the chance and finding the courage, confidence and love within ourselves we can change this world sooner, for the better of all beings.

What We Need & What You Get


I am looking to raise $1500AUD for this project.

All funds raised will go toward production, mastering, distribution and artwork costs.

In return for your kindness and contribution, all my music here to download for free or by donation. This new Album will also be up for free download once completed at the end of Winter.

http://alicespacedoll.bandcamp.com/

If I do not reach my financial goal, the funds will still go toward the album, and I trust the abundance will flow from other sources.

Please donate what you can or send me your blessings that I will find the abundance to complete these works so I can get them out into the World!

Thankyou for taking the time to read this.
Love Alice

story:
Even though our campaign has ended, you can still help!!

Send your TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donations through paypal.com to pete(at)earthteach.org. Please add a note saying something like "For Edgewalkers". 

Or, send a check made out to The Way Foundation (Addressed c/o Heron Brae), P.O. Box 1171, Ashland, OR 97520. 

If you don't care if it's tax deductible, you can send via paypal to our own email address, wildtender.fundraising(at)gmail.com.

What is Edgewalkers Winter Social Forestry Camp?

Edgewalkers is an emerging collective of semi-nomadic wildland tenders. Winter Social Forestry Camp is an experiment in regenerative wild-tending, where a small community of people comes together to work at restoring a landscape while living in reciprocal relationship to nature. Camped out in a temporary primitive village in the woods, we work on improving the ecological quality of the landscape through Social Forestry. We focus on tending wild plants and forests that provide sustenance as food, medicine, timber, and craft material. We are doing this work on wildlands held in public trust, in a mutually beneficial gifting relationship with land caretakers. This is the second year of our camp, and there will be 10 of us coming together for 10 weeks nestled in the mountains on the edge of the Cascades and Siskiyous in southern Oregon.


Our work: We tend and plant native plants with a focus on edibles and medicinals. We reduce forest fire fuel load by thinning in a pattern that mimics the forest shaped by historic fire regimes. We create wildlife habitat through leaving snags and brushpiles. We clear around heritage hardwoods, restore disturbed areas, manage invasive species, encourage carbon sequestration, and collect data. We work with fire as a restorative and renewing tool to help the forest, via controlled forest floor burns and fuel reduction burn piles.

                       

Our perspective: Humans are a vital link in healthy ecosystems; our presence living in the wild is not detrimental if done well, but in fact is beneficial to the spirit & diversity of plants and animals that surround us. Contrary to popular belief, many of the most ecologically rich and diverse areas of the planet have become so in part because of longstanding co-evolution with indigenous humans, not despite our presence. We do not pretend that we know how to care for the land as indigenous people to this place have practiced, but we humbly seek to learn from the traditional knowledge of the people living in ancient relationship to this place.

                                   

Our lifestyle: In addition to stewarding the land, we love to explore the cultural aspect of rewilding, and to make beauty with our hands to sustain ourselves from the land – processing wild food and medicine, weaving baskets, transforming roadkill into food and crafts and tools, building round-pole structures from forest products, and much more! We live in canvas structures with wood stoves and fir bough floors. We butcher animals, cook on an outdoor fire, support each others' emotional and spiritual development, and hold self-created rituals on each of the moon phases. We have trainings on learning to read the landscape and how to tend it well. We begin our work days with song. We prioritize hand tools and working with awareness as we cut down overcrowded trees. 

                            

              

Our culture: We are co-creating camp culture, including how we integrate our individual earth-based practices and spiritualities into our daily work, and how to slow down into human-scale time. Through consensus process and collaborative leadership models, we organize our time and learn from each other how to move through conflict in transformative ways, how to support one another in shadow work, and how to have real relationships with one another.


Our roots: We've garnered spirit and momentum through teachings of Traditional Ecological Knowledge and Wisdom, the ecological restoration movement, earth ancestral skills movements, and from fervent whispers by mentors Finisia Medrano and Hazel (a.k.a. Tom Ward, of Siskiyou Permaculture). We have grown from previous grassroots-organized community projects in rewilding, such as the RogueAbout, Camas Camp, Root Camp, Pine Nut Camp, Queer Forestry Camp, Taproots Skillshare, Free Cascadia Witchcamp, and more. We are nourished by our dear friends and mentors who have come before us and continue to hold us close, providing us with fertile earth from which to sprout.  

Our Long Term Vision: Edgewalkers is a seed that we are nurturing to germinate towards building many semi-nomadic Regenerative Tending Cooperatives that work on long term stewardship contracts on private and public lands and comprise a large mutual aid support network between land projects.  The Cooperatives will help facilitate ecological diversity and fecundity in wildlands while also nourishing and supporting the communities of human beings who tend those lands. 

We are proud of our successes from last year's camp! These are some of our highlights: 

-Clearing out competing young vegetation from several ancient stately oak trees

-Fuel reduction in about 3 acres of rich native oak woodland habitat using hand tools

-A half-acre controlled burn under an oak grove, and reseeding native food plants afterwards

-Effectively modeling collaborative empowered leadership in our human "guild" system

-Actively supporting one another in resolving interpersonal conflicts

-Sharing our experience and final work results with local community in our public open house culminating celebration

-Producing dozens of round poles for building structures on the land

-Producing our own biochar in open burn piles for our bokashi humanure system

-Training many new people in the arts of outdoor living, such as open fire cooking

-Training many new forest tenders in ecological assessment and tree felling

-Empowering new forest workers in how to wield a chainsaw and other skilled forestry tools

-and so much more


WHAT WE NEED:  

While many incredible restoration and rewilding projects currently exist, as far as we know, our project is unique in these ways: it is the seed for the creation of an economically viable culture and lifeway for rewilders; we are documenting and monitoring our work so that we can share our results; and we are deeply committed to sharing our knowledge through public outreach and education, building a bridge from rewilders to the greater community.

We really need your support to make Edgewalkers Winter Camp a success.

Your generous donations will help us cover expenses for our volunteer restoration forest tenders to live in the winter giving our gifts of labor to the land. We need food, shelter, and basic amenities. We will be purchasing infrastructure that we will continue using in future years. We need to purchase equipment to set up scientific monitoring plots, tools for forestry work, medical supplies, fire safety gear, and more!

Toward the vision of a sustainable economic way of life for rewilders, we want to provide basic stipends for our volunteers, in order to allow more of us to participate in the work of giving back to the land for longer periods of time. We are working to develop economic models which bring income from restoration work, value-added crafts, and education. For this beginning stage, we are asking for your help in supporting us as volunteers.

Any contribution helps.

All contributions are tax deductible.

Please help us pass the word to your friends and neighbors who you think might be interested, and share our campaign with your internet networks. 

We thank you from our hearts for helping us build the vision, and for believing in the possibility of a future where humans live in reciprocal, regenerative relationship with the land and each other.

All photo credits to rain crowe. See our full photo gallery from last year here.

Questions? Wanna stay in touch? Email us at wildtender.fundraising@gmail.com

that provide sustenance as food, medicine, timber, and craft
material. We are doing this work on wildlands held in public trust, in a mutually
beneficial gifting relationship with land caretakers. This is the second year of our camp, and there will be 10 of us coming together for 10 weeks nestled in the mountains on the edge of the Cascades and Siskiyous in southern Oregon.

Our
work: We tend and plant
native plants with a focus on edibles and medicinals. We reduce forest fire fuel
load by thinning in a pattern that mimics the forest shaped by historic fire regimes. We create wildlife habitat through leaving snags and brushpiles. We clear around heritage hardwoods, restore
disturbed areas, manage invasive species, encourage carbon
sequestration, and collect data. We work with fire as a restorative and renewing tool to help the forest, via controlled forest floor burns and fuel reduction burn piles.                        Our perspective:  Humans are a vital link in healthy ecosystems; our presence living in the wild is
not detrimental if done well, but in fact is beneficial to the spirit
& diversity of plants and animals that surround us. Contrary to popular belief, many of the most ecologically rich and diverse areas of the planet have become so in part because of longstanding co-evolution with indigenous humans, not despite our presence. We do not pretend that we know how to care for the land as indigenous people to this place have practiced, but we humbly seek to learn from the traditional knowledge of the people living in ancient relationship to this place.
                                    Our lifestyle: In addition to stewarding the land, we love to explore the cultural aspect of rewilding, and to make beauty with our hands to sustain ourselves from the land – processing wild food and medicine, weaving baskets, transforming roadkill into food and crafts and tools, building round-pole structures from forest products, and much more! We
live in canvas structures with wood stoves and fir bough floors. We
butcher animals, cook on an outdoor fire, support each others' emotional and spiritual development, and hold self-created rituals on each of the moon phases. We have trainings on learning to read the landscape and how to tend it well. We
begin our work days with song. We prioritize hand tools and working with awareness as we cut down overcrowded trees.                                              Our
culture:  We are co-creating camp culture, including how we
integrate our individual earth-based practices and spiritualities
into our daily work, and how to slow down into human-scale time.
Through consensus process and collaborative leadership models, we
organize our time and learn from each other how to move through
conflict in transformative ways, how to support one another in shadow
work, and how to have real relationships with one another. Our roots: We've garnered spirit and momentum through teachings of Traditional Ecological Knowledge and Wisdom, the ecological restoration movement, earth ancestral skills movements, and from fervent whispers by mentors Finisia Medrano and Hazel (a.k.a. Tom Ward, of Siskiyou Permaculture). We have grown from previous grassroots-organized community projects in rewilding, such as the RogueAbout, Camas Camp, Root Camp, Pine Nut Camp, Queer Forestry Camp, Taproots Skillshare, Free Cascadia Witchcamp, and more. We are nourished by our dear friends and mentors who have come before us and continue to hold us close, providing us with fertile earth from which to sprout.  Our Long Term Vision: Edgewalkers is a seed that we are nurturing to germinate towards building many semi-nomadic Regenerative Tending Cooperatives that work on long term stewardship contracts on private and public lands and comprise a large mutual aid support network between land projects.  The Cooperatives will help facilitate ecological diversity and fecundity in wildlands while also nourishing and supporting the communities of human beings who tend those lands. 

We are proud of our successes from last year's camp! These are some of our highlights: 
-Clearing out competing young vegetation from several ancient stately oak trees-Fuel reduction in about 3 acres of rich native oak woodland habitat using hand tools
-A half-acre controlled burn under an oak grove, and reseeding native food plants afterwards
-Effectively modeling collaborative empowered leadership in our human "guild" system
-Actively supporting one another in resolving interpersonal conflicts
-Sharing our experience and final work results with local community in our public open house culminating celebration
-Producing dozens of round poles for building structures on the land
-Producing our own biochar in open burn piles for our bokashi humanure system
-Training many new people in the arts of outdoor living, such as open fire cooking
-Training many new forest tenders in ecological assessment and tree felling
-Empowering new forest workers in how to wield a chainsaw and other skilled forestry tools
-and so much more




WHAT WE NEED:  
While many incredible restoration and rewilding projects currently exist, as far as we know, our project is unique in these ways: it is the seed for the creation of an economically viable culture and lifeway for rewilders; we are documenting and monitoring our work so that we can share our results; and we are deeply committed to sharing our knowledge through public outreach and education, building a bridge from rewilders to the greater community.
We really need your support to make Edgewalkers Winter Camp a success.
Your generous donations will help us cover expenses for our volunteer restoration forest tenders to live in the winter giving our gifts of labor to the land. We need food, shelter, and basic amenities. We will be purchasing infrastructure that we will continue using in future years. We need to purchase equipment to set up scientific monitoring plots, tools for forestry work, medical supplies, fire safety gear, and more!Toward the vision of a sustainable economic way of life for rewilders, we want to provide basic stipends for our volunteers, in order to allow more of us to participate in the work of giving back to the land for longer periods of time. We are working to develop economic models which bring income from restoration work, value-added crafts, and education. For this beginning stage, we are asking for your help in supporting us as volunteers.
Any contribution helps.All contributions are tax deductible.Please help us pass the word to your friends and neighbors who you think might be interested, and share our campaign with your internet networks. We thank you from our hearts for helping us build the vision, and for believing in the possibility of a future where humans live in reciprocal, regenerative relationship with the land and each other.All photo credits to rain crowe. See our full photo gallery from last year here.Questions? Wanna stay in touch? Email us at wildtender.fundraising@gmail.com

story:
The story about Honko

  

The coast of SW Madagascar is home to many rural communities that rely on mangrove forests for its wood (firewood and construction) and animals (fish, crabs, shrimp). However, the rapidly growing population – 71% of one commune’s population is under 21 years old – has meant more pressure on mangrove forests and degradation/deforestation of this amazing ecosystem that is also incredibly important to the livelihoods of local people.

Honko Mangrove Conservation & Education, a small NGO based in Ambondrolava, Madagascar, has been working these coastal rural communities since 2007 to promote community-based mangrove conservation and develop alternative livelihoods to simultaneously reduce dependence on mangrove resources and alleviate poverty. Our diverse initiatives, all while working closely alongside the community and local management association, have included:

  • environmental education
  • awareness about the importance of mangroves and management
  • village-based fish farming
  • apiculture
  • women's vannerie association
  • development of a community-based Plan Vivo carbon credit project that will allow the community to invest in their own conservation and community development projects
  • and more...


Honko's trusty truck

Throughout Honko’s years of existence, our truck has been with us through thick and thin, providing an essential helping hand for almost every one of our projects. However, the truck is in urgent need of repairs or, unfortunately, retirement...

In order to continue working towards Honko’s mission, we are raising funds to purchase a used vehicle that will continue the priceless assistance that our beloved, retirement-worthy truck has given us, including building village-based tree nurseries and leading village awareness events among many other activities in the year 2014. This will ensure that Honko can continue its valuable work on the ground throughout its five project area villages for years to come.


How you can help, and what's in it for you!

     

Now is your opportunity to be part of this truly effective, locally-based conservation effort! By making a contribution towards our purchase of a new truck, you will ensure the continuity of Honko’s community-based conservation and poverty alleviation efforts in SW Madagascar. It sounds cliché, but it is 100% true, every contribution counts! From a heartfelt thank you postcard from Honko, to a school mural painted in your name - every dollar will bring us closer to our fundraising goal of $8,500. All funds raised will be used towards the search for a new vehicle, or on repairs to significantly extend the lifespan of our trusty truck if we fall below the goal.

On the right hand side of this page you can see in detail the various perks that you can receive - our way of saying “THANK YOU!!” the best that we can all the way from here in Ambondrolava. And don’t feel limited by the options to the right – we are happy to receive any help that you are able to contribute :)


Can’t contribute at this time? Here’s how else you can help!

Get the word out! Share this campaign with you friends, family, coworkers, acquaintances – anyone that would be interested in supporting Honko’s efforts! The more people this campaign reaches, the better chances we have, together, of reaching our goal. You are still lending a great helping hand by simply sharing this campaign with others! See just below our video for easy ways to share this campaign on Facebook, email, Twitter, you name it! 


Thank you for your support!

story:
Clean solar cooking... 

because "cooking shouldn't kill"*. 

My name is Ricca Slone. I teach public policy in Chicago, but in 2011-2012 I taught English at a rural school in Orissa state in eastern India.  Watching the Indian women collect and carry fuelwood, and cook over smoky open stoves, made me want to help them find a safer way to feed their families. 

Millions of women collecting firewood every day for cooking fuel causes severe deforestation. The World Health Organization estimates that hazardous indoor air pollution from primitive cookstoves causes 2 million excess deaths every year. 

My idea is to introduce clean solar cooking to these women. I brought a small household-sized solar oven, the Global Sun Oven, to a rural school in India and the kids were fascinated by it! 

An American company makes a big version of this solar cookstove called the Villager Sun Oven.  The Villager Oven can cook a hot lunch for 200 children using just clean solar energy! 

I formed a company called Sun Oven India to import Villager Sun Ovens to India for a one-year demonstration. Sun Oven India brought two Villager Ovens to India in 2012. Now we want to bring more Villager Sun Ovens to India and train the cooks, so they will understand how to use the ovens efficiently and how the ovens can keep them healthy.

Your contribution will help us bring clean solar cooking to four rural schools in India this year, and six more next year. We will train village.women, and learn whether using the big ovens will increase their acceptance of solar cooking in their own homes.

What We Need & What You Get

Each Villager oven weights 980 lbs. and costs $9,500. It costs another $1,000 for a set of cooking pots and a simple trailer to move the oven indoors when needed for security. It costs at least another $1,000 per oven to ship it from the US to India, pay the import duties, and local transport in India. We also provide special cooking pots, stepladders to help raise the solar panels on the oven, and oven mitts to keep the cooks from burning themselves.

I am asking for $11,000 per oven. Sun Oven India will donate the balance for each oven. Four big sun ovens with all the items that go with them fill one shipping container for transport on a cargo ship. 

My family and friends are supporting me, by contributing their music and talents to this cause.  I will send periodic updates to all contributors who provide an email address. Check out the perks below, and thanks for supporting our campaign!  

The Impact

Together we can save lives and improve the environment in rural India through clean solar technology! This cause will help people live healthier lives and take better care of our planet. 

Please help us help these women and their families, because "cooking shouldn't kill". (*courtesy of The Global Alliance on Clean Cookstoves.)   

Other Ways You Can Help

Please post our project on your Facebook page, tweet about it, tell all your friends and colleagues, even send it to your local newspaper!

story:
Update: Hello Everyone. Ive been working hard on rebuilding the site. Between doing this and helping build the new Vodka company I have been very busy. Please share us with your friends to help us get some more press. Ill make a video later this week. Still learning all the tricks to these kind of websites but Im getting the hang of it quick lol.

Thanks again for all the support though well get there.

Best,

  Ryan Sovelius 

 

Please help support us on Facebook if you get the chance!

http://www.facebook.com/pages/All-Electric-Driverscom/425934007473374

Link to the website; Its still in its early stages:

http://www.allelectricdrivers.com/

The Electric Car Revolution

Whats the Goal?

To promote the increased usage of Electric Cars around the world through a new online magazine and webforum! We also want to emphasize the fun that electric cars are now and will increasingly become in the future along with all the new clean tech advancements that are being made in regards to all electric vehicles that will help to further clean up our world. 

As the magazine and forum start to make money we will start donating to various cities with the goal of helping them transition from carbon based automotive systems to completely 100% electric fleets and related support systems. 

The Problem and Solution

There are many new fully electric cars currently on the market but unfortunately there is no central source of information where all the benefits and other related info on these exciting new vehicles can be promoted, I hope to fill that void with the new online forum and magazine.  

I firmly believe that the electric car market will continue to grow drastically over the next few decades. This aforementioned growth will benefit first and foremost the environment that we live in and love so much but secondly itll help to get more and more people into and driving 100% electric cars as they become more aware and knowledgable on Electric Cars.

No other automotive technology makes as much sense as a pure 100% electric car. Batteries and their related cost and lifecycle were the hurdle with past electric cars but because battery technology today is accelerating at such an excitingly fast pace the overall cost of electric cars will begin to decrease drastically year after year, all of which will help to make electric cars more and more popular with the average driver. 

Some benefits of 100% All Electric Cars:

  • Good for Earths long term survival
  • Clean
  • Decrease usage of carbon based pollutants in our cities and thus lives
  • Powerful
  • Help grow the renewable energy sector
  • Futuristic
  • Fun
  • Low maintenance cost
  • New
  • Quiet
  • Efficient

 

Where do your donations go?

All donations will go to the building of All Electric Drivers.com’s online magazine and web forum.

I will pay a graphic designer to make us a nice professional logo.

I will be using the money to pay a web programmer to do coding for me to help build the magazine and to maintain the website.  

I will also have a close friend help with the global promotion of the site so we can increase traffic drastically.

I personally will write some articles but I also have a few friends who are very enthusiastic about electric cars that I will pay for their help.   

 What will be in the magazine and on the related web forum?

 

  • Discussion of new Electric Car Models
  • Magazine articles and editorials on anything to do with Electric Cars
  • General Info about Electric Cars
  • And a whole bunch of other awesome electric car related info
  • Discussions and Articles on how 100% all Electric Cars benefit our environment

 

 

With a little help from some generous donations and some good promotion from the online magazine and forum, we should be able to spread the news and encourage more and more people of all the benefits that can come from driving All Electric Cars both now and into the future.

And even if you can’t help financially you can still help by reading our future articles related to electric cars, participating in our forums, and simply just by spreading the news of our new online magazine and forum.


Lastly A big Thank You to anyone who decides to help me promote the wonders and benefits that comes with driving all electric cars.  

Best,

    Ryan Sovelius 

 

Please check out and like our facebook page if you get a chance. Any support is much appreciated. 

http://www.facebook.com/pages/All-Electric-Driverscom/425934007473374

 

Who is Ryan?

I’m a native Texan and graduate of the University of Texas at Austin who has loved all types of cars since birth. After I graduated from undergrad I thought I might go off to Law School but after doing some soul searching and a 7 month internship with the Justice Department I found that I was much more business/entrepreneurial minded and thus decided to forgo the legal path and instead jump into the entrepreneurial world 100%. My day job is working with a team who is starting a distillery and whose first product will be a new Vodka. The Vodka should launch around New Year’s 2013. I was also born with Craniosynostosis (1$ to anyone who knows what that is without looking it up :) ) and have an interest in all things related to it :)

story:
Background 

"One of the most amazing things you can do in life, is to follow your heart and pursue your dream. The only thing greater than that is if you can pursue your dream and manage to help and inspire other people along the way."

Our passion lies in exploring nature and its elements to the fullest, and in getting as close to Mother Nature’s incredible forces in every way possible. This has lead us to develop a strong connection to nature, so we naturally want to give back by nurturing and caring for our environment. 

Vision 

We want to inspire people to push the boundaries of their outdoor comfort zone in order to further explore and strengthen their relationship with nature. We believe that this relationship is a necessary foundation in the process of implementing solutions to environmental issues. If we can inspire more people to get outdoors, it is our hope more people will develop the same connection as we have, and start implementing some environmental nurturing habits. 

Impact 

Our belief is that if we can inspire people to get outdoors and experience the wonders nature has to offer. By getting more people out into nature, we are opening the possibility of developing a similar connection to what we have with our environment. It is this connection where people begin to feel happier and healthier whilst in the outdoors. It is also the start of developing nurturing habits, habits that in turn contribute to sustaining our environment for future generations. 

Risks & Challenges 

We will be traveling in the roughest, rawest part of Europe during a stormy season. Being exposed to such weather adds to the challenge, but it also allows us to express our respect and admiration for an environment that we cannot control. 

Enduring the bad weather makes you appreciate the good weather, but it also draws on our passion and drive to push past these hardships. These hardships will make it more of an exciting story to follow, creating drama and suspense along the journey.

story:
Greetings!
My name is Gretchen Elsner, and I am writing from Athens Georgia.I have been living in Athens building a solar powered travel trailer from the ground up since 2009.
 
It has been built from new, but mostly recycled materials gleaned from light gauge steel construction projects in the area, the local Habitat for Humanity ReStore, locally reclaimed wood, the talents of local artisans, and information absorbed by a complete novice builder at the local library. It has also been built almost entirely by bicycle. I am committed environmentalist, and I have been endeavoring to build a fully modern home that will be powered only by the eight gel batteries I have and the panels I will soon install. Here to fore I have payed for the project as I go, working still as a clothing designer and pop-up book maker, as is my craft, trade and profession for the past 13 years, as well as working construction, industrial solar installation, waitress and as a portrait model for artists. In many ways this home represents the power of a double dream, providing the basic needs for housing in a world of increasing economic and environmental instability, as well as offering a model for establishing a paradigm change that I believe can inspire and transform how art, engineering and efficacy shapes our lives.
With the funds raised through this campaign I intend to purchase the high wattage solar panels manufactured here in Georgia by Suniva. I have very limited roof space, and so installing high wattage panels is a nessesary part of the design of the system. http://www.suniva.com/
 
My research had lead me with confidence to a MPPT charge controller manufactured by Morning Star, which used power point tracking to deliver added high volts to the batteries at the peak of the charging cycle so as to maintian good battery charge and maximize the efficiecy of the panels and the life of the batteries. http://www.morningstarcorp.com/en/home
 
After inverter manufactured by Magnum Energy, light weight honeycomb paneling for the sub flooring manufactured by Plasticor. All these are American made products. I also intend to hire local solar enectricaian Garry Dale to work with me on this project.
 
 
http://www.morningstarcorp.com/en/home
http://www.magnumenergy.com/
http://www.plascore.com/
story_txt:
Greetings!My name is Gretchen Elsner, and I am writing from Athens Georgia.I have been living in Athens building a solar powered travel trailer from the ground up since 2009.
 
It has been built from new, but mostly recycled materials gleaned from light gauge steel construction projects in the area, the local Habitat for Humanity ReStore, locally reclaimed wood, the talents of local artisans, and information absorbed by a complete novice builder at the local library. It has also been built almost entirely by bicycle. I am committed environmentalist, and I have been endeavoring to build a fully modern home that will be powered only by the eight gel batteries I have and the panels I will soon install. Here to fore I have payed for the project as I go, working still as a clothing designer and pop-up book maker, as is my craft, trade and profession for the past 13 years, as well as working construction, industrial solar installation, waitress and as a portrait model for artists. In many ways this home represents the power of a double dream, providing the basic needs for housing in a world of increasing economic and environmental instability, as well as offering a model for establishing a paradigm change that I believe can inspire and transform how art, engineering and efficacy shapes our lives.
With the funds raised through this campaign I intend to purchase the high wattage solar panels manufactured here in Georgia by Suniva. I have very limited roof space, and so installing high wattage panels is a nessesary part of the design of the system. http://www.suniva.com/

 
My research had lead me with confidence to a MPPT charge controller manufactured by Morning Star, which used power point tracking to deliver added high volts to the batteries at the peak of the charging cycle so as to maintian good battery charge and maximize the efficiecy of the panels and the life of the batteries. http://www.morningstarcorp.com/en/home

 
After inverter manufactured by Magnum Energy, light weight honeycomb paneling for the sub flooring manufactured by Plasticor. All these are American made products. I also intend to hire local solar enectricaian Garry Dale to work with me on this project.
