story:
What are we doing?: students building UAV to support wildlife conservation.

An international student team (Team AREND) is collaborating to compete in the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge - to design, build & fly an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) to support anti-poaching operations in South Africa.  This student team is led by Dr. Jean Koster at the University of Colorado at Boulder, and includes teams from Helsinki Metropolia University of Applied Sciences, University of Pretoria SA, and the University of Stuttgart.

Also collaborating with and supporting / sponsoring this student team is Wildlife Protection Solutions, Helios Torque Fusion, Inc, and NIST - the National Institute for Standards and Technology.  Wildlife Protection Solutions (WPS) is an international non-profit group dedicated to the conservation of endangered species.  Their current focus is on the five species of rhinos world-wide, with a special emphasis on creating habitat and breeding programs that will allow rhino populations to grow faster than they are being poached.  Helios Torque Fusion, Inc. is a Colorado-based business working to commercialize hybrid-electric propulsion systems for UAVs, making the aircraft more fuel-efficient and quieter - both important for wildlife monitoring & protection.

Our video was produced by Ben Fraser and the Denver Zoo graciously provided the appropriate backdrop.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise nearly $200,000 to support the project in these areas of development:

  • Aircraft construction materials, fuselage & wing components, control surfaces and so forth,
  • Sponsored research with the University teams for use of mechanical and electronic shops, machinists, technicians, and administrative personnel,
  • Hybrid-electric engine development, balancing long-endurance capabilities with fuel efficiency and low noise,
  • Trade studies of military-grade sensor packages to detect animals and threats
  • Team travel for flight testing and site visits, and other documentation and administration as required for aircraft operations.

All contributions will be received by Wildlife Protection Solutions, a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization, and qualify as charitable contributions.  Additionally, every donor will receive memorabilia and recognition for their contributions to the effort - see perk details for more information about donation levels, and what the benefits are for various levels of donation.

    The Impact

    In the past 40 years, Rhino populations have suffered a 90% decline.  In Kruger National Park alone, 425 rhinos were poached in 2012, and this number has nearly doubled in 2013 as of printing time.  This kill rate is nearing parity with the birth rate, making extinction a grave concern.

    Source: Lowveld Rhino Trust

    Compounding this problem, the poaching arrest rate is only about 5% due to the extensive poacher networks, and their increasing sophistication.  Park Rangers are in desperate need of a force multiplier, which is where the UAV system comes into play. 

    Web Video (WARNING!!!, some scenes of animal violence may be disturbing, inappropriate for young or sensitive viewers):

    1.  http://youtu.be/e_e8V2TvFS8

    2.  http://youtu.be/4ATMX_YeQPI

    3.  http://youtu.be/eKHu3oNEonU

    About the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge

    In response to President Obama's Executive Order on Combating Wildlife Trafficking, Princess Aliyah, the Reserve Protection Agency, and Global Unmanned Systems initiated the worldwide Wildlife Conservation unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) Challenge to foster innovation and invention in the design, fabrication, and utilization of unmanned aircraft to assist with counter-poaching and illicit wildlife trafficking.  It calls on students, hobbyists, academics and corporations to sooperate in a design, build, fly & compute challenge that emphasizes the integration of sensors, embedded systems, and communications in a robust and high-endurance aircraft.

    Princess Aliyah created Kashmir-Robotics as a division of the Al-Kareem Foundation to ensure the best possible aircraft and ground robots are integrated with anti-poaching systems to help protect endangered species.

    Please note that this fundraising campaign is specifically to support a team participating in the competition, and not the competition itself.  More info about the challenge can be found here: www.wcuavc.com

    More Details about the causal problem...

    Demand for goods made from rhinoceros horns has skyrocketed in South East Asia and China over the last 6 years due to a rapidly rising middle class in those economies. At the root of the rhino crisis is the use of rhino horn in traditional Chinese medicine to treat fever, pain, rheumatism, cancer, erectile dysfunction and convulsions. Rhino horn is highly sought after in China and more importantly in Vietnam, despite the fact that rhino horn has been extensively analyzed scientifically and offers no medicinal properties. Nevertheless, claims of the medicinal value of these products are broadcast by profit-seekers. Rhino horn is comprised of keratin, the same material as human hair and finger/toe nails. In addition, rhino horn is a recreational drug in Vietnam and used by the middle class as a detoxifying beverage and body-rejuvenating tonic. To satisfy this demand, poaching in places like Kruger National Park in South Africa is rampant with captured rhinos killed and left to rot for nothing more than their horns. Many countries in Africa suffer from poaching. The following map shows poaching areas and market areas for the Rhino horns.

    Rhino horn trade route

    Until now many countries in Asia lacked legislation to prevent legal import of these goods. Only recently have the Chinese and Vietnamese governments implemented new laws against the import of rhino and elephant products but the question remains how quickly these laws will take effect in a flourishing black market. And more importantly when will the people in these cultures realize the irreversible damage caused by poaching rhinos is not worth their carved ornamental artifacts of no use or the ineffective traditional medicine based on horn material. The syndicated black market continues to supply the demands by the nouveau-riche until those people change their philosophies.

    Colonel Bobelo (SAM) says that it became increasingly important utilize in the army when syndicates began using helicopters, night vision equipment and high-powered rifles in their hunts. Rangers on the ground are ill equipped to stop the poachers, often outnumbered and out-gunned by a criminal network that invests in technology and intelligence to ensure their access to the rhinos. The deployment of South African National Defence Force (SANDF) members at the Kruger National Park has brought confidence that Rangers can regain control, at least to some degree. The SANDF deployed 265 soldiers at Kruger National Park and the borders around the park in March 2013, following a plea for help by the South African National Parks (SanParks).

    Until 2007 the poaching was limited. Since 2008 there was a rapid, exponential increase in poaching. Poaching became a year round activity. Poaching is considered to be a “low risk - high reward” activity by the poachers, for reasons discussed below. In recent years poachers use darting guns and veterinary drugs to immobilize the rhino. Darting guns are silent and prevent detection by patrols. With axes and/or motor saws, without veterinary knowledge that might give the animal a chance of survival, poachers cut off the horn anyway they can as it must be done very quickly in order to retreat fast. In some cases they tranquilize the animals and mutilate it so much that it cannot survive in the wild, leaving them to die a horrible death. In other cases they simply kill the animal.

    The poachers that come from other countries, particularly Mozambique, are armed with AK47s, grenades, chain saws, axes; GPS, night vision, and sometimes helicopters. They don't play, these poachers mean business. Many of the poachers are former Mozambican soldiers and are well trained to fight. They often use “tourists” in the Parks who join Ranger patrols to have the rangers guide them to locations of Rhinos. They transmit the GPS data to their command center that then dispatches the poachers, primarily during cover of night.

    Examples of poached animals are shown below. They were recent events on the ranch of John and Albina Hume. Images show how reckless the poachers are in removing the horn and how traumatic it is for the animals.

    Pictures Courtesy of Albina Hume (University of Pretoria)

    Shown below is another example of a Rhino that survived the poaching act; but only for a short time! It did not survive the event very long because of the severity of the wounds. If the animals survive poaching they are often euthanized by Rangers to stop their incredible suffering.

    Picture courtesy of Lowveld Rhino Trust; http://lowveldrhinotrust.org/#

    While a rhino horn price in 2006 was just $1000 for 1 kg (2.2 lbs.), today one kg of rhino horn has an average market value of about $80,000. Poachers often get around ZAR1 million (~$100,000) for one horn of about 4 kg (8.8 lbs.). Black market prices vary widely; as of last fall 2012 dealers in Vietnam quoted prices ranging from $33 to $133 a gram (0.002 lbs.) ($80 on average), which at the top end is higher than the price of gold (~$47/gram on 10/26/2013) and exceeds the price of cocaine in most locations including New York City.

    The poacher who is going to shoot the rhino reportedly gets R500,000 (~$50,000) from syndicated criminals, the one with an axe and the third one get R250,000 ($25,000) each. Some of the poachers are young unemployed South African men driven by poverty and lured by foreign syndicates to do the dirty job in exchange for very attractive amounts of money. These would-be poachers get a deposit from the syndicates before they carry out the job within a given time frame. Given their limited understanding of that money, they often spend the money before having the horn. As their customers are associated with global organized crime syndicates, the promise to come back with the rhino horn must be fulfilled at all costs, or else they are in big trouble to repay their debt! This means that there is also a major socio-economic problem linked to poaching.

    In recent time poachers commanded by syndicates operate in flash mobs. Multiple groups enter the park at the same time in small groups. Reports mention that up to 300 poachers were roaming in KNP at one given time.

    Park rangers are up against well-armed crime syndicates which use funds from poaching for terrorist activities.  For example, Al-Shabaab, a terrorist group aligned with al Qaeda, is raking in about $650,000 a month on the black market from poaching, according to England's Daily Express. Thus the US government announced a $1M reward for information leading to the dismantling of some syndicates, primarily operating from Laos (http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/14/world/asia/us-to-offer-reward-in-wildlife-trafficking-fight.html?ref=earth) as reported by the New York Times.

    The fight against poaching has several stages as depicted in the following sketch. The Rangers are pursuing the poachers in order to prevent the killing. Once the poacher gets past that line of defense and leave KNP into Mozambique, middlemen smuggle the horns out of that country to end-markets  Customs officials have some capability to detect the smuggle ware, but these horns do not usually enter the destination countries via conventional, legal routes. In the receiving country, there are the syndicated middlemen who distribute the horns to small back alley shops where they are prepared for the final market, primarily the nouveau riche middle class in emerging Asian countries (e.g. Vietnam and China).

    Path way of illegal trade. Interceptions are possible at each interface.

    And perhaps there is corruption involved in the entire trade. It appears that criminal syndicates have infiltrated the law enforcement and justice systems of South Africa. If an arrest is made, it happens often that filed papers are mysteriously lost. Once the dockets have gone missing, the case is over and the suspects are released. These organized criminals have systematically reduced their risk of breaking important conservation and humane rulings.  They have had the upper hand long enough – it is time for a surge in protecting forces. It is quite seriously “one-minute-to-midnight” in the war against poaching! Due to the significant money some rangers now participate in the poaching as well. On February 2012 four rangers of KNP were arrested on suspicion of poaching rhinos they are tasked to protect. (http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/29/us-sa...).

    Preventive Efforts

    Rangers have often gone into the Kruger National Park to dehorn Rhinos that roam very close to the Mozambique border. This is a measure to protect the animal from being killed, as it devalues the animal as a poaching target. These operations are done by veterinarians who know how to dehorn a Rhino without harm. The horn will grow back in several years. The Rhino will be less protected against lion attacks, but still very capable to defend itself vigorously. It would be much better not to have this kind of need for animal protection! Often the poachers even kill for a stump.

    http://www.ewt.org.za/programmes/LPP/Doc/studyon_dehorning_african_rhinoceros.pdf

    Left: The picture shows the dehorning of a White Rhinoceros Ceratotherium simum in Hwange National Park during the early 1990s; Photo was taken by M. Kock. Middle: veterinarians dehorn a tranquilized Rhino for its own protection from poaching. Right: a Rhino that recovered from dehorning performed by veterinarians.

    Kruger National Park

    Poaching is not limited to the nation of South Africa. Many African Nations, like Kenya, have major problems as shown in the table below. Much of the poaching is also done in provincial and private parks in South Africa. However, Kruger National Park (KNP) is the most severely poached park as bordering with Mozambique. The Southern White Rhino – 20165 surviving, are under huge pressure of poaching as the Black Rhino has a population of less than 5000. After declared extinct in 2006, protection has given them a chance to recover. Our project will focus on the Rhino poaching in (KNP) in South Africa where the white rhino roams. But the technology could serve everywhere to help Rangers stop poaching and animal.

    The park lies in the north-east of South Africa. It is one of the largest national parks in the world, with an area of 19,485 square kilometers (~7,580 sq miles); larger than Connecticut and a tiny bit smaller than New Jersey. KNP is approximately 360 kilometers (220 miles) long, and has an average width of 65 kilometers (40 miles). At its widest point, the park is 90 kilometers (56 miles) wide from east to west. To the north and south of the park two rivers, the Limpopo and the Crocodile respectively, act as its natural boundaries. To the east the Lebombo Mountains separate it from Mozambique the 14th poorest nation in Africa in 2013 (Financenews).

    Source: Google Maps

    The park varies in altitude between 200 m in the east and 840 m in the south-west near Berg-en-Dal. The highest point in the park is a hill called Khandzalive. Several rivers run through the park from west to east, including the Sabie, Olifants, Crocodile, Letaba, Luvuvhu and Limpopo Rivers; waterways that get also used as rhinos seek waterways.

    The climate of the Kruger National Park is subtropical. Summer days are humid and hot with temperatures often soaring to above 38 °C (100 °F). The rainy season is from September until May. September and October are the driest periods, culminating in rains late in October.

    Poaching Statistics

    The statistics of poaching show an increasing number of Rhino poaching events. Below are recent graphs that show the development of the poaching problem and visualize the exponential growth of the poaching. The current concern is that the poaching kills are exceeding the birth rate of rhinos; which is an undisputable warning sign that the extinction of rhinos is becoming a real concern.

    Data source: https://www.environment.gov.za/media/releases/rhinoissue_management_report

    Data source: Lowveld Rhino Trust; http://lowveldrhinotrust.org/

    Unfortunately the arrests made by the Rangers have, at best, remained constant and in some cases have even declined over the years. This trend has reversed a little since the military joined the rangers in the war against poachers. Of the 425 poached Rhinos in Kruger National Park in 2012 only 73 poachers were arrested. Considering that the poaching teams are often 3 to 6 men, this means only about 10-15 events were caught. That is an anti-poaching “success” rate of less than 5%! Thus poachers see their effort as a very low risk undertaking and very lucrative effort.

    In 2013 the number of poached Rhinos in South Africa has dramatically increased to 408 in the first 6 months. At this point the numbers exceed 2 Rhinos per day in the “summer” season. KNP takes the brunt of poaching with 265 animals, most of which are killed in the process. The rangers, with support of the SA military, recently improved their success with intelligence driven operations to arrest 56 poachers in that time frame. However, not all were convicted as files got mysteriously lost in transition.The current (20 November) number of poached rhinos for 2013 stands at 859 and the total arrests stands at 165 (67 in KNP). Assuming teams of 3 poachers per rhino, we compute an arrest rate of ~7%; a slight improvement, possibly due to the involvement of Army soldiers supporting the rangers. However for KNP the arrest rate decreased to 4.7%. In addition it is a war: since 2006 some 22 poachers were gunned down. But rangers are killed as well, often being outgunned by the poachers.

    Rhino poaching has dealt South Africa a financial loss of about ZAR228 million (~$23M) with the 333 rhinos poached last year alone. These are the statistics according to the Wildlife and Environment Society of South Africa (WESSA); it is for this financial reason and the need to protect rhinos that the country is going all out to counter poachers.

    Project Rationale

    In view of the escalating problem of wildlife trafficking, President Obama has signed an Executive Order for Combating Wildlife Trafficking on July 1, 2013:

    http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/07/01/executive-order-combating-wildlife-trafficking


    Now you can be part of the solution! Help us provide an unmanned aircraft solution that multiplies the Ranger’s forces.The graduate University of Colorado Boulder team will collaborate with international teams at the Universities of Pretoria, South Africa; the University of Stuttgart, Germany, Metropolia University in Helsinki, Finland, the National Institute of Science and Technology and several industries in developing an aircraft with the appropriate capabilities; thus you will gain experience in design, project management, technology transfer, global collaborations, cross-functional and multi-cultural teamwork, critical design analysis, and business organization in addition to engineering credit.

    Goal

    Conceive, Design, Implement & Operate a special remotely-piloted aircraft equipped with distinct sensors, embedded systems, and 3G/4G and TCIP communications in a robust and high endurance aircraft meeting also acoustic and wilderness operation requirements. The aircraft will be equipped with a hybrid propulsion system to satisfy one of the prime requirements of the concept of operations!

    Baseline aircraft: Hyperion


    The Challenge & Competition

    The national Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge is composed of four phases or milestones.

    Concept – By January 31, 2014

    Team proposes a concept aircraft with communications, sensors, and embedded systems.

    The global team will be developed with graduate students from the Universities of Colorado, Stuttgart, Pretoria and Helsinki. International teams of students have select knowledge to augment Colorado’s team skills. A graduate design course starting in Spring semester 2014, followed by a summer semester course and a Fall semester course is the framework for this educational project. Volunteers are working with the international team to prepare this milestone before design course begins in January 2014.

    Build & Fly – By April 30, 2014

    The global team shall design, build, and fly their aircraft and demonstrate airworthiness, communications, and safety at a local flying field. The deliverable includes a short video documenting Build & Fly (MP4 File Type).

    Design Report – By June 30, 2014

    The teams shall submit a written Design Report to the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge (http://www.wcuavc.com/home.html ). The report includes a description of hardware and software for avionics and embedded systems and demonstrated flight performance. Design reports submitted by all competing teams will be evaluated. Teams will receive recognition for best airframe, best avionics, and best embedded systems.

    The teams awarded the highest points will be approved for the next phase of the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge which is the Challenge Flight.

    Challenge Flight – August 30, 2014

    Teams shall compete in the Challenge Flight scenario defined by the challenge organizers. The Challenge will involve a mission profile that includes launch within a time window, climb to operational altitude of 300 feet above ground level (AGL), transit to several GPS way-points, collection of video and RFID tag data, on board processing, communications, return to base, and recovery.

    Specific details of the challenge scenario will not be released until the morning of the competition: teams will need to be prepared to adjust flight profiles, sensor parameters, and data processing as needed.

    Kruger Mission – Fall semester 2014. Date to be Determined

    The winning team will participate in a safari and counter-poaching mission in Kruger National Park. The mission will include several days of demonstrations and operational flights. Sponsoring companies also can bring equipment to Kruger for demonstrations.

    The Hyperion team, with its global partners, is seeking funding to position itself to develop the ultimate anti-poaching UAV and thus make a historical contribution to a successful fight against rhino poaching and finish as the winning team of the competition.

    Long Live The Rhino!

    Photo courtesy of Sean Thomas, The Telegraph

    The Project

    Conceive, Design, Build, and Operate an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that helps fight Rhino Poaching. Develop a special, remotely-piloted aircraft meeting stringent operation-in-wilderness requirements, and equipped with diverse day/night sensors to detect poachers as well as tagged Rhinos. The propulsion system is a hybrid gas-electric engine which provides endurance with the gas engine with the option to fly quietly with electric only propulsion when poachers are detected.

    The team is composed of aerospace, mechanical, electrical, computer engineers.

    Skills are needed in structures, composite materials, fabrication, aerodynamics, thermodynamics, controls, (power) electronics, sensors and instrumentation, software, etc.

    Aircraft Requirements:

    ·  Aircraft as described in Design Report. Random changes after submission not permitted.

    ·  Small modifications require submission of revised report prior to challenge flight.

    ·  Low cost UAV to perform counter-poaching missions.

    ·  Take-off gross weight < 55 lbs satisfying AMA regulations.

    ·  Compliance with Build & Fly requirements.

    ·  On site demonstration of communication system.

    ·  Must have mechanical motor arming system

    ·  Engine must be safely accessible by crew member

    ·  Safety arming device must be in safe mode for all payload access.

    ·  Communication must be always powered on

    ·  Throttle must be verified closed before activating motor arming switch.

    Aircraft Performance Requirements:

    Evaluated on ease of launch, endurance, ease of recovery.

    ·  Radio or (preferred) auto-controlled

    ·  Endurance goal: 120 minutes flight

    ·  Recovery: radio or (preferred) autopilot recovery

    ·  Recovery zone goal: 10 meters (~30 ft) radius

    ·  Take-off weight with payload < 55 lbs

    Communication Performance:

    Evaluated based on range, continuity of coverage, accessibility over internet capable devices (PC, smart phones). 3G/4G communications with backup radio links.

    ·  Range goal: 20 km (~12.4 miles)

    ·  Continuity goal: 76-100%

    ·  Accessibility over IP devices: full telemetry with video streaming

    Imagery Quality:

    Will be evaluated based on resolution, stability, low ambient light level performance

    ·  Resolution goal: 5 centimeter line separation at 300 ft AGL

    ·  Stability goal: electronic image and physical stability

    ·  Low light level (dawn/dusk) and night time

    Embedded Systems:

    Evaluated based on ability of onboard system to detect moving ground targets (humans, rhinos) in imagery. Goal is to detect and geo-register (GPS position):

    ·  moving targets

    ·  animal targets

    ·  identify animals

    Cost limit:

    ·  <$5000 TBR (without sensor package)

    ·  Goal: $1000

    Stretch goals:

    For creative and innovative ideas beyond the required specifications, teams can earn bonus points.

    Project Collaborators:

    University of Stuttgart, Germany: Aerodynamics and Composite materials

    University of Pretoria, South Africa: Aerodynamics, Controls, Wildlife management

    Metropolia University, Helsinki, Finland: remote controls, 3G/4G

    Helios Torque Fusion Inc.: hybrid propulsion technology

    NIST: RFID technology

    Four Winds Interactive: Software

    Wildlife Protection Solutions: Campaign finance support & poaching information material, domain expertise

    African Conservation Foundation: poaching information material

    References and Further Reading

    Further Reading supporting above statements (Caution: these may raise your blood pressure!):

    1.  Rhino Wars, National Geographic March 2012. By Peter Gwin, Photograph by Brent Stirton: http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2012/03/rhino-wars/gwin-text

    2.  http://rhinoslaughter.wordpress.com/category/rhino-death-toll/

    3.  http://www.traffic.org/home/2012/8/21/loose-horns-surging-demand-and-easy-money-create-perfect-sto.html 

    4.  http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/Defending-the-Rhino.html

    5.  http://www.africam.com/wildlife/the_truth_about_rhino_poaching_an_interview_with_dr_joseph_okori

    6.  http://www.rhinos.org/25-things-you-didn-t-know-about-rhinos

    7.  http://news.softpedia.com/news/6-Amazing-Things-About-Rhinos-and-their-Horns-79342.shtml

    8.  http://www.rhinoconservation.org/

    9.  http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2013/05/why-does-a-rhino-horn-cost-300-000-because-vietnam-thinks-it-cures-cancer-and-hangovers/275881/

    10.  http://ecowatch.com/2013/01/15/rhinos-in-crisis/

    11.  http://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=rhino+poaching+trade&qpvt=rhino+poaching+trade&FORM=VDRE

    12.  http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/extinction-countdown/2013/07/12/rhino-horn-south-africa-legalized/

    13.  http://www.stoprhinopoaching.com/

    14.  http://wildaid.org/?gclid=COPR9firq7oCFe4-MgodBCcAKg

    15.  http://www.bisbeesconservationfund.org/Conservation/SaveTheRhino/

    16.  http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/endangered_species/rhinoceros/african_rhinos/poaching_crisis_african_rhinos/

    17.  http://www.hsi.org/issues/rhinoceros_poaching/

    18.  http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/16/world/africa/helicopters-versus-drones-rhino/

    19.  http://lowveldrhinotrust.org/

    20.  http://ens-newswire.com/2013/01/14/rhino-poaching-death-toll-soars-across-south-africa/

    21.  http://wessa.org.za/get-involved/rhino-initiative/current-rhino-poaching-stats.htm

    22.  http://killingforprofit.com/
story_txt:
What are we doing?: students building UAV to support wildlife conservation.
An international student team (Team AREND) is collaborating to compete in the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge - to design, build & fly an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) to support anti-poaching operations in South Africa.  This student team is led by Dr. Jean Koster at the University of Colorado at Boulder, and includes teams from Helsinki Metropolia University of Applied Sciences, University of Pretoria SA, and the University of Stuttgart.Also collaborating with and supporting / sponsoring this student team is Wildlife Protection Solutions, Helios Torque Fusion, Inc, and NIST - the National Institute for Standards and Technology.  Wildlife Protection Solutions (WPS) is an international non-profit group dedicated
    to the conservation of endangered species.  Their current focus is on the five species
    of rhinos world-wide, with a special emphasis on creating habitat and breeding programs
    that will allow rhino populations to grow faster than they are being poached.  Helios Torque Fusion, Inc. is a Colorado-based business working to commercialize hybrid-electric propulsion systems for UAVs, making the aircraft more fuel-efficient and quieter - both important for wildlife monitoring & protection.
Our video was produced by Ben Fraser and the Denver Zoo graciously provided the appropriate backdrop.



What We Need & What You Get
Our goal is to raise nearly $200,000 to support the project in these areas of development:

Aircraft construction materials, fuselage & wing components, control surfaces and so forth,
Sponsored research with the University teams for use of mechanical and electronic shops, machinists, technicians, and administrative personnel,
Hybrid-electric engine development, balancing long-endurance capabilities with fuel efficiency and low noise,
Trade studies of military-grade sensor packages to detect animals and threats
Team travel for flight testing and site visits, and other documentation and administration as required for aircraft operations.


All contributions will be received by Wildlife Protection Solutions, a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization, and qualify as charitable contributions.  Additionally, every donor will receive memorabilia and recognition for their contributions to the effort - see perk details for more information about donation levels, and what the benefits are for various levels of donation.



The Impact
In the past 40 years, Rhino populations have suffered a 90% decline.  In Kruger National Park alone, 425 rhinos were poached in 2012, and this number has nearly doubled in 2013 as of printing time.  This kill rate is nearing parity with the birth rate, making extinction a grave concern.


Source: Lowveld Rhino Trust
Compounding this problem, the poaching arrest rate is only about 5% due to the extensive poacher networks, and their increasing sophistication.  Park Rangers are in desperate need of a force multiplier, which is where the UAV system comes into play.  
Web Video (WARNING!!!, some scenes of
animal violence may be disturbing, inappropriate for young or sensitive viewers):
1.  http://youtu.be/e_e8V2TvFS8
2.  http://youtu.be/4ATMX_YeQPI
3.  http://youtu.be/eKHu3oNEonU



About the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge
In response to President Obama's Executive Order on Combating Wildlife Trafficking, Princess Aliyah, the Reserve Protection Agency, and Global Unmanned Systems initiated the worldwide Wildlife Conservation unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) Challenge to foster innovation and invention in the design, fabrication, and utilization of unmanned aircraft to assist with counter-poaching and illicit wildlife trafficking.  It calls on students, hobbyists, academics and corporations to sooperate in a design, build, fly & compute challenge that emphasizes the integration of sensors, embedded systems, and communications in a robust and high-endurance aircraft.Princess Aliyah created Kashmir-Robotics as a division of the Al-Kareem Foundation to ensure the best possible aircraft and ground robots are integrated with anti-poaching systems to help protect endangered species.
Please note that this fundraising campaign is specifically to support a team participating in the competition, and not the competition itself.  More info about the challenge can be found here: www.wcuavc.com

More Details about the causal problem...




Demand for
goods made from rhinoceros horns has skyrocketed in South East Asia and China
over the last 6 years due to a rapidly rising middle class in those economies.
At the root of the rhino crisis is the use of rhino horn in traditional Chinese
medicine to treat fever, pain, rheumatism, cancer, erectile dysfunction and
convulsions. Rhino horn is highly sought after in China and more importantly in
Vietnam, despite the fact that rhino horn has been extensively analyzed scientifically
and offers no medicinal properties. Nevertheless, claims of the medicinal value
of these products are broadcast by profit-seekers. Rhino horn is comprised of
keratin, the same material as human hair and finger/toe nails. In addition,
rhino horn is a recreational drug in Vietnam and used by the middle class as a
detoxifying beverage and body-rejuvenating tonic. To satisfy this demand,
poaching in places like Kruger National Park in South Africa is rampant with
captured rhinos killed and left to rot for nothing more than their horns. Many
countries in Africa suffer from poaching. The following map shows poaching
areas and market areas for the Rhino horns.



Rhino horn trade route
Until now
many countries in Asia lacked legislation to prevent legal import of these
goods. Only recently have the Chinese and Vietnamese governments implemented
new laws against the import of rhino and elephant products but the question
remains how quickly these laws will take effect in a flourishing black market. And
more importantly when will the people in these cultures realize the
irreversible damage caused by poaching rhinos is not worth their carved ornamental
artifacts of no use or the ineffective traditional medicine based on horn
material. The syndicated black market continues to supply the demands by the
nouveau-riche until those people change their philosophies. 
Colonel Bobelo
(SAM) says that it became increasingly important utilize in the army when
syndicates began using helicopters, night vision equipment and high-powered
rifles in their hunts. Rangers on the ground are ill equipped to stop the poachers,
often outnumbered and out-gunned by a criminal network that invests in
technology and intelligence to ensure their access to the rhinos. The
deployment of South African National Defence Force (SANDF) members at the
Kruger National Park has brought confidence that Rangers can regain control, at
least to some degree. The SANDF deployed 265 soldiers at Kruger National Park
and the borders around the park in March 2013, following a plea for help by the
South African National Parks (SanParks).


Until 2007 the
poaching was limited. Since 2008 there was a rapid, exponential increase in
poaching. Poaching became a year round activity. Poaching is considered to be a
“low risk - high reward” activity by the poachers, for reasons discussed below.
In recent years poachers use darting guns and veterinary drugs to immobilize
the rhino. Darting guns are silent and prevent detection by patrols. With axes
and/or motor saws, without veterinary knowledge that might give the animal a
chance of survival, poachers cut off the horn anyway they can as it must be
done very quickly in order to retreat fast. In some cases they tranquilize the
animals and mutilate it so much that it cannot survive in the wild, leaving
them to die a horrible death. In other cases they simply kill the animal. 
The poachers
that come from other countries, particularly Mozambique, are armed with AK47s,
grenades, chain saws, axes; GPS, night vision, and sometimes helicopters. They
don't play, these poachers mean business. Many of the poachers are former Mozambican
soldiers and are well trained to fight. They often use “tourists” in the Parks
who join Ranger patrols to have the rangers guide them to locations of Rhinos.
They transmit the GPS data to their command center that then dispatches the
poachers, primarily during cover of night. 
Examples of
poached animals are shown below. They were recent events on the ranch of John
and Albina Hume. Images show how reckless the poachers are in removing the horn
and how traumatic it is for the animals.



Pictures Courtesy of Albina Hume (University of
Pretoria)
Shown below
is another example of a Rhino that survived the poaching act; but only for a
short time! It did not survive the event very long because of the severity of
the wounds. If the animals survive poaching they are often euthanized by
Rangers to stop their incredible suffering.

Picture courtesy of Lowveld Rhino Trust; http://lowveldrhinotrust.org/#
While a
rhino horn price in 2006 was just $1000 for 1 kg (2.2 lbs.), today one kg of
rhino horn has an average market value of about $80,000. Poachers often get
around ZAR1 million (~$100,000) for one horn of about 4 kg (8.8 lbs.). Black
market prices vary widely; as of last fall 2012 dealers in Vietnam quoted
prices ranging from $33 to $133 a gram (0.002 lbs.) ($80 on average), which at
the top end is higher than the price of gold (~$47/gram on 10/26/2013) and
exceeds the price of cocaine in most locations including New York City. 
The poacher
who is going to shoot the rhino reportedly gets R500,000 (~$50,000) from
syndicated criminals, the one with an axe and the third one get R250,000
($25,000) each. Some of the poachers are young unemployed South African men
driven by poverty and lured by foreign syndicates to do the dirty job in
exchange for very attractive amounts of money. These would-be poachers get a
deposit from the syndicates before they carry out the job within a given time
frame. Given their limited understanding of that money, they often spend the
money before having the horn. As their customers are associated with global
organized crime syndicates, the promise to come back with the rhino horn must
be fulfilled at all costs, or else they are in big trouble to repay their debt!
This means that there is also a major socio-economic problem linked to
poaching.
In recent
time poachers commanded by syndicates operate in flash mobs. Multiple groups
enter the park at the same time in small groups. Reports mention that up to 300
poachers were roaming in KNP at one given time. 
Park rangers
are up against well-armed crime syndicates which use funds from poaching for
terrorist activities.  For example,
Al-Shabaab, a terrorist group aligned with al Qaeda, is raking in about
$650,000 a month on the black market from poaching, according to England's
Daily Express. Thus the US government announced a $1M reward for information
leading to the dismantling of some syndicates, primarily operating from Laos (http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/14/world/asia/us-to-offer-reward-in-wildlife-trafficking-fight.html?ref=earth) as reported by the New York Times.

The
fight against poaching has several stages as depicted in the following sketch.
The Rangers are pursuing the poachers in order to prevent the killing. Once the
poacher gets past that line of defense and leave KNP into Mozambique, middlemen
smuggle the horns out of that country to end-markets  Customs officials have some capability to
detect the smuggle ware, but these horns do not usually enter the destination
countries via conventional, legal routes. In the receiving country, there are
the syndicated middlemen who distribute the horns to small back alley shops
where they are prepared for the final market, primarily the nouveau riche
middle class in emerging Asian countries (e.g. Vietnam and China).


Path way of illegal trade. Interceptions are possible at each interface.
And perhaps
there is corruption involved in the entire trade. It appears that criminal
syndicates have infiltrated the law enforcement and justice systems of South
Africa. If an arrest is made, it happens often that filed papers are
mysteriously lost. Once the dockets have gone missing, the case is over and the
suspects are released. These organized criminals have systematically reduced
their risk of breaking important conservation and humane rulings.  They have had the upper hand long enough – it
is time for a surge in protecting forces. It is quite seriously
“one-minute-to-midnight” in the war against poaching! Due to the significant
money some rangers now participate in the poaching as well. On February 2012
four rangers of KNP were arrested on suspicion of poaching rhinos they are
tasked to protect. (http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/29/us-sa...).
Preventive Efforts

Rangers have
often gone into the Kruger National Park to dehorn Rhinos that roam very close
to the Mozambique border. This is a measure to protect the animal from being
killed, as it devalues the animal as a poaching target. These operations are
done by veterinarians who know how to dehorn a Rhino without harm. The horn
will grow back in several years. The Rhino will be less protected against lion
attacks, but still very capable to defend itself vigorously. It would be much
better not to have this kind of need for animal protection! Often the poachers
even kill for a stump.






http://www.ewt.org.za/programmes/LPP/Doc/studyon_dehorning_african_rhinoceros.pdf

Left: The picture shows the
dehorning of a White Rhinoceros Ceratotherium simum in Hwange National Park
during the early 1990s; Photo was taken by M. Kock. Middle: veterinarians
dehorn a tranquilized Rhino for its own protection from poaching. Right: a
Rhino that recovered from dehorning performed by veterinarians. 
Kruger National Park

Poaching is
not limited to the nation of South Africa. Many African Nations, like Kenya,
have major problems as shown in the table below. Much of the poaching is also
done in provincial and private parks in South Africa. However, Kruger National
Park (KNP) is the most severely poached park as bordering with Mozambique. The
Southern White Rhino – 20165 surviving, are under huge pressure of poaching as
the Black Rhino has a population of less than 5000. After declared extinct in
2006, protection has given them a chance to recover. Our project will focus on
the Rhino poaching in (KNP) in South Africa
where the white rhino roams. But the technology could serve everywhere to help
Rangers stop poaching and animal.
The park lies in the north-east of South Africa. It is one of the largest
national parks in the world, with an area of 19,485 square kilometers (~7,580
sq miles); larger than Connecticut and a tiny bit smaller than New Jersey. KNP
is approximately 360 kilometers (220 miles) long, and has an average width of
65 kilometers (40 miles). At its widest point, the park is 90 kilometers (56 miles)
wide from east to west. To the north and south of the park two rivers, the
Limpopo and the Crocodile respectively, act as its natural boundaries. To the
east the Lebombo Mountains separate it from Mozambique the 14th
poorest nation in Africa in 2013 (Financenews).
Source: Google MapsThe park varies in
altitude between 200 m in the east and 840 m in the south-west near
Berg-en-Dal. The highest point in the park is a hill called Khandzalive.
Several rivers run through the park from west to east, including the Sabie,
Olifants, Crocodile, Letaba, Luvuvhu and Limpopo Rivers; waterways that get also
used as rhinos seek waterways.

The
climate of the Kruger National Park is subtropical. Summer days are humid and
hot with temperatures often soaring to above 38 °C (100 °F). The rainy season
is from September until May. September and October are the driest periods, culminating
in rains late in October.
Poaching Statistics

The statistics of poaching show an
increasing number of Rhino poaching events. Below are recent graphs that show
the development of the poaching problem and visualize the exponential growth of
the poaching. The current concern is that the poaching kills are exceeding the
birth rate of rhinos; which is an undisputable warning sign that the extinction
of rhinos is becoming a real concern.

Data source: https://www.environment.gov.za/media/releases/rhinoissue_management_report


Data source: Lowveld Rhino Trust; http://lowveldrhinotrust.org/
Unfortunately the arrests made by the
Rangers have, at best, remained constant and in some cases have even declined over
the years. This trend has reversed a little since the military joined the
rangers in the war against poachers. Of
the 425 poached Rhinos in Kruger National Park in 2012 only 73 poachers were
arrested. Considering that the poaching teams are often 3 to 6 men, this means
only about 10-15 events were caught. That is an anti-poaching “success” rate of
less than 5%! Thus poachers see their effort as a very low risk undertaking and
very lucrative effort. 
In 2013 the number of poached Rhinos in
South Africa has dramatically increased to 408 in the first 6 months. At this
point the numbers exceed 2 Rhinos per day in the “summer” season. KNP takes the
brunt of poaching with 265 animals, most of which are killed in the process.
The rangers, with support of the SA military, recently improved their success
with intelligence driven operations to arrest 56 poachers in that time frame. However,
not all were convicted as files got mysteriously lost in transition.The current (20 November) number of poached
rhinos for 2013 stands at 859 and the total arrests stands at 165 (67 in KNP).
Assuming teams of 3 poachers per rhino, we compute an arrest rate of ~7%; a
slight improvement, possibly due to the involvement of Army soldiers supporting
the rangers. However for KNP the arrest rate decreased to 4.7%. In addition it
is a war: since 2006 some 22 poachers were gunned down. But rangers are killed
as well, often being outgunned by the poachers.

Rhino poaching has dealt
South Africa a financial loss of about ZAR228 million (~$23M) with the 333
rhinos poached last year alone. These are the statistics according to the
Wildlife and Environment Society of South Africa (WESSA); it is for this financial
reason and the need to protect rhinos that the country is going all out to
counter poachers.
Project Rationale

In view of the escalating problem of
wildlife trafficking, President Obama has signed an Executive Order for
Combating Wildlife Trafficking on July 1, 2013: 
http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/07/01/executive-order-combating-wildlife-trafficking

Now you can be part of the solution! Help
us provide an unmanned aircraft solution that multiplies the Ranger’s forces.The graduate University of Colorado
Boulder team will collaborate with international teams at the Universities of
Pretoria, South Africa; the University of Stuttgart, Germany, Metropolia
University in Helsinki, Finland, the National Institute of Science and
Technology and several industries in developing an aircraft with the
appropriate capabilities; thus you will gain experience in design, project
management, technology transfer, global collaborations, cross-functional and
multi-cultural teamwork, critical design analysis, and business organization in
addition to engineering credit. 
Goal

Conceive,
Design, Implement & Operate a special remotely-piloted aircraft equipped
with distinct sensors, embedded systems, and 3G/4G and TCIP communications in a
robust and high endurance aircraft meeting also acoustic and wilderness
operation requirements. The aircraft will be equipped with a hybrid propulsion
system to satisfy one of the prime requirements of the concept of operations!





Baseline
aircraft: Hyperion

The Challenge & Competition



The national Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge is composed
of four phases or milestones. 
Concept – By January 31, 2014
Team proposes a concept aircraft with communications,
sensors, and embedded systems. 
The global team will be developed with
graduate students from the Universities of Colorado, Stuttgart, Pretoria and
Helsinki. International teams of students have select knowledge to augment
Colorado’s team skills. A graduate design course starting in Spring semester
2014, followed by a summer semester course and a Fall semester course is the
framework for this educational project. Volunteers
are working with the international team to prepare this milestone before design
course begins in January 2014.
Build & Fly – By April 30, 2014
The global team shall design, build, and
fly their aircraft and demonstrate airworthiness, communications, and safety at
a local flying field. The deliverable includes a short video documenting Build
& Fly (MP4 File Type). 
Design Report – By June 30, 2014
The teams shall submit a written Design
Report to the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge (http://www.wcuavc.com/home.html ). The report includes a description of hardware
and software for avionics and embedded systems and demonstrated flight performance.
Design reports submitted by all competing teams will be evaluated. Teams will
receive recognition for best airframe, best avionics, and best embedded
systems.
The teams awarded the highest points will
be approved for the next phase of the Wildlife Conservation UAV Challenge which
is the Challenge Flight.
Challenge Flight – August 30, 2014
Teams shall compete in the Challenge
Flight scenario defined by the challenge organizers. The Challenge will involve
a mission profile that includes launch within a time window, climb to
operational altitude of 300 feet above ground level (AGL), transit to several
GPS way-points, collection of video and RFID tag data, on board processing,
communications, return to base, and recovery.
Specific details of the challenge
scenario will not be released until the morning of the competition: teams will
need to be prepared to adjust flight profiles, sensor parameters, and data
processing as needed.
Kruger Mission – Fall semester 2014. Date
to be Determined
The winning team will participate in a
safari and counter-poaching mission in Kruger National Park. The mission will
include several days of demonstrations and operational flights. Sponsoring
companies also can bring equipment to Kruger for demonstrations.
The Hyperion team, with its global
partners, is seeking funding to position itself to develop the ultimate
anti-poaching UAV and thus make a historical contribution to a successful fight
against rhino poaching and finish as the winning team of the competition. 
Long
Live The Rhino!

Photo courtesy of Sean Thomas, The Telegraph

The Project



Conceive, Design, Build, and
Operate an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that helps fight Rhino Poaching. Develop
a special, remotely-piloted aircraft meeting stringent operation-in-wilderness
requirements, and equipped with diverse day/night sensors to detect poachers as
well as tagged Rhinos. The propulsion system is a hybrid gas-electric engine
which provides endurance with the gas engine with the option to fly quietly
with electric only propulsion when poachers are detected. 
The team is composed of
aerospace, mechanical, electrical, computer engineers.
Skills are needed in
structures, composite materials, fabrication, aerodynamics, thermodynamics,
controls, (power) electronics, sensors and instrumentation, software, etc.
Aircraft Requirements:
· 
Aircraft as
described in Design Report. Random changes after submission not permitted.
· 
Small
modifications require submission of revised report prior to challenge flight.
· 
Low cost UAV to
perform counter-poaching missions.
· 
Take-off gross
weight < 55 lbs satisfying AMA regulations.
· 
Compliance with
Build & Fly requirements.
· 
On site
demonstration of communication system.
· 
Must have
mechanical motor arming system
· 
Engine must be
safely accessible by crew member
· 
Safety arming
device must be in safe mode for all payload access.
· 
Communication
must be always powered on
· 
Throttle must be
verified closed before activating motor arming switch. 
Aircraft Performance Requirements:
Evaluated on ease of launch,
endurance, ease of recovery.
· 
Radio or (preferred)
auto-controlled
· 
Endurance goal:
120 minutes flight
· 
Recovery: radio
or (preferred) autopilot recovery
· 
Recovery zone
goal: 10 meters (~30 ft) radius
· 
Take-off weight
with payload < 55 lbs

Communication Performance:
Evaluated based on range,
continuity of coverage, accessibility over internet capable devices (PC, smart
phones). 3G/4G communications with backup radio links.
· 
Range goal: 20
km (~12.4 miles)
· 
Continuity goal:
76-100%
· 
Accessibility
over IP devices: full telemetry with video streaming
Imagery Quality:
Will be evaluated based on
resolution, stability, low ambient light level performance
· 
Resolution goal:
5 centimeter line separation at 300 ft AGL
· 
Stability goal:
electronic image and physical stability
· 
Low light level
(dawn/dusk) and night time
Embedded Systems:
Evaluated based on ability of
onboard system to detect moving ground targets (humans, rhinos) in imagery.
Goal is to detect and geo-register (GPS position):
· 
moving targets 
· 
animal targets 
· 
identify animals
Cost limit:
· 
<$5000 TBR
(without sensor package)
· 
Goal: $1000

Stretch goals: 
For creative and innovative
ideas beyond the required specifications, teams can earn bonus points.
Project Collaborators:
University of Stuttgart, Germany: Aerodynamics and
Composite materials 
University of Pretoria, South Africa: Aerodynamics, Controls,
Wildlife management 
Metropolia University, Helsinki, Finland: remote
controls, 3G/4G
Helios Torque Fusion Inc.: hybrid propulsion
technology
NIST: RFID technology
Four Winds Interactive: Software
Wildlife Protection Solutions: Campaign finance support & poaching information
material, domain expertise
African Conservation Foundation: poaching information
material

References and Further Reading



Further Reading supporting above
statements (Caution: these may raise your blood pressure!):
1.  Rhino Wars,
National Geographic March 2012. By Peter Gwin, Photograph by Brent Stirton:
http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/2012/03/rhino-wars/gwin-text
2.  http://rhinoslaughter.wordpress.com/category/rhino-death-toll/
3.  http://www.traffic.org/home/2012/8/21/loose-horns-surging-demand-and-easy-money-create-perfect-sto.html  
4.  http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/Defending-the-Rhino.html
5.  http://www.africam.com/wildlife/the_truth_about_rhino_poaching_an_interview_with_dr_joseph_okori
6.  http://www.rhinos.org/25-things-you-didn-t-know-about-rhinos
7.  http://news.softpedia.com/news/6-Amazing-Things-About-Rhinos-and-their-Horns-79342.shtml
8.  http://www.rhinoconservation.org/
9.  http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2013/05/why-does-a-rhino-horn-cost-300-000-because-vietnam-thinks-it-cures-cancer-and-hangovers/275881/
10.  http://ecowatch.com/2013/01/15/rhinos-in-crisis/
11.  http://www.bing.com/videos/search?q=rhino+poaching+trade&qpvt=rhino+poaching+trade&FORM=VDRE
12.  http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/extinction-countdown/2013/07/12/rhino-horn-south-africa-legalized/
13. 
http://www.stoprhinopoaching.com/

http://wildaid.org/?gclid=COPR9firq7oCFe4-MgodBCcAKg

http://www.bisbeesconservationfund.org/Conservation/SaveTheRhino/

http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/endangered_species/rhinoceros/african_rhinos/poaching_crisis_african_rhinos/
17. 
http://www.hsi.org/issues/rhinoceros_poaching/
18. 
http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/16/world/africa/helicopters-versus-drones-rhino/
19. 
http://lowveldrhinotrust.org/
20. 
http://ens-newswire.com/2013/01/14/rhino-poaching-death-toll-soars-across-south-africa/
21.  http://wessa.org.za/get-involved/rhino-initiative/current-rhino-poaching-stats.htm
22.  http://killingforprofit.com/

story:
The Jacket has no visible wires and all the electronics systems are integrated in the Jackets  layers.

You need only to set up a comfort temperature and enjoy!






With  your support we expect to have the first production of The Corp Jacket in your hands by late of December 2014. We are very excited about this project and hope you are too. We appreciate your support and please share The Corp Jacket with your friends too!


The amount of funding we require is $200,000. We hope you will find it in your heart to help us deliver this valuable and useful product. 








Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Can I wash my The Corp Jacket in the washing machine?

A: Yes. Wash it at a temperature not exceeding 40° C, without drying. All of the components are shockproof and waterproof.


Q: Is it  safe for health?

A: The jacket has no harmful effect upon people. The automatic temperature control and the possibility to choose the heating areas keep the user from overheating or unwanted heating of certain areas, depending on user’s needs. The voltage in the circuit is 7 volts, which insures a high level of electronic devices security and reliability.

The security tests carried out with the support of the employees of the Military Medical Academy of Saint-Petersburg showed the following results:

- the used electric heaters and their emissions are harmless for people;

- the temperature control in the hip area (2-3° C lower heating as related to the rest of the areas) prevents from kidneys overheating;

- prolonged human exposure to electric heating is not recommended in temperatures exceeding +45° C (thats why we limited heating to +40° C);

- the voltage and electric current intensity in the Jacket are harmless for people;

- the influence upon cardiac stimulators is unlikely.


Q: How can I contact you?

A: You can contact us via e-mail: hello@thecorp.ru

story:
We're excited to share our true story about a little known rainforest with you...



In 2009 we began crowdfunding the iGiveTrees campaign to give trees back to this endangered rainforest, while documenting the process to tell its story...




Learn why it is 93% deforested (look around your kitchen and dining room for clues), and meet the people who have been trying to restore it.



Thanks to people like you supporting a system that included a seed collecting family, a small nursery, a local NGO and many subsistence farm families, we've made some progress toward renewing this endangered rainforest. 



But due to he worst drought in the last century, our main tree supplier went out of business after losing thousands of baby trees in the nursery. 



Our project has been planting organically grown and maintained, native species trees. 


But some of our trees, already planted planted in the fields, are stressed. They need some extra care. What most people aren't aware of is how much manual labor is involved in keeping the trees happy after they've been planted.



We required that NO HERBICIDES be used. Local water supplies have already been contaminated by the chemicals applied to nearby Genetically Engineered Eucalyptus plantations. 

Many seedling trees planted through large reforestation projects don't even survive their first year. Since aggressive braquiária grass was planted to feed pasturing cattle, it must be cut or pulled from around each young tree several times a year. Trees can die due to lack of water, compacted soil and harsh weed control that usually includes herbicides.


During this campaign, anyone who makes a contribution of $60 or more toward TREE CARE will receive a 32 page, full color book, shipped to a US address, delivered in time for Christmas. After the campaign's closing date, books will be available through the iGive Trees website, but we can't offer pre-holiday delivery, and shipping charges will be an additional cost. 


For a $20 contribution you'll receive a download of a printable color poster of the Atlantic Forest in bloom – a sight rarely seen – as well as all of the offerings below.

  

For smaller contributions you'll receive gift cards you can print out, by Touch Drawing artist Deborah Koff-Chapin...


... a stellar music collection by these recording artists: Michael Bernhard Beckwith, Rickie Byars Beckwith, Ben Dowling, Marianne Lewis, Niki Harris, Katherine Woodward Thomas, Jami Lula, Ester Nicholson, Charles Holt, Gary Malkin, Hayley Sales and Faith Rivera...


...and even a gift certificate that you can print to put under your holiday tree! 



Will you please help our planet's children to have the gift of a diverse rainforest that they can give to their children?






Please share this page link on your social media to help us spread the word!

THANK YOU!

Knowing that this page will remain online long after this campaign has ended, I want to share another way you can help us support future tree care. If you shop for groceries through this link , it will not only provide you with quality food at great prices, but it will also support our continued efforts for trees: Thrive Market in support of trees.

story:
Running the Great Wall Marathon to raise awareness and funds towards conserving Snow Leopards in China.

China holds the largest number of endangered Snow Leopards in the world (2000-2500 individuals, potentially 60% of the global population). However the future of the elusive Snow Leopard remains uncertain, threatened by an increase in human activity throughout their range.

There is a need to support local conservation initiatives throughout China in order to ensure the future survival of the species.

We are running the Great Wall Marathon to support and raise funds for such conservation projects. So far, we have two athletes running a total of 63 kilometers (39 miles) dressed up (with spotted face paint and tights) like Snow Leopards. We would love others to take part in supporting this cause by either donating funds and/or joining us during the Great Wall Marathon on May 17th, 2014 in Snow Leopard attire. (great-wall-marathon.com). 

Our goal is to raise a total of 20,000 RMB, with $1,000 (~6,200 RMB) through this website. We have already raised over 11,000 RMB in cash here in Beijing.

All proceeds will go directly to conserving Snow Leopards on the ground in China. Money will support the Wildlife Institute's work in conserving Snow Leopards in China's Gansu Province, by allowing the conservation team to assess how many Snow Leopards are currently living within QilianShan Nature Reserve. More specifically, the money will contribute to monitoring Snow Leopards (using camera traps) and support the local conservation team during the 2015 winter survey.

For more information feel free to contact Justine directly at justine.s.alexander@gmail.com or read the following article: http://www.cityweekend.com.cn/beijing/blog/environmentalists-who-will-save-china/

*fun fact: snow leopards cannot roar, so let’s roar for them!

story:
Short Summary

Vashon Nature Center is a nature education organization supporting a community of islanders and visitors who connect with island natural wonders and with each other through research, education, and citizen science. 

OwlCam is a 24-hour livestream camera that we plan to install on an owl nest box this winter. Nesting season usually starts in February or March. This camera setup will allow us to share with everyone 24-hour footage of a barn owl family from egg to fledging. We will set up a livestream feed so that anyone may tune into it, any time!  Extra funds raised will support WildCam Vashon, an islandwide network of motion-sensing wildlife cameras including OwlCam.

We are excited about this for many reasons:

  • Over the past few years, VNC staff and landowners where nest boxes have been placed, have learned a lot about the diets and habits of barn owls. And much of what they have observed has not yet been published in scientific literature. Having more community eyes on our owl nest boxes through this livestream feed has the potential for continued discovery and understanding about owl lives and behaviors.
  • We are all about creating community around nature! A community-sponsored owlcam, for the viewing enjoyment of all islanders, is an inclusive, shared natural history observation experience that has the potential to contribute to science. We are excited for our community to experience the thrill of following the daily lives of these amazing creatures.
  • This provides a tremendous educational opportunity for teachers and students (locally and around the world) to learn firsthand about the lives of owls. Our local elementary school second graders study owls every year-OwlCam would be a great addition to this unit!
  • OwlCam will be part of the Vashon Nature Center's larger wildlife camera network: WildCam Vashon. When owls are not nesting we will be able to use this livestream to share other amazing wildlife experiences with the local community. 

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to Heidi Grimsley at John L. Scott Realty we already have $500 designated for our livestream OwlCam! Axis Cameras and Camstreamer have also generously provided some camera equipment and software setup donations. Our goal is to raise the remaining $1500 for equipment and maintenance that will enable us to get the livestream camera off the ground. 

The $1500 will be applied directly to the livestream Owlcam. If we receive more or less than $1500, the donations will be applied directly to WildCam Vashon. This includes administration and supplies for our existing motion- sensing camera network (35 remote sensing cameras) to cover: administration, storage space, batteries, memory cards, cable locks for wildlife cameras, replacing wildlife cameras that break etc. 

We have offered the use of VNC wildlife cameras to many island residents who have noticed interesting wildlife on their properties and we will continue to do so. By teaming up with you, we have monitored deer kills and bear sign, salmon carcasses, and coyote movement patterns. We have checked for mountain beavers (but only turned up large rats so far), and confirmed beaver and cougar residents. Do you have an owl box? Do you have a nesting pair of owls? Contact us and perhaps we can livestream from your property one season!

The Impact

  • OwlCam is a part of WildCam Vashon, a citizen science program that actively engages our community in learning about our local wildlife. We build community as we share the common experience of observing and discovering nature together.
  • Wildlife cameras are very effective, non-invasive ways of learning more about animal habits and needs.
  • Together we can make discoveries about our local wildlife to help us better live alongside our wildlife populations. And possibly make new contributions to science!
  • Wildlife cameras provide early detection systems for new island species. For example, we relied on wildlife cameras to verify the presence of black bear, cougar, and beaver over the last two years on Vashon-Maury.
  • These cameras are also amazing educational tools that we can share with our local schools to supplement science curriculum.

Risks & Challenges

Owls can change their nesting preferences, so there is a small chance that owls will not nest in an area where we can easily livestream this year. If this is the case, we will do our best to find another potentially useful location. If not, we will put the camera to use in another engaging location monitoring other island wildlife. We are not short on ideas!

We may experience difficulties setting up the livestream due to internet availability and the remote locations we may be working in. We have already asked for extra assistance from the vendors providing the cameras and software due to the nature-based locations we will be working in and received confirmation that they will assist us to the best of their ability.

Life in nature can be difficult: not all owl babies survive and sometimes entire nests are lost. If this happens we will grieve the passing of the owls and wait to see if the parents try for a second brood. If they don't we will have to wait until next year as moving the camera to another successful nest mid-season would be too disruptive for the animals. We may also choose to cut footage if circumstances become too hard to watch, or are not appropriate for children.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share this indiegogo page on Facebook, Instagram (#vashonnaturecenter), and by email!
  • Contact us to volunteer on projects or help us monitor existing wildlife cameras: info@vashonnaturecenter.org
  • Can you provide technical trouble-shooting experience for livestream setups or remote internet/hotspot access? We would love your help.

story:
Our Story:

The Getting to Zero Project is a model for sustainable living and social innovation. This campaign is more than just saving an historic or old commercial building in a sustainable way. This project will serve as an example of a non-profit driving sustainable value with inclusion and benefits for everyone. Community residents, students, interns, volunteers, political and business leaders will participate together for the health and well-being of themselves and the planet. 

My name is Vera Struck. I started Terrabluteams*, a Massachusetts non-profit corporation in Ipswich last January to fulfill a decade old dream. Terrabluteams is here to inspire, educate, motivate and facilitate positive change in human behavior towards a sustainable lifestyle and workplace; one person and one business at a time. 

Our programs empower individuals with an engagement model to lead themselves, their families, communities and workplaces towards a sustainable world.

From the bottom UP, a grass roots approach, not from the TOP DOWN.

And who am I? I’m an artist, mother, three-time cancer survivor and entrepreneur.

And who are TerraBluTeams? We are educators, advocates, business and community leaders who believe sustainability is not just an option but an imperative. The health and well-being of each of us and the planet make a more sustainable world to live in.

* I am campaigning as an individual as my non-profit is still awaiting 501 (c)(3) status certification, the IRS just informed us that when our status is activated, all contributions will be deductible retroactively to June, 2012.

 

The Impact:

Environmental and Economic Impact:

There are many old and historic buildings in this country. Most of these older New England structures have inefficient or wasteful energy use. The Getting to Zero Project will model zero carbon living and working for other communities to emulate.

In the construction of the project we will be employing mostly local carpenters, electricians, engineers, architects, sustainability experts, students, interns, volunteers will help the local economy and revitalize the area.

There will be an airbnb unit for anyone to rent for a few days to see what zero carbon living is like and learn how it was achieved.

The building will be green; LEED and other organic and green certifications will be sought. It will have rainwater collection and grey water systems, solar design, super insulation, recycled materials, triple glazed windows, a heat-transfer ventilation system, and an air-to-water heat pump that will maintain a 63 degrees F temperature throughout the building year round.

Social and Cultural Impact:

We will be educating the youth, residents and other community members about zero carbon living. There will be classes with visiting sustainability specialists about how to live a sustainable lifestyle and sustainability for small business.

There will be space for theatrical and artistic performances, art galleries, and interactive exhibits on how the project was completed.

We will have paid residencies for local artisans and environmental artists.

The general public will have opportunities to use the Center for workshops and gatherings. Fun for all ages!

In partnership with Ipswich Community Access Media, we will continue executive producing sustainable education programs (done 6 already) about sustainable living and working.  

What We Need:

We have already hosted a small fundraiser, gotten the support of Ipswich residents, business and community leaders and members. We’re applying for grants and are awaiting our 501 (c)(3) status (IRS informs us they are still 6 months behind, when status is granted, all donations are deductible retroactively to 6/2012). We are doing all we can to fundraise but still need money from YOU!! Our budget is 1.2 Million, this campaign goal is $500K and every donation large or small gets us closer!

So how did we get that number?

1. These are the properties we have under consideration, an Old Town Hall (vacant) and an old auto repair place with a mixed use 2nd building (also vacant). About 40% of our budget is to secure a downtown structure (see below-both are in need of lots of work and love).  

http://terrabluteams.org/getting-to-zero-project-indiegogo-proposed-properties/

2. Rennovation, retrofitting, and repurposing the structure with all green materials, renewable energy for a net-zero environment will cost, according to estimates an additional 40%. We need to make sure the building is sustainably built, materials and waste are properly repurposed or recycled.

3. With the remaining 20% we will employ local contractors, interns, students, an author and videographer (Book and DVD) architects, sustainability specialists and engineers (with decent wages!)

  

What You Get:

IndieGoGo Perks (What You Get):

Pledge $15 or more:  Web Shoutout

A Facebook and Twitter Shoutout on TerraBluTeams Facebook page and Twitter with our gratitude for your contribution to make the world a more sustainable place!

Pledge $25 or more:  Getting to Zero Book and DVD

A copy of the Getting to Zero Project Book and DVD (When construction is completed, estimated Summer, 2013)

Pledge $125 or more: Update Podcasts

Project Update Podcasts with Chapters of Book and DVD as they are made, and all previous tiers

Pledge $250 or more: Weekend Stay in Getting to Zero Project AirBNB unit

2 night stay at Getting to Zero Airbnb Unit (When construction is completed, estimated Summer, 2013) and all previous tiers

Pledge $500 or more: Private Tour of Getting to Zero Project and Invite to Private Opening the week before Project Opens

Lunch with TerraBluTeam Founder and private tour of building just before the Private Opening party that you attend, and all previous tiers

Pledge $1,500 or more (only 2 of these): An original painting by TerraBluTeam Founder, artist Vera Struck

These 48” x 48” exquisite fine art originals on canvas are entitled “Tuscan Dreamer #1” and “Tuscan Dreamer #2”. Their value is $2,500@.

Pledge $5,000 or more: Donor Recognition Wall

Your name listed on artist designed donor recognition wall in hallway of completed Project Building, and all previous tiers except the $1,500 category.

All larger tiers and their perks are listed here.

If you are in or near Ipswich, MA., want to volunteer, help with interns or be an intern, do not hesitate to reach us at vera@blucirclezeroplus.com.

All perks will be delivered when funding is received with the following exceptions: The Getting to Zero Book & DVD (written as the project is being constructed), free nights at the Getting to Zero AirBNB, private tours and Opening Party Invite obviously cannot be delivered until construction is completed.

 

Relevant perk link with higher donor categories:

http://terrabluteams.org/getting-to-zero-project/

 

Other Ways you can help:

Please help us spread the word. Share our campaign with your family and friends that care about sustainability, art, organic gardening, culture, education, food, health, and helping the community of Ipswich, MA., on its quest for sustainability (while helping the Earth and humanity)!

Please send this link to other people who may be able to donate or share the link on Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn.
