story:
About Me

My name is Felipe Correa and I’m the Founder of Easybici Chile, an e-mobility company that uses electric bike (e-bike) technology to implement sustainable transportation projects in areas that experience high-impact tourism.  Our company focuses on two strategic areas: Tourism and local communities that support tourism.

I was born in Santiago, Chile but grew up in the United States. Since my early days as a Boy Scout in California I had always been fascinated by the outdoors; it had everything I ever needed—big rocks to climb and shiny rivers to swim in. As I got older and, hopefully, more aware, I started to learn about how people and responsible companies that offer sustainable tourism alternatives can have a huge impact on the health of the environment.  That knowledge, coupled with my professional interests as an entrepreneur, led me to establishing my own sustainable tourism business in tourist-heavy communities that offer little to no sustainable transportation alternatives. 

Easybici Chile started in early 2015 with a fleet of 20 e-bikes for tourists to visit popular attractions in and around Santiago, Chile.  In a short time, we have experienced real demand serving over 3,000 tourists and growing!  Because of our sustainable model, we have been awarded the CORFO national seed funding award (2015) and the Santiago regional seed funding award (2015)—awards given to organizations that are making an impact by implementing innovative business ideas that have a positive impact on the environment.  (CORFO is a Chilean government entity that supports and finances up and coming industries.)

With our success and experience in Santiago, we set out to explore opportunities to make a difference on Easter Island, one of the top tourism destinations in Chile.  We established Easybici Chile on Easter Island in July of 2015 with a fleet of 17 e-bikes and have served over 2,000 clients to date. 

Because of our tourism business, we’ve become part of the local Chamber of Commerce, which has allowed us to learn first-hand about the unsustainable growth challenges of the island, particularly on the transportation side. This project for a sustainable e-bike transportation project is a first step towards addressing some of these challenges.

 

The Project

Phase one of our project on Easter Island started in 2015 with the establishment of a fleet of 17 e-bikes for tourists to visit popular attractions around the island.  With the "pedal assist" features of an e-bike, which makes a ride over 30 kilometers while climbing hills pretty much effortless, and the reduction in CO2 emissions from using an e-bike instead of a car or bus, makes the e-bike the ideal transportation alternative to motorized vehicles and traditional bicycles.

Although bicycles provide the greatest health benefits and lowest environmental impact, they are not an ideal option for the physical realities of riding long distances against strong island winds and over hilly terrain.  Nor are they an ideal option for tourists who want to maximize their time, effort and comfort as they get around the island.  Without an alternative like the e-bikes, tourists will opt for the only other option on the island—cars and buses—which will only add to the traffic, noise and pollution that are already a problem.

Since 2015, our e-bike rental business on Easter Island has served over 2,000 riders from over 45 countries, typically between the ages of 35 and 65.  The impact of these riders renting an e-bike over a car or hopping on a bus is real and tangible, and we now want to make this even bigger!

 

Our goal is to move beyond tourism and implement phase two—a scalable, sustainable transportation pilot project for the local community of Easter Island. Once funding is secured, we will set up a centrally located station in Hanga Roa, the main city on Easter Island, which is home to 87% of the population.  The station, which is the same recycled shipping container that we use for our tourism business, will hold 20 e-bikes and be staffed by attendants who will register riders, manage the e-bike loans, maintain the equipment, and collect information to track our progress.

For this pilot project, the e-bikes will be for the exclusive use of public employees (such as national park employees and civil servants) who have specific and regular transportation needs during the week. We will work with them to collect a variety of information to determine the project’s success and, if it is, plan the strategy for phase 3—securing government and private sector support to expand the program to multiple stations throughout the island, and making e-bikes available at no-cost to all residents of island. 

CORFO, the government agency dedicated to promoting investment, innovation and entrepreneurship to achieve sustainable development, is developing a strategic initiative to make Easter Island a model of sustainability for high impact tourism destinations by 2025. Our e-bike project is aligned with these goals.

This sustainable project is based on a solid foundation—our experience and success from our e-bike rental services.  Thanks to our tourism arm, we are already on the island making a difference every day.  We hope that you will be as excited as we are about the possibility to make a huge impact on the environmental health of Easter Island and the quality of life of it’s residents by partnering with us on this project!

 

Use of Proceeds

The budget to fund the pilot project for the first year is $80,000.  This includes fixed start-up costs for a fleet of 20 e-bikes (valued at $2,000 each with shipping), a modified shipping container to store the bikes ($4,000), e-bike parts ($6,000), safety equipment ($2,000), and working capital (mostly personnel $28,000).  One hundred percent of the funds raised will go towards the development and execution of the project.

After the first year we´re confident that the project will attract enough sponsorship to cover the overhead of additional e-bikes and stations, ongoing personnel and maintenance.

If we don´t reach our goal of $80,000, we will start the project by investing in fewer e-bikes. The project is viable and can have an impact with as few as ten bikes.

 

Contribution Perks!

For your support we have some cool perks!  Depending on your giving level, these can include digital postcard updates of the project, a one-on-one video chat with our crew on Easter Island, a one-of-a-kind contribution certificate designed and signed by a local artist, and a complimentary VIP e-bike tour for Easter Island or Santiago, Chile. 

The impact you´ll be making is real, tangible and immediate.  By far, the biggest perk is that you’ll be partnering with us in an effort to create a more sustainable environment on one of the most unique places on earth.

 

Risks and Challenges

On Easter Island there are always challenges.  Luckily, our experience from phase one (sustainable tourism) taught us a lot about how to work in such a remote place.  Some of these challenges include not being able to order replacement parts quickly (there is no overnight express service to the island) and the increased risk for rust due to the humidity and salinity of the air.  But all of these challenges can be addressed with a comprehensive maintenance plan and a well-trained staff. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can´t contribute financially?  No problem!  Please help us spread the word about this wonderful effort to create a more sustainable environment on Easter Island. Share this campaign with your family and friends, and on your social media networks by using Indiegogo’s convenient share tools! 

 

 

Sustainability side note:  We understand that electric bikes use electricity and, therefore, by themselves are not technically sustainable.  An electric bike releases .19 kg of CO2 from the production of electricity, while a small car releases 6 kg of CO2 per person / per car.  What is important to consider here is the impact of the offset of C02 production when a passenger chooses an e-bike over a motorized vehicle.  A full carbon neutral study on the impact of our campaign and the implementation of solar panels to offset any electricity use is in development for 2017.
story_txt:
About Me
My name is Felipe Correa and I’m the Founder of Easybici Chile, an e-mobility company that uses electric bike (e-bike) technology to implement sustainable transportation projects in areas that experience high-impact tourism.  Our company focuses on two strategic areas: Tourism and local communities that support tourism.
I was born in Santiago, Chile but grew up in the United States. Since my early days as a Boy Scout in California I had always been fascinated by the outdoors; it had everything I ever needed—big rocks to climb and shiny rivers to swim in. As I got older and, hopefully, more aware, I started to learn about how people and responsible companies that offer sustainable tourism alternatives can have a huge impact on the health of the environment.  That knowledge, coupled with my professional interests as an entrepreneur, led me to establishing my own sustainable tourism business in tourist-heavy communities that offer little to no sustainable transportation alternatives. 
Easybici Chile started in early 2015 with a fleet of 20 e-bikes for tourists to visit popular attractions in and around Santiago, Chile.  In a short time, we have experienced real demand serving over 3,000 tourists and growing!  Because of our sustainable model, we have been awarded the CORFO national seed funding award (2015) and the Santiago regional seed funding award (2015)—awards given to organizations that are making an impact by implementing innovative business ideas that have a positive impact on the environment.  (CORFO is a Chilean government entity that supports and finances up and coming industries.)
With our success and experience in Santiago, we set out to explore opportunities to make a difference on Easter Island, one of the top tourism destinations in Chile.  We established Easybici Chile on Easter Island in July of 2015 with a fleet of 17 e-bikes and have served over 2,000 clients to date. 
Because of our tourism business, we’ve become part of the local Chamber of Commerce, which has allowed us to learn first-hand about the unsustainable growth challenges of the island, particularly on the transportation side. This project for a sustainable e-bike transportation project is a first step towards addressing some of these challenges.

We will work with them to collect a variety of information to determine the project’s success and, if it is, plan the strategy for phase 3—securing government and private sector support to expand the program to multiple stations throughout the island, and making e-bikes available at no-cost to all residents of island.

story:
Help us Create  the biggest park of native honey plants in Slovenia. 

We are Petra and Bogdan Mak, the owners of the SUN PARADISE Estate (Posestvo SONČNI RAJ). We want to plant 9,500 seedlings of exclusively native honey plants planted in the Honey Park area. The plants will make possible for bees to pollinate flowers and crops, and reproduce naturally. We want to preserve Slovenian tradition and create a sustainable study park for children, youth and adults. 

The Honey Park project has more than 2,5 hectars of meadows to be turned into extensive meadow orchards, set to offer biodiversity typical for our area.

We tend to plant about 9,500 seedlings - a plant per every tenth resident of the Maribor city and its surroundings. Symbolically, we would like to map the number of people living in our city and show that it is possible to make a change towards preserving and protecting nature in a big city such as this one.   

The honey park is based on the idea of ensuring bees a biodiverse and a quality eco feast. Instinctive bee pollination and that of other insects is our future, it is the future of our children and it feels right that those of us who care about tomorrow devote our time and energy to this.

Your donation will help us purchase the seedlings and show that you care about sustainable development.

This is slovenin website: zasadimo.si, our English website is in progres..

story:
Hello everyone, my name is Mark and I am an engineer.  My partners are Bob (architect), Bruce (4th generation farmer), and Drew (social media/advertising guru).  We have designed a business model to accomplish building homes with sustainable materials and powered with renewable energy.  The centerpiece of our plan is to put in 2+ acres of organic vegetable gardens and use sales from gardens to pay utility, tax, and maintenance bills.

With the obvious changing weather patterns, we simply must reduce our carbon footprint.  By addressing food, energy, and housing from a renewable-sustainable perspective, we can do lots of good for everyone.

We need your help in raising $500,000.00 to ready the gardens for a 2014 harvest, do site prep (grading/landscaping), build a tree house educational center, pay upfront engineering costs, and pay for your perks.   And speaking of the perks:  @ $25 contribution, you will receive heirloom vegetable seeds or LED light bulbs, @$50 you get custom T shirt or hat, @$125 you can select (2) of the above, and @$250 your name /city on garden shed wall of fame, plus you receive all four perks.  All funds received through the campaign will be applied to the beginning priorities to accomplish completion of the project.  

We will be building 24 condos made with sustainable materials and powered by renewable energy with 2+ acres of organic vegetable gardens.  Our plan is to start in Fountain Inn, SC and then build  many of these developments in the southeast US first. As we perfect our build plan, our goal is to expand our capabilities to build anywhere. The environmental challenges are huge, but as with any challenge the solution can be achieved one step or one bite at a time.  Enough of these kinds of projects will begin to have significant impact on our shared environment.  Each of the partners has achieved individual success during their careers and are ready to collectively as a team be successful with this new mission.

So please consider helping us ignite a renewable-sustainable evolution that will help us all. You can follow our progress on our website "Renewable-Sustainable-Living.com" and be looking for our continuing blogs.  Please tell your family, friends, neighbors, associates, and anyone else you want and thank you again for your support

story: We found out that a certain corporation is about to start building a natural gas well with a few satellite wells around it in Northern BC. Four of us are heading there to help protect mother earth. We are also going to write a book about our travels. If you would like to help us out you may contact Mona Lisa Saulnier on Facebook. We will post info on the "Natives And Bikers For A Healthy Environment" page. Send a request and we can add you. we will be selling tickets on this air brushed flag by Gerry LeBlanc proceeds going towards a trip to Northern BC to protest fracking. $5 per ticket. 3 for $10. Contact Mona Lisa Saulnier https://www.facebook.com/idlenomore22.

story:
Help fund my work to control the threat of underwater noise pollution to marine animals in the high seas. My name is Lora L. Nordtvedt Reeve and I am asking for your support.


The next year is a critical time for the conservation of marine animals in the high seas.

Credit:  National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS)

“Undersea noise pollution is like the death of a thousand cuts. Each sound in itself may not be a matter of critical concern, but taken all together, the noise from shipping, seismic surveys, and military activity is creating a totally different environment than existed even 50 years ago. That high level of noise is bound to have a hard, sweeping impact on life in the sea.”

-Dr. Sylvia Earle, Former NOAA Chief Scientist

We are polluting the seas with sound.

  • Commercial shipping noise interrupts the hearing, navigation, and communication of whales, dolphins, and fish.
  • Noise from seismic exploration and offshore drilling scare dolphins and whales away from prime foraging prime areas.
  • Military sonar noise causes frightened whales to strand themselves on beaches and die.

    In 2005, pilot whales stranded on the coast of North Carolina, likely caused by U.S. Navy sonar. Credit: NMFS Southeast Fisheries Science Center. http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/health/mmume/event2005jan.htm


    The world is waking up to the terrible consequences of noise pollution in the ocean.

    Squid & Octopuses Experience Massive Acoustic Trauma from Noise Pollution in the Ocean

    http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/04/110411111032.htm

    Shipping Noise Causes Major ‘Stress’ in Whales

    http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/9068202/Shipping-noise-causes-major-stress-in-whales.html

    Whales Flee from Military Sonar Leading to Mass Strandings, Research Shows

    http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/jul/03/whales-flee-military-sonar-strandings

    Whales Are Being Killed by Noise Pollution

    http://www.newsweek.com/2014/04/11/whales-are-being-killed-noise-pollution-248069.html

    Mounting Concern About Underwater Noise Pollution Harming Marine Wildlife

    http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/environment/mounting-concern-about-underwater-noise-pollution-harming-marine-wildlife.25062564


    How do we control noise when it travels over vast ocean distances and does not stop at national boundaries?

    Noise pollution in the ocean is an international problem that requires an international solution.

    Right now there is no treaty to control ocean noise and it is not officially classified as a marine pollutant. Some nations have acted to try to manage noise along their coasts, but in the high seas there is very little meaningful regulation.

    World shipping lanes. Credit: European Commission. http://bioval.jrc.ec.europa.eu/products/gam/sources.htm

    We have a unique window of opportunity.

    In 2015, the United Nations will take up the issue of whether to protect biodiversity in the high seas. We need to make sure underwater noise pollution is considered in any action by the global community.

    https://www.un.org/depts/los/biodiversityworkinggroup/biodiversityworkinggroup.htm

    To support this goal, in 2015 I will begin my Ph.D. project at the Australian National Centre for Ocean Resources and Security, University of Wollongong. The project will explore options for the international community to regulate underwater noise pollution generated by human activities in the high seas.

    http://ancors.uow.edu.au/index.htmlu.au/index.html

    The product of my research will be a comprehensive book that offers practical solutions for the global management of underwater noise pollution and supports advocacy for quieter oceans. The book will serve as a resource for scientists, policymakers, educators, and conservationists.

    Lora surveying for whales aboard a research vessel off Maui, 2008.

    Over the last ten years, I have prepared for my research through the study of law and science, professional experience with U.S. and international conservation organizations and government agencies, and publication of legal papers on high seas policy issues. 

    http://www.brill.com/ocean-yearbook-26 http://mainelaw.maine.edu/academics/oclj/vol-18-no-1.html

    My path has been guided by my passion for developing effective conservation policy for the ocean. I hold a law degree in international ocean law and a master’s degree in marine mammal ecology.

    Lora attending the marine biodiversity working group meeting at the United Nations as a member of the IUCN delegation, 2011. http://www.un.org/Depts/los/biodiversityworkinggroup/biodiversityworkinggroup.htm

    In November 2014, I will be a speaker and high seas panel member at the 3rd International Marine Mammal Protected Areas Conference and a rapporteur for the High Seas Panel at the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) World Protected Areas Congress. Follow me at quietocean2015 on Facebook and Twitter.

    http://www.aomevents.com/ICMMPA3 http://www.worldparkscongress.org/index.html

    https://www.facebook.com/pages/Quiet-Ocean-2015/788964567833143

    To fund the first phase of my research, I am seeking your support to raise $13,600.

    100% of every dollar you contribute will go toward the expenses associated with my expenses during my research in Australia.

    And the perks are all sea creatures that are harmed by underwater noise pollution!

    Thank you!

story:
Where are dumpsites?

An estimated 40% of the world's waste ends up at dumpsites. These sites are typically located in low and middle-income countries.

We have identified some of the World's most polluting dumpsites. Several of these sites directly threaten marine or coastal areas.

There are thousands of more dumpsites around the world.

 

 

 

How are dumpsites polluting our Oceans?

Most cities and towns around the world are located by the ocean, a sea or a river. Dumpsites are the de facto waste management option for many of these cities and towns. Wind, landslides, erosion, and flooding allow plastic and other waste to make its way into waterways that lead to the ocean, or in some cases, waste can flow directly into the ocean. And that's just the impacts on the oceans!

 

And what about our environment?

Dumpsites are also a major contributor to climate change and harm human health.  Illegal dumping and disposal practices often take the form of uncontrolled burning, accentuating the release of toxic gases that include furans and dioxins as well as black carbon, a climate pollutant.

 

What's the difference between dumpsites and engineered landfills?

Often the terms 'dumpsite' and 'landfill' are used interchangeably, but they're very different...

 

Who are we?

We are the International Solid Waste Association: a global, environmental not-for-profit working in the public interest to promote and develop sustainable waste management worldwide.  We started in 1970. Our members are waste professionals from 110 countries across Asia, Africa, the Middle East, South America, North America, and Europe. We have expertise across all aspects of solid waste management. We are taking leadership on addressing global waste issues - including marine litter and open dumpsites.

 

Our approach.

We have developed a Roadmap for closing dumpsites. This report provides the guidance required, to each and every local authority or government, for the process and procedures required to close a dumpsite and develop an alternative sound waste management system. 

ISWA is running a long term multi-year programme to raise awareness about dumpsites and deliver best-practice in helping communities to move towards sustainable waste management practices close dumpsites. 

Closing dumpsites is neither simple nor quick. It requires an alternative waste management system, adequate planning, institutional and administrative capacity, financial resources, social support and finally political consensus. All of these conditions are really difficult and sometimes impossible to meet in countries where dumpsites are the dominant method of waste disposal and level of governance quality is questionable. 

To make any lasting change or impact ISWA understands that there has to be complete buy-in to the process by the local governments and authorities. Therefore, ISWA wants to work with municipalities that are committed to closing open dumpsites and moving up the waste hierarchy with a long-term vision of achieving a circular economy.

ISWA is interested in working on closing all dumpsites and not only ones that are close to the rivers and water sources because we recognise that all open dumps affect the environment and the health of people living around them.

 

What is your donation for? Where will your money be spent?

Your money will be spent by ISWA towards a feasibility study to identify site specific solutions for a specific dumpsite and replace it with locally appropriate solutions, such as an engineered landfill. We will work with local associations and government partners to achieve this.

 

Success to date.

We have had success campaigning in Brazil, where the government closed the Estrutural dumpsite. This was the biggest dumpsite in Latin America and was polluting the groundwater of Brasilia, the capital. It was successfully closed and replaced with an engineered landfill that safely contains the waste. The city is now also building recycling facilities. Read about ISWA's success story 

 

Get involved!

Just a few of the biggest dumpsites have been closed, but there's more to go!

We can’t do it alone. We need your help to raise funds and awareness about this issue. Please share our campaign with your friends, family, and colleagues.

 Together we can #MakeDumpsitesHistory

story:
Our Story

We are a group of Thompson Rivers University (TRU) students in Kamloops, British Columbia, Canada, who are interested in monitoring weather and climate change in hopes of protecting our community. 

We want to create a solid collection of weather data accurate to our region in Kamloops. This will help in future community planning and understanding of urban weather patterns. 

For example, a mine has recently been proposed just outside the boundary area of Kamloops and there has been a great deal of debate as to the environmental impacts it will have on the city. The monitoring of meteorological patterns within the urban area can act as an indicator if any negative change is occurring, and the resulting magnitude.
Currently, there is a weather station located at TRU that has historically been used for research and teaching purposes. However, it is now outdated and no longer functioning properly.

                   

                                                The current TRU weather station. 
New research equipment for the University would provide reliable data, which would be operated by trained faculty at the University, and available for students in training. 
By having your support, we can achieve together a real time system to monitor our environment and provide the tools for future hands on learning for students at Thompson Rivers University. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $500.00 but we are aiming to raise $10,500.00. This will go towards site updates and repairs consisting of much needed landscaping, general maintenance to existing equipment, and the addition of a remotely accessible data logger, which will cost approximately $500.00. In addition, we want to purchase a radiometer to measure energy inputs and outputs and can be used to monitor changes in atmospheric pollution levels. Depending on the quality of this piece of equipment the cost can range from $1500.00 to $10,000.00. Also, we would like to acquire an air quality monitor which typically cost approximately $5,000.00. 

                           

                                                                  Radiometer
Our initial funds will go towards the $500.00 in updates, with additional funds being put towards a radiometer. Any remaining funds will go towards the purchase of an air quality monitor and future research projects. 

Our Aim

  • Protect environment and quality of life.
  • Provide reliable data/research with open and easy access for the public.
  • Ensure accountability for industry and commercial.
  • Provide a basis for future work, research and learning.
  • Maintain current and reliable equipment for valuable results. 

Risks & Challenges

The only risk is that we do not achieve our goal.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate but have an interest in our project, you can still help us! Please share our campaign with the link provided and tell your friends about us.
Thank you!!

story:
Mission Statement

    The mission of the Interfaith Alliance for Environmental Stewardship is twofold. First, it is to bring people together. We want to foster a tolerant and loving environment in our communities, with faith groups and environmental groups working together for a better future. We want to open up dialogue about our commonality with the people around us, despite apparent differences, and we want to bring peace to a world wrapped up in unrest. Second, it is to cultivate a deep passion for earth and the environment in our communities and faith groups.
What We Need & Why We Need It

Our goal of $3000 goes to specific company needs (in order of importance):

  • $650 organization startup costs
  • $350 website costs
  • $500 miscellaneous/preparatory fund
  • $1000 work stipend for full-time work commitment
  • $500 prize costs (approx.)                                                                                             

The Impact

Our organization has a unique goal of fostering community through interfaith dialogue, using a common love for the environment as a conduit for this dialogue.

  • We represent faith groups in specific regions, allowing for regional community building, and representation of individual faith groups
  • We have had positive feedback from each faith group we have contacted so far, and have received significant support from the interfaith, collegiate, and environmental community. 
  • We exist entirely for the benefit of the community, the faith groups we represent, and for a more sustainable earth.

Possible Risks

Nothing is easy, and starting a non-profit organization has many risks:

  • Our organization relies entirely on support from the interfaith community, so if the faith groups aren't interested, the organization won't fulfill its role
  • It is sometimes difficult to find a common tongue, and be relatable to representatives from many different faiths             
  • We intend to do everything we can to be relatable to representatives from many different faith traditions, and overcome these possible risks with perseverance and creativity                        

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and share our campaign!
  • Go to our website and sign up to be a member!

story:
BASIC INFORMATION

The Machias  River Wigwams Program is a dual-mission outdoor career education and environmental restoration program serving teens from Washington County, Maine. Participants enjoy a two week backcountry immersion experience that engages them in outdoor professions including guiding, field biology, archaeology and habitat restoration.The Machias River Wigwams Program is an opportunity to educate and inspire the next generation of Maine outdoor professionals by connecting today’s Washington County youth to outdoor traditions and giving them relevant skills and experiences.

This program is a partnership between the Downeast Salmon Federation  and the Cobscook Community Learning Center, and is an expansion of a highly successful 2013 pilot.

The group in Eastern Little River.

THE PROGRAM AND THE RATIONALE

The Program

Teens live as a group in the wilderness at the Wigwams Rapid on the Machias River. They work with our staff, agencies and volunteers doing river habitat restoration and trail work.The program has been designed to blend three important experiences for young adults:  it is one-third overnight camp experience, one-third school, and one-third summer job. The Wigwams Program eliminates common barriers for young people from our area to participate in summer camps meaningful summer employment and the same time that it builds their skills they can actually build careers around. Participants in the MRWP have the chance to experience the camaraderie, humor and community of a camp, but also learn from visiting outdoor professionals. They are expected to contribute hard work and long days under the direction of group leaders who act as teachers and mentors rather than as traditional bosses. The program takes place in July so that participants can still work the wild blueberry harvest in August. The Machias River Wigwams Program strives to build skills for a comprehensive suite of outdoor recreation and outdoor careers that includes a wide range of disciplines from nature-based art to sustainable forestry to fish biology and wilderness trip leading - all built around a deep care for the beautiful Machias River watershed.

A teen operates a grip hoist to add large wood to a stream to recreate lost habitat complexity.

If you are a Washington County teen, or you know one who would like to participate, please contact Maria for an application. (maria@mainesalmonrivers.org)

Why is something like this necessary?

This is necessary because Maine is the last chance to maintain wild Atlantic salmon in the United States, and this restoration effort is the perfect opportunity for local teens to emerge from simply living here into stewards and outdoor professionals.

The Downeast Salmon Federation was founded by local anglers in 1982 to address the decline of the wild Atlantic salmon in the northeast United States.  The Wigwams Program builds on 32 years of habitat protection and restoration  in the Downeast region. However, since this once-famous salmon fishery has been closed, today’s generations do not have memories of catching sea-run salmon or a concept of the salmon as a public resource and responsibility.  This brings the next generation of Washington County youth into engagement and action around our watershed. While Washington County kids are surrounded by some of the least developed forests and watersheds on the east coast, many of them do not have access to outdoor experiences because of financial barriers and lack of skills on the part of their parents. This program strives to help youth who want to stay in Washington County find their own "recipe" to do it.

THE NUTS AND BOLTS

The Wigwams group and volunteers from the Passamaquoddy Tribe excavate a disturbed riverbank as part of an archaeological dig.

Budget

Total Costs for the Wigwams Program = $25,538. Of that total, $8,503 is realized through in-kind support. The balance of $17,035 translates into $95 per participant per day for a powerful transformational 15-day outdoor experience. That is the total cash we need to raise. Our IndieGoGo campaign goal is $10,000. We anticipate that grant funds will cover the balance of our program expenses. Please be as generous as you can. Your contribution will enrich a young person's life.

Expertise

The Machias River Wigwams Program is a unique partnership between the Downeast Salmon Federation (DSF) and the Cobscook Community Learning Center (CCLC). CCLC has extensive experience running youth and outdoor programming, including an expedition-based high school program. DSF has a 32-year history of watershed education and restoration in the Downeast region. The trip leaders for the Machias River Wigwams Program, Michael Giudilli and Maria McMorrow, are well supported by both organizations for emergency response, parental liaison and any other needs. Michael and Maria are both certified Wilderness First Responders and lifeguards. Michael has a degree in Recreation Management and Maria is a Registered Maine Guide. The Downeast Salmon Federation arranges the collaboration with agencies such as US Fish and Wildlife, Maine Department of Marine Resources and Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, so that all habitat restoration is done to the latest scientific specification and under the correct permits mandated by the Endangered Species Act.

HOT PERKS

All contributions are appreciated. The perks we offer contributors are closely tied with the land and character of the area, and to our program. Below are descriptions of the Downeast Salmon Federation's camps. These include everything from handwritten thank-you notes from participants to weeklong stays at DSF's rustic camps. Learn learn more about the camps in the following descriptions.

The Camps

The “Camp” is a traditional and current part of Maine culture. Camps might be cottages, log cabins, tar-paper shacks, canvas wall tents or any other kind of structure where people get away from the demands of daily life. Year after year, families and friends head “upta’ camp” to fish, bond with each other, goof off and unplug.

We are offering contributors the opportunity to stay at the Downeast Salmon Federation's rustic Maine camps. These camps have wood stoves but no electricity, and sleep between 4 and 10 people - each one of the 3 camps is located in a different secluded place along the Machias or the Narraguagus River. 

The Wigwams sleeps 7 and is accessible by 4WD vehicle, or 2WD vehicle and a 1/4 mile walk. Of course, you could always paddle up! It is right on the water and has gas lighting and a gas stove. The Wigwams Rapid  (part of which is pictured above) is a great place to fish or paddle. 

The Lack Camp has bunks for 4 and a large open loft that will fit many more. Closer to town, it is further downstream on the Machias and connects to an award-winning multi-use trail system. This camp has drive up access but is still totally secluded.

The Boar's Nest camp is a circa 1930 log cabin on the Narraguagus River accessible by a 15 minute walk or a 45 minute paddle. It is surrounded by 14,000+ acre area of protected land. Though it does take a little planning to get there, the Boar's Nest is truly a wild Maine experience.

**Most but not all dates are available. Depending on weather, a short walk or paddle may be necessary for access.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP 

The group heads across the blueberry barrens back to the bus.

We don't just need money! There are many, many ways to support this project. 
Volunteer time, lumber, tools and farm fresh eggs are examples of much-appreciated donations we received and used during the 2013 pilot.

In particular, we could use clothing, footwear and gear donations. We found that many participants don't have great equipment to bring. 


Here are some suggestions:
Sleeping bags (packable is helpful!)
Rainjackets and rainpants (not ponchos)
Daypacks
Drybags
Dry sacks to line daypacks

Wool socks

Sandals that will stay on in water (with a back strap)

Good quality rope

Headlamps

Work gloves

If you have a way to get some of these items, or other ideas of ways you might be able to give, please contact Maria McMorrow (maria@mainesalmonrivers.org)

(maria@mainesalmonrivers.org)

story:
Dear Friends:

We are a group of artists and designers, scientists and ocean advocates, who have spent the past seven months working to develop an innovative ocean project.

This non-profit initiative, called Blue Trail, is a trail of seven interactive art-science installations to be located along the San Francisco waterfront this fall, each designed to connect people to the ocean and inspire them to take action for a sustainable blue planet.

Explore the 7 installation designs in the Gallery above.

 

Why We Care – and Hope You Will, Too

Some of us came to the Blue Trail project as passionate ocean advocates. But many of us came with an average level green environmental awareness.

Together we are working to raise awareness of "blue" as vital to "green" and to communicate the urgency of responding to plastic pollution, loss of habitat, and marine species extinction. The ocean is at a tipping point.

 

 

What Makes Blue Trail So Innovative?

Blue Trail is a new approach to getting people to care about the ocean.

Blue Trail asks: If the scientific reports documenting these problems are not inspiring change, what would happen if artists and designers got involved? Can they help make a difference?

Blue Trail has assembled seven creative teams who are ready to produce large-scale immersive and interactive "art and science" installations along the San Francisco waterfront - one of the world’s most visited public promenades - focused entirely on ocean sustainability.

We believe deep within our bones that art can connect people to the beauty, mystery and, importantly, the fragility of the world’s oceans.

If these waterfront installations make people feel more connected and engaged in ocean sustainability, those experiences will resonate and inspire them to take action within their own lives and land communities. 

 

 

Please give today to make Blue Trail a reality – and tell your friends to join you. Your donation makes a difference! 

We are ready to build the Blue Trail.

We have the seven designs in hand (see Gallery above). And we have laid the political, logistical and collaborative groundwork required (no small feat!).

The missing piece is the funding.

It costs an average of $25,000 to $50,000 to produce one installation. While we intend to raise most of our budget from corporate sponsors, we hope you will help us raise our first $25,000 to kick-start our campaign. How much we raise in sum will determine how many of the installations we produce (we want to build them all!).

Your donation will send a clear message to potential funders that the ocean is important, that art is a powerful tool for making a difference, and that Blue trail is an innovative investment of time and resources.

 

Thank you!

PS Special thank you to Blue Trail artist and internationally acclaimed photographer Lukas Felzmann who is contributing images from his archive documenting plastic pollution on the Farallon Islands for the "perks" that you will receive when you donate $250 and above!

 

Note: Blue Trail is a fiscally-sponsored project of Intersection for the Arts, one of San Francisco's leading arts institutions. Collaborators include UCSC OpenLab, United Nations Safe Planet Campaign, and 7Story. Pro bono PR is provided by Saatch & Saatchi S.

story:
Our Story

Did you know that on just a quarter of an acre of land, you can grow enough to provide over 4/5 or 80% of the yearly food consumed by a family of 3 plus have a surplus left over to sell at the local markets? By using intensive farming methods, a "mini farmer" can produce as much in 1400 square feet as a conventional farmer can on 3/4 of an acre! (Source: "Mini Farming", by Brett L. Markham)

My name is Jeanine. I live with my husband, Bendar, and my son, Rohnin, in Clyde, Ohio.  As of November, 2011, Ohio's unemployment rate was 8.5% (from http://www.bls.gov/web/laus/lauhsthl.htm) with many of Ohio's counties in our area at a higher rate than that, not to mention the unemployment rate in the rest of the United States and beyond! The jobs that are available are the lowest paying in recent history and certainly come with little to no benefits. In addition, food and energy prices are continuously rising.

People are going deeper into debt just to feed their families and put gas in their tanks. What if they knew that they could take their land, even if it's just a few hundred square feet, and turn it into a mini farming operation that would save them thousands of dollars on food every year and even generate revenue by selling surplus produce at the local markets? How much gas money could they save by taking fewer trips to the grocery store and eliminate the need to drive to a second job that is now unnecessary?

Mini Farm Project Sustainability aims to answer these questions and provide the people in our community and beyond with the tools they need to save money, generate income, and harvest fresh, healthy produce from their own mini gardens by using intensive farming techniques. We plan to make a documentary that follows our journey to become more self-sufficient while establishing our mini farm as a community resource to help others see what is possible and that it can be done. Many people in the U.S. feel that they need to change the way they live but are afraid to take the first step or don't know where to start. We will take that first step for them by becoming their support system, helping them decide where they will construct their gardens and other small support structures taking into consideration their land size, layout of their property, physical abilities of all household members, free time available to work the land, etc. We want to know what their goals are and help them to reach those goals, whether it is saving thousands of dollars yearly on food or more ambitious goals that include generating extra income. This may allow a mother to have more time with her children or a retiree to live more comfortably on a fixed income. For a family in danger of losing their home, it may very well tip the balance in their favor.

We will accomplish our ultimate goal in the spring of 2013 when we open a community garden where we host classes on mini farming and let people who have no land access grow their own crops on our land to save money on their food bill, freeing up income for other needs. Learning how to grow, harvest, and preserve crops will help people in our community and beyond to become more self-sufficient and therefore empowered to help themselves and others. We are hoping those we help will go on to become successful mini farmers and help other future mini farmers! We do not have, nor do we wish to have, a monopoly on this information. 

 

The intensive farming methods we wish to employ include, but are by no means limited to: 

- Planting crops in raised beds versus traditional rows which raises the temperature of the soil by around 10 degrees, thereby extending the growing season.

- Planting crops closer together, eliminating the need to weed, which will drastically cut down on the workload.

- Planting cover crops to replenish nutrients, keep soil in place, and create green manure. 

- Thermophilic composting to kill pathogens and turn table scraps, animal manures, and green manures into nutrient-dense compost that will replenish soil depleted by growing crops.

- Covering raised beds with an inexpensive frame & plastic sheet, making it possible to extend the growing season to January, even in northern states.

- Using natural pest control to protect crop yields and prevent chemical insecticides and fungicides from contaminating crops by eliminating the need to use them.

- Preserving the harvests for later consumption using canning, vacuum-packing, freezing, storing via root cellar, and other preservation methods.

- Saving open-pollinated seeds from crop plants that flourished, eliminating the need to purchase seeds for the next crop year and increasing the chances of a more productive future harvest.

 

Do you want to learn more about intensive farming techniques? I recommend these books, though there are countless resources on this subject:

Mini Farming: Self Sufficiency on 1/4 Acre, by Brett L. Markham

The Backyard Homestead: Produce all the food you need on just a quarter acre!, by Carleen Madigan

The Urban Homestead: Your Guide to Self-Sufficient Living in the Heart of the City, by Kelly Coyne & Erik Knutzen

The Self-Sufficient Life and How to Live It, by John Seymour

 

The Impact

If we are not able to raise the funds we need by July, the consequence is that it will take us much longer - likely years - to save the money we need to start mentoring people who are hungry for this knowledge. We need to get started this summer by preparing the land for crop growth, starting thermophilic compost, and reaching out to our immediate community and beyond through farmers markets, health food stores, community organizations, and especially through developing and dispersing our mini farming documentary. 

We live on rented land. According to park rules, we are not allowed to have the small, 20 square foot garden that we dug four years ago, but others in our park have tomato plants and small gardens, so for the time being, the landlord is letting this slide. I tried to grow medicinal herbs a couple years ago only to discover that my landlord had decided to dig up and mulch the area I had planted them which destroyed all of my plants. It is very limited what we are allowed to do on our rented lot, and I know there are many people who are in a similar situation or who don't have any land at all. This inability to work the land is why we need your help. If we already had our own land to start even a few hundred square feet of raised beds, believe me, we already would have done it, and we would not have the need to humbly ask for your help!

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $10,000 that will go directly towards the down payment on a parcel of workable farm land on at least 2 acres. That's it. We are not asking for money to buy a pre-built greenhouse or truck in loads of bricks to surround the raised beds. We will build this mini farm as cost-effective as possible once we have the land by doing the work with a spade and garden fork, double digging the raised beds and surrounding them with low-cost wood or free cement blocks - whatever we can get our hands on. The $10,000 will simply allow us make a down payment to acquire the property - we will supply the man and woman power! 

Time line of our project:

February - August (ongoing) 2012: Use intensive farming techniques in our 20 square foot garden on rented land. We will share our experiences with this endeavor in the documentary and on our website http://minifarmproject.com/, then apply this knowledge on a larger scale to the newly acquired parcel of land, comparing crop yields from conventional farming techniques that we had used in previous years.

April: $10,000 funding goal reached. A savings account will be opened which will be used solely to hold these funds for land purchase.

July: Apply for loan pre-approval while locating a suitable property.

August: Purchase property.

September: Dig raised beds. We plan to double dig at least 300 square feet of raised beds with plans to dig more as we have the resources including time and funds. To put this square footage into perspective, using intensive gardening practices, if we planted only one crop - carrots, we should be able to harvest 900 pounds of them in one growing season!

October: Attain straw, start thermophilic compost pile, plant cover crops.

November: Piece together video footage from February all the way to the current time, giving viewers an intimate view of the beginnings of our mini farm. We will distribute the work in progress with plans to expand on the documentary in the spring of 2013 when we begin preparing for the first crop year.

December 2012 â€“ February 2013: Develop our teaching curriculum, drawing from our experiences up to the current time and reaching out to more knowledgeable mentors in our area and beyond to help decide the best approaches to teaching intensive farming techniques. We will also start advertising our class dates/times at local farmerâ€™s markets, health food stores, websites, etc.

March: Start seedling indoors and begin preparing the land that will be used by students (prepare raised bed and compost areas as well as connect water supply to the area for crop watering/irrigation).

May: Plant our first big crop and begin our first mini farm classes.

If we raise additional money over the $10,000, it will allow us to:

- Buy a slightly bigger parcel than we originally planned, accelerating our plans to help the community by providing more workable land to those who have none.

- Dig more raised beds than the 300 square feet we are currently planning in the fall before winter comes, making it possible to plant more cover crops to create green manure for composting and plant more food crops in the spring.

- Spend more time working on our documentary, making it available to the international community in a more timely manner.

As a way to say thank you for your generosity, we have 8 perk levels for you to claim that range from $5 to $1000 that we will be overjoyed to give to you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with everyone you know who may believe in empowering people to live sustainable, healthy lives. We are ambitious, but we need your help to get the word out and reach our donation goal! Feel free to visit our website at http://minifarmproject.com/. We can be found on twitter @MiniFarmProject and on Facebook and Google+ by searching for Mini Farm Sustainability Project. Do you need to write a paper or conduct a study to earn your college degree? Consider our mini farm as the subject of your studies. We are happy to share our experiences for the benefit of everyone! Consider a visit to our mini farm once it is operational, as we will have tours available.

We will bring positive change to people who are searching for a way to better their lives. Whatever you are willing and able to give, we are grateful. I hope I have conveyed my excitement about the capabilities of a mini farmer who has a little land to work, and I hope you are excited, too!

story:
“CYCLES OF CHANGE”

EcoVids, a project Great Leap, Inc.

Promoting small changes that can make big differences in our environment.

 

Great Leap is launching into the creation of its third environmental music video, CYCLES OF CHANGE, about the virtues of bicycling as an alternative form of transportation and a healthy way of living in Los Angeles.  Directed by Dan Kwong, the video features song and performances by Nobuko Miyamoto and the Chicano rock band, Quetzal. Created in conjunction with CicLAvia and the Los Angeles County Bike Coalition, the storyline will include professional actors, cameos by celebrities as well as community participation.

 

EcoVids is a series of music videos that use music, story, culture and humor, along with hard facts to inspire and engage people to make small changes in their lifestyles that can make a big difference in our environment. These short videos are now distributed through YouTube and other social networking media.  We also engage communities in proactive events and interactive websites to further education and participation. With Great Leap’s 34 years of experience of cross-cultural performing arts, these videos aim to include communities of color in the environmental conversation.

 

Cycles of Change Goals:

 

  • To use the arts to educate and empower people to make healthier environmental choices
  • To show people they are connected and a natural part of mother earth
  • To bring communities of color into the environmental dialogue by shining the light on their cultural wisdoms and practices
  • To pass on earth-friendly cultural traditions between older and younger generations
  • To use digital technology to reach the widest of audiences, and to encourage participation in that process.

 

About Great Leap: 

Great Leap, Inc., is a Los Angeles-based, multicultural arts organization which uses art as both performance and creative practice to deepen relations among people of diverse cultures and faiths and to transform how we live on the earth.   We collaborate and create with professional artists, foster new leadership in the arts by mentoring emerging artists, and build community through our workshops, residencies and performances.

story:
GREENevada believes that every school can be green and every child can learn global responsibility through local example. Together, we can transform the way students learn.

Our Story

GREENevada – Growing Resources for Environmental Education in Nevada – is a coalition of seven non-profits in Reno that includes the Alliance for Climate Education, Black Rock Solar, Envirolution, GreenPower, Keep Truckee Meadows Beautiful, Sierra Nevada Journeys and Urban Roots Garden Classrooms.

In 2011, we held our first Student Sustainability Summit, bringing together high school students from Washoe County, Nevada to share their ideas for improving their schools' environmental standing.

Thanks to a grant from Pepsi Refresh, we awarded $28,000 to nine high schools. The winner, Reed High, won $12,000 to improve water efficiency in the school bathrooms.

This year, students from all over Northern Nevada are invited to share their ideas at the 2012 Student Sustainability Summit, on April 20 at the University of Nevada, Reno. School teams have been working on their projects for months, and are ready to present them in front of a judging panel of distinguished educators and community leaders.

All we need is the prize money to recognize and support these hardworking students.

 

2011's first place winners, the Reed High Eco Warriors

 

The Impact

Many of our local schools have the desire to make changes, but not the funds. For some schools, change can be as simple as removing styrofoam from the cafeteria. For others, it might mean starting a school garden or even installing solar panels. All of these things cost money.

Participating school teams must present:

 

  • Research of their school's current situation
  • A project plan with a budget

 

Their presentations are judged by a panel of experts, who ask pointed questions about the viability of these projects. The goal is to fund a project that will not only be completed under budget, but will truly benefit the school.

Your donations don't just recognize the students' hard work. You can help fund improvements that will help schools, teachers and students for years to come.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The more you give, the more we can give directly to the students. We've set the bar at $4,000, but we're hoping for more. As a coalition of nonprofits, we don't take a cut of the money. Minus a few expenses, it goes directly to the schools.

Every school will receive prize money. The more you give, the farther it goes.

We've also secured donations from a number of local businesses, in exchange for being featured sponsors. We'd like to offer you a few perks in thanks for your donation, too. Check out our list of perks below!

 

Rainshadow Charter School won second place in 2011.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Pass it on! Tell your friends about GREENevada and the students' efforts, and ask them if they can donate $20 or more.

And please join us and cheer on our teams on April 20th at 2pm, in room 110 of the Davidson Mathematics & Science hall.
story_txt:
GREENevada believes that every school can be green and every child can learn global responsibility through local example. Together, we can transform the way students learn.
Our Story
GREENevada – Growing Resources for Environmental Education in Nevada – is a coalition of seven non-profits in Reno that includes the Alliance for Climate Education, Black Rock Solar, Envirolution, GreenPower, Keep Truckee Meadows Beautiful, Sierra Nevada Journeys and Urban Roots Garden Classrooms.
In 2011, we held our first Student Sustainability Summit, bringing together high school students from Washoe County, Nevada to share their ideas for improving their schools' environmental standing.
Thanks to a grant from Pepsi Refresh, we awarded $28,000 to nine high schools. The winner, Reed High, won $12,000 to improve water efficiency in the school bathrooms.
This year, students from all over Northern Nevada are invited to share their ideas at the 2012 Student Sustainability Summit, on April 20 at the University of Nevada, Reno. School teams have been working on their projects for months, and are ready to present them in front of a judging panel of distinguished educators and community leaders.
All we need is the prize money to recognize and support these hardworking students.
 

2011's first place winners, the Reed High Eco Warriors
 


The Impact
Many of our local schools have the desire to make changes, but not the funds. For some schools, change can be as simple as removing styrofoam from the cafeteria. For others, it might mean starting a school garden or even installing solar panels. All of these things cost money.
Participating school teams must present:
 

Research of their school's current situation
A project plan with a budget

 
Their presentations are judged by a panel of experts, who ask pointed questions about the viability of these projects. The goal is to fund a project that will not only be completed under budget, but will truly benefit the school.
Your donations don't just recognize the students' hard work. You can help fund improvements that will help schools, teachers and students for years to come.
 


What We Need & What You Get
The more you give, the more we can give directly to the students. We've set the bar at $4,000, but we're hoping for more. As a coalition of nonprofits, we don't take a cut of the money. Minus a few expenses, it goes directly to the schools.
Every school will receive prize money. The more you give, the farther it goes.
We've also secured donations from a number of local businesses, in exchange for being featured sponsors. We'd like to offer you a few perks in thanks for your donation, too. Check out our list of perks below!
 

Rainshadow Charter School won second place in 2011.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Pass it on! Tell your friends about GREENevada and the students' efforts, and ask them if they can donate $20 or more.
And please join us and cheer on our teams on April 20th at 2pm, in room 110 of the Davidson Mathematics & Science hall.

story:
Short Summary

Hello friends.

Are you wanting to become more involved in the animal rights community but don't know how or where to start?!

On May 26, 2018 in Zagreb, a peaceful march will be held to demand the closure of all slaughterhouses and to end the violence that we inflict on non-human animals. We will be joined by compassionate citizens, who will march in solidarity.

As a society, we have marched against sexism, racism, and homophobia. Now, we ask you to join us to march against another oppression: speciesism. Our fellow non-human Earthlings desperately need us to act against their continuous pain and suffering at the hands of an animal-eating society. Meat, dairy, and egg consumption cause more suffering and death than any other human activity and are completely unnecessary.

It is estimated that every year 1,000-billion aquatic animals are killed worldwide. That's 1,902,588 every minute or 31,710 every second. And, even worse, it's estimated that each year 64-billion land animals are killed worldwide for the appetite of humans (or 121,766 every minute and 2,029 every second).

It's time to state clearly the necessity to abolish nonhuman slavery, and oppose the practices that exploit, torture, and murder animals. Please join us for this critical event and speak out on behalf of those who cannot speak for themselves. This march is part of a movement needed to permanently shut down all slaughterhouses and will ultimately awaken the greatest transformation of humankind.

What We Need & What You Get

In addition that organizing the protest requires time, dedication, consistency, many people are involved arbitrarily and voluntarily, unforeseen situations arise, but some parts of organizing the march inevitably generate the costs. Costs of march organization are roughly $ 5.000,00 and include stage setup, proclamation, required noise measurement by the City of Zagreb, power supply,  stand setup, announcement of march, making, printing and placating posters around the city. As part of the event, a concert will be held where special performers are invited – Darko Rundek and band ŽEN.

By contributing to our campaign you can directly support our strive to spread the message of compassion and kindness, and influence people not only in Croatia but worldwide to become aware that animals are not ours to consume, wear, torture or experiment on. They are not here for our enterainment. You also support a long-term vision that generation of our children, and the one after that, will not have to fight this fight! So that they can live in a world free from disconnect, cruelty and suffering. A world where all animals live safe, happy and free. Peace begins on your plate.

The Impact

So this is our 3rd march in Zagreb. More and more people recognize how much the importance of action is and march is expanding to other countries as well. This year, activists from Serbia decided to start on organizing their first international march of this type.

We organized two marches in 2017. On March 11, 2017 was held "1. International Protest ANIMAL LIBERATION for Closing All Slaughterhouses“ and May 27, 2017 "2. International Protest ANIMAL LIBERATION for Closing All Slaughterhouses ". The idea developed in line with the international "March to Close all Slaughterhouses" event that began in Paris and is now held every year in France, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Turkey, the UK, Australia, USA, Canada, Brazil.

You can see how it all looked like in 2017 in Zagreb via links below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vGf_0bucW40

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hhWUxulkB74

More details on the international protest for closing all slaughterhouses and the "Animal Liberation" association can be found:

Web: www.oslobodjenje-zivotinja.com

Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/Oslobo%C4%91enje-%C5%BEivotinja-Animal-Liberation-395299990665869/

Facebook group:  https://www.facebook.com/groups/1326459500747530/?ref=ts&fref=ts

Facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/391726344609176/

YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCFADudZZSnC1LfC_rzhqYcA

Other Ways You Can Help

Even the tiniest donation is appreciated, but if you can't contribute financially perhaps you can help in another way, by sharing this campaign on Facebook and/or other social networks. Also, we are inviting you to support the march with your arrival and send a message with us to give animals the right to appropriate treatment and basic right to life!

Thank you so much for checking out our campaign and remember: „Speciesism is a failure, in attitude or practice, to accord any nonhuman being equal consideration and respect." – Joan Dunayer
